name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Jens Gieseke and Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy on behalf of the Committee of Inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive industry on the investigation of emission measurements in the automotive industry (2016/2215 (INI)) (A8-0049 / 2017).

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner Bieńkowska, ladies and gentlemen! Thanks for the good cooperation to my co-rapporteur Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy and all shadow rapporteurs. Twelve months of work, 27 meetings and a total of 47 hearings are behind us. We have already adopted the final report in the committee and achieved great success. We have succeeded in presenting a balanced report and we are now about to vote in plenary. What conclusions can we draw from the work of the past twelve months? The result of the report is clear: nobody actually assumed that there was willful fraud. In addition, unfortunately, no law in the world can completely protect against willful fraud. But it is also clear that the current regulations on exhaust gas regulation offer too much room for interpretation. The Commission and the Member States should have enforced clearer rules and acted earlier. That is why I ask: Firstly: We now urgently need the implementation of the emissions tests in real road operation. By the way, using the latest technologies there are already clean diesel engines that comply with the limit values ​​on the road. Second, we need better market surveillance. The aim here is to eliminate deficits between member states and the EU Commission. The cooperation between the Member States and the Commission did not work. Neither the Commission nor the Member States have considered defeat devices as a possible cause of the discrepancies between the NOx emissions measured in the laboratory and those measured on the road. The scope and the provisions of the prohibition of defeat devices have never been objected to by either side, nobody has asked for clarification here. Emission reduction strategies - that sounds very technical; it is too. However, if these so-called strategies mean that within of a certain thermal window - that is, only at a certain temperature - the emission reduction is fully switched on, this is very difficult to justify on the grounds that this serves to protect the motor. The same applies to a certain time window if this time window roughly corresponds to the test duration on the roller stand. Here the engine protection was designed very broadly, also at the expense of environmental protection and air quality. That is not acceptable. In addition, the provisions of EU law for exceptions to defeat devices are not applied uniformly in Europe. That is why we need uniform legal implementation in the EU more than ever. In the event of discrepancies, the European Union must be given powers to make legally binding decisions. Otherwise the law will continue to be applied differently. The Commission did not monitor the enforcement of the defeat device ban, although it was obliged to do so. Most Member States have not put in place an effective, proportionate and dissuasive system of penalties to prevent unlawful use of defeat devices. Neither the Commission nor the Member States can give a good report in this regard. But now it is important to look ahead. As far as better market surveillance and uniform implementation of the law are concerned, some colleagues keep bringing an EU agency into play, based on the motto: if there is a problem, I simply invent a new agency. I ask myself why. There are already 34 decentralized agencies, plus other executive agencies. These are associated with high administrative costs, too much bureaucracy and additional costs for the taxpayer. We do not need another bureaucratic agency to monitor the market and ensure uniform legislation. Much more efficient and The task could be taken up by the EU Commission in a more cost-saving manner. I am surprised, Commissioner Bieńkowska, that the Commission does not seem capable of this task. So, we as the EPP definitely trust you as the Commission and you as Commissioner to do this. You have our support. In addition, some colleagues are calling for consumer compensation. Firstly, we have to state that there is no uniform legal basis in Europe, as there is, for example, in the USA. In Europe we have a high level of protection for consumers in a global comparison. This protection is defined at the level of the Member States - and that is a good thing - and ultimately judged by the courts. In this context, I find some amendments for today's plenary vote remarkable. On the one hand, comprehensive compensation is required, on the other hand, no employee should be negatively affected by such compensation. If you make such a request, then you should also be honest that you are putting hundreds of thousands of jobs in the automotive industry at risk. A policy of "wash my fur but don't get me wet" will not work. Furthermore, European vehicles could be retrofitted so that they comply with the limit values. This was not possible in America. And finally, this type of compensation does not solve the real problem. That is the last and most important point I want to bring to the end: the real problem is poor air quality. As the EPP, we have now tabled an amendment to the plenary, in which we are setting up an environmental fund so that ultimately those who are really injured are also compensated, namely cyclists and pedestrians. Not only the consumer as the buyer of a vehicle is affected, but above all pedestrians and cyclists. I believe that we as the EPP are innovative and progressive here are.I assume that this will find the support of the Greens - Bas Eickhout is there, he is already laughing, he will certainly support us on this issue because it is an innovative approach.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Reporter. - I too would like to thank my fellow rapporteur, not only Jens Gieseke, but also his predecessor Pablo Zalba for the pleasant cooperation. Obviously the shadow rapporteurs, the coordinators, the chairman of our committee, but especially the secretariat of the committee, which in the end worked much harder than all of us put together. Madam President, I think that this committee of inquiry has done a very good job. Shocking facts have surfaced and we have become more critical and unified as the work has progressed, including those who were not initially in favor of the creation of this committee of inquiry. I think that we can all be very proud of the final report. We got a lot of facts out and came to very strong, firm conclusions. Nevertheless, I think it could have been even better. Better cooperation from both the European Commission and the Member States could really have resulted in even better work, but also our internal functioning. Why did we start hearings so quickly and not take much more time for the preliminary investigation? Madam President, the final report reads like a train and I really advise anyone who has not yet done so to just read it. Take that half hour, because it provides a unique insight into the failure of the European Union. It presents a shocking picture of European and national failure to get cleaner cars on European roads and it is truly outrageous how the interests of our European citizens have been haggled on such a large scale. The growing discrepancies between lab testing and actual emissions had been known for ten to twelve years! Shockingly little has been done to improve the situation. In fact, the Committee of Inquiry has shown that both within the European Commission and in many Member States, better control, stricter enforcement and the development of a new, better auto test are simply thwarted. Most shockingly, even after the outbreak of the diesel scandal, very little has been done to improve the situation. And the conformance factor of 2.1 is really a travesty. The system was and possibly is - let's face it - rotten. Member states did not want to tackle the car industry more harshly and consciously turned a blind eye. And the quarrel now between Germany and Italy about Fiat is a sign of this: not tackling their own industry, but being very critical of the industry in another Member State. Within the European Commission, fierce battles had been going on for years between the environmental departments and the industry department up to and including the commissioners. Not the interests of 500 million Europeans were leading, nor the simple application of European law. No, unfortunately, the short-term interests of the auto industry prevailed. Our research focused mainly on public actors, but our hearings with the industry and many media reports around them have provided a shocking picture of the industry's lack of sense of responsibility. That is really close to zero! No public apologies, no gesture to car owners, no hands in their bosom, and certainly no sign of responsibility to the millions of Europeans forced to breathe dirty air. On the contrary, stern denials from individual car manufacturers and certainly from ACEA. For me, one of the most shocking moments was when the ACEA representative confirmed to my question that it was also in the spirit of the law to get clean cars in a lab and not on the road. Shocking! Madam President, our investigation is over, but there is still a lot to do. I really expect the European Commission to take our conclusions and recommendations seriously and act quickly, for example by taking responsibility for air quality and to place legislation, such as that on car emissions, in the hand of one Commissioner and not turn it into a debate between two Commissioners. But especially the Member States should read our report carefully and I would advise all national parliaments to also put this report on the agenda in their own parliaments. Not implementing the law should not be acceptable to national parliaments either. But the Member States will also have to look at a much more transparent and open operation of the technical working groups, the technical expert groups, a very big problem. Incidentally, Member States and a Council that is now again shining through absence. And finally, I really sincerely hope that those same Member States, when they deal with the new type-approval legislation, will now really realize that we need to move to a different system with much stronger European supervision. That we really have to get away from that national intention to keep national industry under control and not to think about all 500 million Europeans at all.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to thank both rapporteurs, I want to thank the Chair of the committee, Mrs Van Brempt, all of the members of the committee who really devoted a lot of time and effort to this important topic. I welcome the report. I welcome the conclusions achieved by the Committee of Inquiry into Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) and I am glad that I have again the possibility to discuss it with you.  At the beginning I want to very much stress that we have to remember one thing: the emissions scandal should keep all of us still alerted, for the sake of the consumers who bought cars based on false promises, because of the arrogance in disregarding the rules and, importantly, because of the loss of the time which should have been spent making progress on the topics of the future: driverless and zero emissions cars.  I am sure that today the report will give our citizens too – not only ourselves, but especially our citizens – clarity and transparency about what has happened and what needs to change. Today is really a very symbolic day, on which we can we can start looking into the future, planning and acting. We want the industry to play by the rules and to truly respect and compensate consumers in Europe, not just to say they do so. From today, I want Member States to carry out proper market surveillance and enforce the law. Most importantly, I also want the Commissioners – myself, ourselves – and co-legislators to agree on an effective legal framework for type approval because such abuse should not take place again in Europe. Again, I appreciate the extremely hard work of the EMIS Committee. This was a massive report. Both I and my colleagues welcome your report and the resolution on which you are about to vote.  We have a very common interest, I kept repeating this, to rebuild the trust in our regulatory system, to regain the credibility of our automotive industry and most importantly, to protect our consumers and our citizens. The Commission has made big efforts so far. We have achieved a lot already. Most notably, I have tabled a revision of the type approval framework, but of course there is still a lot more to be done. We will not let up the pressure on Member States to provide us with concrete information and all of the evidence we need from them. The situation on this is still not very good.  I welcome the conclusion of the EMIS report and the European Parliament recommendations. They show me that the Commission is really on the right track. I will ensure a solid follow-up together with my colleagues, with Karmenu Vella, with Věra Jourová, and with Miguel Arias Cañete.  This follow-up will include the allegation of maladministration, because there are some issues to which we can already respond, and this is because we have acted to remedy this situation as quickly as possible. We have done it, as you know, in three areas: better enforcement, better market surveillance and better rules. The work of your committee has been really key in helping us and helping me progress on all three points. Thank you very much for this. Firstly, I am taking a very strong approach to enforcement and I am again grateful for your support on this. We have launched infringement procedures against seven Member States so far, but I am sure we have not finished our work yet and I will launch many more procedures if necessary.  Secondly, as your draft resolution quite rightly says, we need to improve market surveillance. You propose the creation of the European Vehicle Surveillance Agency, and as you will have noticed in the White Paper on the future of Europe that this document refers to a possible enforcement agency, I think we have to really discuss it further in this context. But in the meantime, let us make quick progress on our legislative proposal on type approval.  Thirdly, we definitely need better rules, not just on market surveillance, but overall. I agree with the views in the EMIS report on this point. I believe that our proposals meet your recommendations in this area as well. We delivered on laboratory testing: CO2 emissions, fuel consumption will become really more realistic with the so-called WLTP test. We delivered on the new robust procedure to test CO2 emissions, in real driving conditions, the RDE packages. And we delivered the guidance for the Member States to enforce the ban on defeat devices. Most importantly of all, as I said we have proposed a much stronger type approval system. I welcome the progress that you have made on this proposal and the vote today.  This takes me to my final point. The Commission has taken first corrective actions but of course we cannot be the only ones. At the source of the scandals was the corrupt behaviour of a number of car manufacturers. But, as was also said by the rapporteurs, the industry’s attitude has not changed fundamentally. I hear very often: OK, this case was unacceptable but this is an isolated case. That is not true. There is also the failure of Member States’ authorities to spot this and to react appropriately. Some Member States have taken serious efforts to improve but others are still in denial.  The work of the committee and the work of the Commission will not be done until attitudes change. Let us use this this political momentum to change. This scandal should be followed by a massive work towards zero emissions cars. We are responsible as policy makers because industry needs a clear regulatory signal. Zero emissions cars are the future of this industry. I hope that we can work together to maintain this pressure even after today’s voting and after the report is concluded.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. In Europe, we have two big goals for years. We have climate goals - to reduce CO2 emissions, we have environmental goals - to ensure good air quality. In the transport sector, this culminated in years of policies to support the deployment of diesel engines in Europe. In Europe, among passenger cars, or in contrast to the rest of the world's major economies, we have almost half - as in any country - of diesel cars, other countries do not. This is because it has been found that the diesel engine is not only beneficial in terms of CO2 emissions, but that, if properly regulated, harmful emissions (which are harmful to the environment, say the human respiratory tract, so-called soot) can also be regulated. And so we also wrote in the law that the development of diesel engines must ensure that NOx emissions are low. What actually happened? In fact, it happened that diesels were developed, but for years, virtually all car manufacturers that sell diesel engines have been deceiving us for years as legislators, deceiving us as consumers with their emissions to the air or NOx. The result is this commission. The result is now the scandal that is. But how is this possible? This is possible because laws are adopted at European level but applied or complied with at Member State level. And there is a big, big gap in Europe here - there is too big a gap between the legislator and the law enforcer. Of course, we are changing the law. Of course, there will now be a new testing methodology that will involve not only laboratory tests, but also the emissions they actually have on the road. But here we all have the lesson that, when pursuing one goal, in this case the climate goal, we must be very careful about the possible side effects, such as the impact on air quality.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - In front of you stands an incredibly proud, proud chairman of the first commission of inquiry for ten years. In the beginning, not everyone was equally enthusiastic about the establishment of that committee of inquiry, including the Commission at the time or the Commissioner, but within a few weeks and months we turned that atmosphere around. We have all had the openness to look at the facts. We have had an incredible number of experts and witnesses on our committee in a year and, with the support of many in that committee, but of course in particular our rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs and coordinators, we have succeeded in ensuring that a very solid report has been submitted. I would also like to especially thank the people at the secretariat. Every day I have seen how they fought to get the right people on our committee time and again. That was really a feat. Now is the time to look a bit at the future and the recommendations, so not only look at what went wrong, but also at what we want to see adjusted in the future. We obviously have an absolute duty to ensure that the cars on the road are clean. That is why it is extremely important that we bring down that conformity factor, Commissioner. That we ensure that we can introduce remote sensing and, for example - a very important thing - start measuring NOx, also during the vehicle inspection. We are also strengthening - as we do in the Dalton report, which has also been well-cooperated - type-approval and market surveillance, and they cannot fetishize an agency at all. However, it is important - and I would like to appeal to colleagues, especially the Liberals and the EPP - to think carefully about it. It's not about extra. It's about making sure we have an independent mindset that can do good auditing implement.And finally: never waste a good crisis.Make sure that the car of the future that will be built in Europe is a car that is completely clean and we want to focus on that too.Thanks again to everyone who worked so hard in this committee.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Colleagues, the "dieselgate scandal" could and should have been avoided. The large differences between car emissions in the lab and those on the road were known and there were indications of possible fraud. Nevertheless, no action was taken to vigorously address the structural problem. On the contrary, the implementation of effective field testing has been significantly delayed. The conclusion cannot be misunderstood: irresponsible member states and a negligent European Commission pushed public health aside. Especially vulnerable road users and children are affected. Poor air quality makes citizens gasp for breath and makes them critically ill. In the EU, 75,000 people die prematurely every year from nitrogen dioxide alone, mainly from polluting diesel cars. However, the technology is available to achieve the set standards today, even in real driving conditions and without a negative impact on CO2 emissions. It is incomprehensible, it is unacceptable that even now some Member States and the automotive sector are still on the brakes. Their deceleration maneuvers must stop. After all, the protection of public health and the environment is a shared social responsibility. Today we have the unique opportunity to show our citizens that we are not going to let them down and that we are getting rid of the structural failure that “dieselgate” has exposed. Strong market surveillance offers the best guarantees in this specific context to rule out political influence. I will soon vote in favor of the agency, both in the report by colleagues Gieseke and Gerbrandy and in the report on the type-approval. I hope that Parliament will not pass up this opportunity. Not drawing lessons from “dieselgate” would simply be unacceptable and would further undermine the credibility of the European Union.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President! It has been a very intensive work this year and I want to give recognition to both the chairman, rapporteurs and colleagues in the committee. I think it has been the most labor-intensive committee this year; a compliment for the time and commitment you have put into the issue. A lot has also emerged that has been important to us. It is clear that the European car industry has standards and opportunities to act in ways that are not possible for other industries. I know what it looks like every time a scandal is revealed in the production of clothes in a clothing company, what it looks like when food producers are exposed in cheating and scandals. It is being fought hard, there are new controls, there is new legislation and we are acting very clearly. There has been cheating going on here that we have been aware of directly and indirectly for a very, very long time. In addition, there has been a failure, both by Member States and by the Commission, to actually act. This makes this industry very, very unique, and here we will need to do even more in the future. I also think it is very good that we have received a clarification. It is also a matter of course that during the time the committee was working, new scandals were revealed in other brands than what perhaps primarily made us start this committee of inquiry. Brand after brand with different methods of cheating. So this is something that we have to say permeates the industry and where the Member States and the controls do not work. It also points out very clearly that the legislation that we often adopt at European level is too seldom properly implemented and controlled, and that it is too bad fines and penalties if they are broken. Here we have a core task for all the legislation that we adopt in this House: to ensure that it is actually complied with and that it has consequences. Another thing that is now being raised by European consumers is the big difference in why in the US you can get large compensation when you have bought a product that does not live up to the promised criteria, while this is not possible in Europe.It is based on the fact that our legal system does not allow it today, and there we have more to do.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the two co-rapporteurs on the good work they have done and on the excellent cooperation we have had. After a year of research and many hours of listening, it is now clear that there are serious political responsibilities. Both the Commission and the Member States have been well aware, since 2013, when the Joint Research Center's report was published, that it was possible to use emission distortion systems. But they did not take any action. The lack of action, however, is not due to a lack of information or insufficient resources, as the resolution of the recommendations wrongly argues. Unfortunately, it was confirmed that the excessive delays were due to the influence of the lobbies and the pressures exerted by the car industry. Despite calls for environmental protection, the Commission has shown that it did not have the political will to act on the seriousness of the issue of high emissions and to give priority to the protection of endangered public health. We therefore denounce the serious political responsibilities and omissions of both the Commission and the Member States in the application of EU law, but also in the imposition of sanctions. Their responsibilities constitute mismanagement to the detriment of the interests of the peoples. Those responsible for the loopholes in the legislation and the safety net they gave to the multinationals in order to be illegal, they will have to pay. Because the Volkswagen fraud is not an isolated case, but part of a wider political scandal.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would also like to thank the co—rapporteurs for having done a very good job on the report and recommendations. I think the conclusions of the committee of inquiry are very clear: the Dieselgate scandal could have been prevented if the national authorities and the Commission had done their work. It could have been prevented. It was not. For all those people who thought we were helping the car industry with that: they are the ones being punished the most, because internationally there is a big lack of trust in European car manufacturers. There you see that politicians who were relaxed towards the car industry are worse for them than those who tried to be tough and fair from the start. Let that be a lesson for all our legislators. If you look at the conclusions, there are six counts of maladministration on Member States. There are five contraventions of European law identified in this report, but there are also seven counts of maladministration done by the Commission cited in our conclusions. So those who say we have full trust in the Commission should maybe read their own reports. Seven counts of maladministration show that something needs to happen and needs to change within the Commission as well. I think that is important too. But my most important point is that the upshot is that a lot of polluting cars remain on the streets. We know that a lot of these car manufacturers produced defeat devices and are using defeat devices. I say to the Commission: if you apply your own guidelines, you will identify that a lot of car manufacturers are applying defeat devices. That is forbidden by law. Until now, no European car manufacturer has been forced to recall cars from the European streets. It is really time for action and, if the Member States do not do this, the Commission has all the powers to address those national authorities. The time for you to do that is now.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 'Dieselgate' scandal is yet another example of a Europe in pieces, fragmented, permeated and guided by industrial interests, devoured by national selfishness, by conflicts of interest and by a conspiratorial silence. The final report of the committee of inquiry, which I believe to be a good document, clearly denounces Europe's complete failure to guarantee truly clean cars on the road in our cities, as they are presented to us in the pounding commercials on television. But the news is only half as good. The final report lacks a clear reference to European consumer compensation treated in a discriminatory way compared to US consumers. As a 5 Star Movement, we ask that adequate compensation be introduced also by means of class action, a tool that unfortunately has not yet been introduced at European level in a uniform and harmonized way. We also believe that to prevent these scandals from happening again in the future, it is necessary to set up an independent European agency, which is the only way to avoid conflicts of interest, in which the controller is the controlled and where each Member State serves the interests of the flag car industry. Yet the 2007 regulation was precisely meant to improve air quality, and instead the European Commission and Member States have guaranteed decades of impunity and a profusion of funds to an auto industry that has been selling lies and disease to European consumers. The final report recognizes many of the mistakes made and identifies clear responsibilities. First, the timing: ten years since the NEDC test was known to be dated and unrepresentative, more than ten years since the environmental agency reports warning of discrepancies between laboratory and real emissions, four years from the report of the Joint Center of research in which the possible use of illegal software was mentioned, and seven years to design the PEMS, which among other things give a further gift to the auto industry thanks to very generous compliance factors, or the famous multipliers for limitsNOx - again a number that has all the flavor of a political choice, without any technical-scientific basis.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the Commission of Inquiry assumed that the standards set by the Commission for diesel vehicles were correctly calibrated. This approach is contested because it is questionable. Without condoning, of course, fraudulent practices, it is a little too easy to simply shame European industry and blame national authorities. This is to forget that they have already made significant technical efforts to reduce polluting emissions over the past fifteen years, which should be emphasized. In an exacerbated competitive environment and in the midst of an economic recession from 2008, the European Union has undoubtedly erred by excess of optimism by overestimating the technological developments that can be made by manufacturers. So how can we be surprised that car manufacturers are using illegal software, with the consent of the Commission itself? Another aspect would also have deserved to be addressed by the Commission of Inquiry, an aspect that can be summed up by the formula: "Who benefits from the crime?" Last week, the Volkswagen group agreed to compensate ten US states to the tune of $ 157.45 million, an amount in addition to the $ 23 billion already disbursed by the German manufacturer to settle the various complaints across the Atlantic . Let’s not be naive, the Volkswagen affair is also and above all an episode in the economic war that the Americans are waging against European companies. American standards and European standards do not follow the same environmental and strategic logic. To favor its auto groups, the United States has logically used the existing differences, it is their right. Rather than weakening our industrialists, let us try to respond intelligently. Like the United States, we should protect our industries. The area automobile accounts for nearly 12 million jobs in Europe which must be preserved, in particular by taking effective measures to prevent massive relocations to third countries.It seems to me that this is a priority issue today.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the policy of improving emissions measurements of major car air pollutants is of double importance. On the one hand, it concerns the protection of the environment. The environment has no present rate, it is a public good and it is a requirement and obligation to ensure it for future generations. On the other hand, in the light of the Volkswagen scandal, a central, autonomous and independent testing system, strict emission limits, a legal accountability framework and realistic measurements under real conditions must be established. A report by the European Parliament cannot fill the gaps in European and national legislation. The synergy of all the actors involved, the institutions of the Member States, experts, technology innovation companies and the car industry is needed. Unfortunately, the tendencies of illegal speculation and unfair competition always play a leading role in an informal corruption contest. History has shown that political leaders other than nationalists converse, nurture, cover up this entanglement and are prone to bribery, protected by parliamentary immunity. Micropolitics and expediencies do not fit into the environment and fair competition, only pure intentions and honest acts.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this committee of inquiry confirms the directions to be followed in order to improve air quality in Europe. Some would have liked to make this commission a political tribunal or a diesel tribunal, but that is not the point. Indeed, everyone has their share of responsibility in this matter. The slow pace of decisions at all levels as well as the complex development of a new test procedure have weighed on the rapid improvement in the quality of vehicle emissions. On the other hand, automakers have been, for some, too reluctant to comply with new and sometimes very strict standards. The tests carried out so far in the laboratory also lacked transparency, which will finally be corrected. We now have a duty to look to the future. The new rules must be acted upon. While major shortcomings have been detected in the approval procedures put in place by national authorities, the European Commission must be able to exercise better oversight by checking the Member States, and it is of course important to ensure the application of sanctions. As for diesel, long favored for its CO2 emissions, it is undergoing major changes to reduce its NOx emissions which are very harmful to health. A better balance between petrol and diesel is inevitable in Europe, but new diesel technologies will only have a future if they comply with environmental standards. The credibility of the auto industry is at stake. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Mr President, Madam President.In line with the things you have mentioned, I would like to ask you whether you now feel that our current will, the will that emerges here in Parliament, embodies rules that make it clear what methodology manufacturers should use to look at realtime tests?

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: "blue card" response.- Thank you very much for your question, I will gladly answer it.I am convinced that this affair, which is a real scandal, forces the car manufacturers to make the right decisions anyway.If there is a real will on our part and on the part of the European Commission as well as the Member States - and this is where we need to push for strict control of vehicle emissions measurements - I amconvinced that we will move forward.On the other hand, we know that car manufacturers are working on new technologies, because today the trend is towards clean vehicles.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank all of those have been involved in this committee of inquiry, including all of my colleagues from across the Chamber. I have to give special mention to my office who have been fantastic, and Mr Alex Keynes, in particular, whose work on this has been brilliant.  The verdict of our report is very clear. There have been clear instances of maladministration not just in the Commission, but crucially in Member States, where the oversight and surveillance were not taking place as they should have been. There have been aspects of widespread fraud throughout the industry that we have uncovered. I am very grateful to the Commissioner for her words today because I think that, although we have to see what actions will follow, the commitment that she has shown here today is very welcome indeed, particularly when you consider the starting point that we had in this committee of inquiry, not just the challenges we had to set it up, but also the insistence at many levels that nothing had gone wrong.  But we cannot waste this unique opportunity now to ensure that we never have another repeat of a scandal like Dieselgate. We have to remember that this Parliament is voting not just on a piece of dry legislation, not just on another report that goes through the normal machinations. This is our response to that crisis, that crisis of confidence in our vehicle industry, yes, but a crisis in public health. That is why it is not enough to say that we cannot have the tools at our disposal to sort this out. We need that agency. We need that independent level of operation to have vehicle surveillance across the European Union. And please, when it comes to compensation, let us not talk immediately about companies going out of business, as if we could put those roadblocks up at the very start. This is a basic principle at play here. Consumers in the US have been compensated; consumers in the European Union have not. That is an issue of basic justice, and what are we for in this place, if not to stand up for consumers? Please support the amendments on consumer rights.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, Dieselgate has given a real public platform to an issue that so many others have been following now for years. Whilst not a supporter of the setting-up of this committee at the outset, I do acknowledge the benefit of increasing awareness that has arrived, so thank you to all of my colleagues for their work. It is the details of the complex legislation and its proper implementation at Member State level that will be telling in the future. In the aftermath of the diesel emissions scandal the European Commission made new legislative proposals to ensure that car manufacturers comply with EU safety, environmental and production requirements. Maybe they do not go far enough – I am thinking, for example, of conformity factors here – but they are a good start. It is clear that we need to have better and more independent oversight of cars that are in circulation. Those of us working on air quality have known for some time about the problems with real driving emissions. That is a separate issue from fraud but, by its very nature, is purposefully perpetrated. Today I am supporting the call for a new European Vehicle Surveillance Agency in this report and, more importantly, in the legislative type-approval vote that will come later. Manufacturers and regulators knew for some time before the VW story broke about some of the discrepancies between the approval stage and on-road testing. I believe that a new agency is the only way to ensure compliance verification and enforce proper oversight of testing at EU level.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it is indeed the American agency which raised the alert and it is American citizens who are currently being compensated by European manufacturers. This is not likely to strengthen the confidence of European citizens in their institutions and in their industrial fabric. The Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) highlighted the weaknesses of the control system in the Union and tried to shed light on the culprits as well as on the means to remedy these shortcomings. One obstacle still stands: will the tests be carried out correctly and by a trustworthy authority? The EMIS committee, unlike the thematic committee, voted for the creation of a European agency responsible for verifying the effectiveness of these tests. This agency, properly endowed with appropriate legal, technical and financial resources, will be better able to ensure the efficiency of the procedures that we want to put in place and to restore consumer confidence where the Commission and the Member States have failed.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr. president. I feel a bittersweet taste at the end of this commission of inquiry. There is no doubt that the new Regulation introduced will allow the development of more effective tests and greater monitoring of emissions, but we must admit a certain failure when it comes to demanding responsibilities and compensation. Proof of this is that Mr Tajani is today President of this Parliament; or that the open infringement processes have not yet led to sanctions against the States; or that consumers continue to have to go to court to obtain redress; and that our cities continue with polluted air; and that the car companies, which got rich off the health of Europeans, now seek to burden workers with the transition from diesel to electric vehicles. The dieselgate has demonstrated the corruption of a regulatory system in the hands of large producers. Although we may breathe somewhat cleaner air in the future, I have the feeling that, in the relationship between the European Union and big capital, little or nothing has changed.

name: Karima DELLI
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, what pride in having worked within this committee of inquiry to draw together, across the lines, the lessons of the Dieselgate scandal! The recommendations of this commission of inquiry concern all car manufacturers that have exceeded the pollution standards voted here ten years ago. These recommendations must be set in stone if the rights of Europe's 500 million consumers and their health are to be protected from air pollution. The citizens are waiting for us at the turn. So let's make sure there is a before and an after Dieselgate! This is why we need to create an independent European gendarme to do the job that no one has been able to do, neither the manufacturers, nor the Member States, nor the Commission. Mrs Bieńkowska, I agree - and this was underlined by Mr Juncker, even by Mr Tajani - we need an automotive market surveillance agency. This is the only way to restore efficiency to Europe so that it is fully at the service of citizens.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, over the last year, the inquiry committee has received technicians and experts from across the European Union to find out what happened to polluting emissions from vehicles. At this point, we all have a fairly approximate idea of ​​what happened: the text provides an adequate answer to our questions. The priority must be to preserve the environment and the health of citizens, of course! The legislation of the European Union must evolve to promote cleaner fuels. It is also desirable to avoid the installation of deactivation devices similar to those detected in the case of the fraud at hand and to include polluting emissions within the scope of the Environmental Liability Directive. Our legislation must offer greater protection and reparation to the consumer in cases such as the one that occurred, because consumer protection is essential in this unique market that we have given ourselves. Finally, I am not in favor of creating a new ad hoc agency. We have many agencies in the European Union, and I do not think it is the solution to avoid cases like this. We just have to lay solid foundations for it and comply with them. The text that we will vote on today clearly indicates the direction in which we have to work, and we must also reflect on whether we are not being too demanding with some industrial sectors that have to compete with the rest of the world.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Mr President, more than a year of investigation, hearings, careful consultation of documents were necessary to clarify this grim Dieselgate affair. The findings of our investigation were widely adopted on February 28, and I welcome that. It shows that with perseverance and goodwill, in a collective spirit, we always manage to restore the truth beyond appearances, and I thank all who have contributed to it. Our conclusions are clear and precise. We must now draw the practical consequences. This is the purpose of the resolution voted on today. The European and national institutions have failed, but the opportunity is now given to them to restore the situation in the interest of all, for less polluted air and cities where people breathe better thanks to cleaner cars and more controlled. The legislation has been poorly applied. We must therefore find the means to apply it correctly throughout Europe and strengthen a posteriori controls, which remain the best way to fight against fraud. What better tool than a specialized European agency to apply the law uniformly, in a manner impervious to national interests, with the help of technically qualified experts? The other modes of transport in Europe, such as air, sea and rail transport are regulated by agencies. Why not road transport? This would be the logical conclusion of our work. Moreover, the committee of inquiry voted in this direction last February and Jean-Claude Juncker declared himself in favor. I hear the sadly budgetary arguments that a new agency is too expensive. I will respond by saying that public health should not be seen as a cost but as an investment, especially when we see the exorbitant price that Europeans pay each year because of air pollution, the thousands of deaths. but also diseases chronic, sometimes long-lasting, and the consequences for our health systems.Also, an agency does not cost that much when it is smartly set up.For example, it is possible to broaden the skills of an existing agency for economies of scale.By relying on the work of national authorities but supervising them, such an agency would also save lengthy and costly litigation between two Member States.Our goal with the creation of this agency is more of Europe and, above all, a Europe that protects.What we need today is a robust system that ensures that the rules are followed.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Dear Commissioner, The scandal with the falsification of exhaust gas test results is an example of a fraud caused by evident loopholes in the European passenger car approval system. Clear gaps no one will be held responsible for. Nobody in Europe, because the US authorities made sure that the customers who were primarily affected by this scandal would receive compensation. I do not think that the proposal to create another agency that will solve another problem is good. First of all, we need precise regulations and a uniform interpretation of these provisions in order to avoid a huge number of exceptions, special conditions under which exhaust emission standards are complied with. The Commissioner expressed her enthusiasm for our motion for a resolution, but I would like the Commissioner to be enthusiastic above all about the steps that the Commission and the Commissioner must take in the future to prevent such frauds from taking place in Europe. Because if there is fraud in Europe and there is no accountability, then there is no Europe.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it has been more than a year and a half since we learned that Volkswagen was using devices to circumvent emissions testing. The result was justifiably outraged consumer reaction. Europe cannot afford another diesel gate. This continent is one of the global leaders in the automotive industry. However, if we are not able to guarantee that European cars are reliable, safe, environmentally friendly and technologically advanced, then it can easily happen that we will lose our position on a global scale. To this day, however, we owe the answer to our consumers. How could something like this happen? And what can we do to help them trust their cars again? I believe that the report adopted by the Commission provides these answers. He also clearly says that the blame lies on several sides. Not only did the public consciously confuse the carmaker, but also the control mechanisms that were supposed to prevent similar steps failed completely. So I believe that with today's vote, we will close one chapter of the story here, which should remain a memento and a great lesson for us in the future.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: - Mister President! I have seldom seen events where so much, so unrestrained and so brazen lies were lied as in some of the hearings of this committee. Above all car manufacturers, but also ministers have really shirked responsibility. Organizations like Deutsche Umwelthilfe, on the other hand, were callers in the desert, and my thanks go to them. Consumers have been cheated for years and now they are not even being compensated in Europe, nor is that reflected in the report. I think that's bad. So no compensation for cars that pollute the air and manufacturers who don't care about the environment and the health of their citizens. What we really need are tough rules, controls and sanctions, as well as strong European supervision that stands for them. The diesel, ladies and gentlemen, at least the diesel is a dinosaur, and anyone who still counts on it - and let me tell the unions as well - will miss the train and there are thousands of employees at the station who are being abandoned. We need a fundamental shift in the auto and vehicle industries before it's too late.

name: Julia REDA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, today we are closing one chapter in the saga that we call Dieselgate. Unfortunately, it is not going to be the last scandal of its kind. We can prevent this particular scandal from being repeated by creating an independent EU oversight agency, but the next fraud and the next violation of the rules will be just as difficult to uncover as this one if we do not improve the accountability of our institutions. Today we are sending a clear signal to the Commission that its practices on access to documents are unacceptable. Let us be crystal clear about this. A Commission that discards all information, all emails and all minutes after six months, unless an official has explicitly marked them as important, will never be a champion of transparency and it will remain part of the problem. Let us end this institutional amnesia policy.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - In the first place, I have to express my disappointment about the car industry again. I myself am a fan of the industry, because it provides employment, prosperity, income. And everyone talks about corporate social responsibility and the Rhineland model, but this way you can see that we have been deceived in a terrible way. These are also thousands of employees who do their work in all honesty and who are nevertheless disappointed by certain forces. That hurt me a lot, all that ethical talk that is wrong. The second point is that agency. That is now becoming a bit of the totem pole of this debate and if there is no agency, the committee of inquiry will not have done its job properly. At least that impression is created. I think that is completely unjustified. I think that we must first adopt the Commissioner's proposal to start with that platform of enforcement. That can be done very quickly. That is already possible at the end of this year. Moreover, it includes the member states. And if anyone has to be bound in this file, it is the member states. Let's try that and possibly need an agency later.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! In the work of the Committee of Inquiry, we have identified serious failures both on the part of the European Commission and on the part of the Member States, which contributed to the emissions scandal. For example, European regulations were sloppily implemented by the member states, sometimes not implemented at all, and the Commission did not follow up on information. In addition, the system of type approval has proven to be extremely flawed. That is why I have three recommendations in the foreground: First, a European agency must be created that controls the activities of the national type approval authorities and at least clearly interprets the confusion of 28 different national authorities. Second, consumer rights need to be strengthened. It cannot be that we in Europe do not have a legal framework for class actions. I believe that must be changed. And thirdly, real and real sanctions must be introduced and dissuasive fines introduced or enforced against those automobile manufacturers who have not yet obeyed the rules. That is why I ask and I ask all colleagues, especially the EPP, to go back to these proposals and to support them. Many Thanks.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mister President!I should like to start with a point of order, if you allow me, and before you let my limited speaking time run out.I would like to put on record that the German translation of the report and in particular paragraph one, the last sentence of the conclusions, has been translated in a misleading manner.I would ask you to take this on record and to check it, and I would also ask the Bureau to consider how we can ensure that the translations into the languages of the individual Member States are such that the reports can also be properly received.So I would like to ask what kind of quality control actually exists there when documents in - let's say - the working language English are then translated into other languages by Member States?

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: We take note of this as a contribution to the rules of procedure.I can't answer that right now, but we'll take a look and you will get an answer.Then let's start with the normal contribution.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! There is no doubt that there is a major scandal here, and it is also unquestionable that car manufacturers have cheated and deceived on a large scale here. The real scandal, however, is that the European Commission has failed, the Member States have failed and the European Parliament has also failed. If we start with the European Commission, we have to state that the deviations between emissions in test operation and emissions in normal road traffic operation have been known for more than ten years. It has been known for more than 20 years that there are defeat devices that can be responsible for such deviations, and yet the Commission has turned a blind eye to it and has not adequately checked whether the manufacturers are possibly being cheated. This is a clear case of policy failure. There is also a second case of policy failure with regard to the European Parliament. Because the European Parliament passed legislation that was so soft and so imprecise that it was an invitation to deceive. It has allowed defeat devices or emission reduction strategies - whatever you like to call them - to be used when damage to the engine can be averted. That is a completely soft and inadequate formulation, and here the European Parliament has to take a hard look at what mistakes it actually made. Unfortunately, there is no adequate reference to this in the investigation report. Thirdly, however, we also have to say - I think I still have half a minute, Mr President, because, as I said, my speaking time only began after the point of order ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr Lucke, your group has given you a minute and a half.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Correct, but you had already run the clock when I was still on the point of order.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: No, no, definitely not.We are very correct there.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Let me just have a moment ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Then finish the sentence now and continue.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - That the agency is justified by the fact that the European Commission may be politicized is a totally inadequate argument.What Parliament must ensure is that the Commission no longer acts politicized in future.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr. Lucke!Would you be so kind as to say again which sentence does not seem meaningfully translated to you?Number 1, last sentence - did I understand that correctly?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Conclusions, number 1 - the connection between the penultimate and the last sentence is completely meaningless.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: We'll check that. Well, I don't think it's pointless, but we'll let the lawyers-linguists check it out.Well, then we come to the next speaker.That’s up to you, Mr Lucke, colleague Gesine Meissner for a minute, please!

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The aim of the investigation committee was to determine who knew what and when and did nothing. It wasn't about whether diesel is good or not good now. Diesel was also used to reduce CO2 emissions, so little attention was paid to NOx. As a matter of fact, we set NOX limits in 2007 and the problem is that no one bothered to comply. On the one hand, it is correct that gray areas were created in the law back then, in which there was no conformity factor. On the other hand, it is above all the case that the Commission, the Member States and the industry clearly did not care whether there were limit values ​​or not. They were exceeded up to three times. Incidentally, in the last period, Mr Lucke, Parliament has already paid attention and called for real driving emission tests because we knew that the tests were not truthful. That was pretty much ignored back then, and unfortunately it is only now being introduced. As a final point: I do not believe that a European agency will add much value because all levels have failed. All levels not only have to make laws, but also obey them. If we can do that, we'll have clean air.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, we have been working on the dieselgate scandal for over a year. During that time, we already know that the Commission and the Member States have failed not only to implement the individual European directives, but also to monitor them. But also the fact that the carmakers used vaguely written European legislation and thus deceived European customers. Unfortunately, we also know that while American customers are receiving financial compensation, Europeans must be content with an apology. I understand that it is easier for Volkswagen to reconfigure cars in Europe, but does that change the fact that consumers who have bought a car of certain parameters in good faith have been deceived? Isn't this act worthy of punishment or compensation? However, European carmakers refuse to pay European consumers what they are morally entitled to. I find it absurd to consider that Europeans are treated in this way. They are not secondary customers and deserve the same treatment. It is too much to blame everything on insufficient legislation in one affair, although I personally understand the outrage of European consumers, as they feel that the law has left them in the lurch again.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! One year emissions test committee - what are the most important points and recommendations for me? On the one hand, one thing is clear: Diesel is not doomed to die; it will remain one of several drive technologies in the automotive industry for the next few years, perhaps decades. The second thing for me is: we need clear and unambiguous legislation, otherwise we would not have had a debate as to whether switching off the engine control is legal component protection or illegal fraud. Third: exhaust gas measurements must be more precisely traceable, because results from the laboratory that cannot be reproduced on the road and cannot be achieved neither help the consumer, nor do they help the environment, nor do they help the manufacturer. That is why we will have real driving emissions in the future and have also created a solution at European level. Regarding the type approval agency: I also take a really critical view of this, because we are building double structures here. We already have corresponding type approval offices in Europe, we don't need anything new. If we do that, we will have a new authority. We need three to five years to build it up. Not much would change in the meantime and we should rather strengthen existing structures. Finally, I would like to thank everyone who has come to this committee: NGOs, car manufacturers, research centers. Because we actually have no authority in our committee to summon anyone. Perhaps we should change that in the European Parliament so that we have better powers there.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the Volkswagen scandal clearly demonstrates that the market without clear rules and adequate controls generates imbalances, unfair competition and serious damage to the environment. The homologation tests done in the laboratory were a farce, a scam. So let's say it clearly: it is not by lowering environmental standards that international competition is won. Together, in committee, we did a good job: now we need to move on from words to deeds. We need an independent European approval agency. It serves a very simple reason: you cannot have a common market with approval rules that are verified with different procedures and costs. And then we need a clear measure to protect scammed consumers. It is indispensable, because consumers have suffered serious harm. And that is why I make a heartfelt appeal to colleagues, to all colleagues. We did a good job together. We are now on the last mile. Let's not waste the opportunity to demonstrate that we are autonomous, independent and have the strength to choose.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: - Mr President!The Commission certainly thought it was doing the European car industry a great service when it went in to not monitor that this part of the industry was properly controlled.In fact, the Commission did both Europe and the European car industry a great disservice.By not pushing for technology, by not pushing for legal oversight, the Commission actually created a situation where Europe's car industry has been technologically lagging behind.It will be of great importance in the future because all our economic development, in Europe in general, is about how well we meet the technological challenge.In that sense, the Commission was counterproductive and we hope that it has actually learned something from this, but we are not convinced.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the first observation I make is addressed to the rapporteurs, to the two co-rapporteurs who have done, as has been repeated several times, an enormous job, as I have rarely seen in these three years of parliamentary activity, and to all the Secretariat, to all collaborating officials. From the point of view of the specific content of this one-year work, the first observation I make - I do it for the presence of the Commissioner - is that we cannot, despite having identified a series of non-compliances, deficiencies, corrections to be made, not we can make the mistake of transferring to the Directorate General for the Environment competences that are specifically to be assigned to the Directorate General for Industry. The fact of having detected some critical issues related to the environmental repercussions of some industrial practices does not mean that in that case the industry must take a step back, from an institutional point of view. What is the competence of the industry must remain. Because here we can afford, as has always happened in Europe, to preside over that level of sustainable development of which Europe is champion in the world. Today we often hear strong criticism of industry in this House, but those who criticize it, industry, often forget that the standard of living we afford here is paid for by the capacity of industry. A child to be corrected should not be thrown out of the house, it must be corrected. And so we have to deal with our entrepreneurs.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - How was it possible that a North American agency was the first to discover the manipulations of a European brand without any of the national agencies having noticed this first? Was there a cover-up of these manipulative practices by the national authorities or even the European Commission? What lessons to learn to avoid repeating the same mistakes in the future? These are the questions that justified this Committee of Inquiry. Their work made evident the European Commission's lack of political will to investigate the facts after the evidence of the first evidence. It also highlighted Member States' lethargy in assessing an inadequate emissions verification system. The work done, however, was worth it for what it revealed and for the changes it will induce in the future. A new type-approval system and new limits for vehicle emissions are an absolute priority now assumed by the European Commission and the Member States. The bet on electric mobility is essential. The creation of a supervisory agency as well. With this we will have a more competitive, reliable and environmentally friendly European automotive sector. EMIS contributed to this.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: - The automotive industry is an important part of our economy, and we are not supposed to create redundant red tape today.But we cannot and will not deny that European consumers have been deceived.That is what I conclude from the report.I am convinced that if the Commission and the Member States take into account our recommendations that are before and will be voted on today, this malicious situation will come to an end.In the future, consumers will be able to buy a new car that meets European standards, both literally and figuratively, with confidence.The same consumer will also be able to breathe cleaner air in the future as a result of these regulations.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, we have put together a very good  report, which is probably the most complex description of the so—called Dieselgate, and will allow the citizens of Europe and others to learn about this unfortunate story. What can they learn from the report? First of all, it is clear that we have made no mistakes in setting limits for cars. We have collected enough clear evidence that there is – and was – technology available that could make car engines compliant with the regulation, regardless of the petrol or diesel technology used. That technology is – and was – available at reasonable cost. Secondly, we learned that some manufacturers decided to save money and produce cars that could seriously harm the health of our citizens. That is what we know for certain. But there was also some reaction, which was late but quite clear. We have put together a new laboratory test. More importantly, we have introduced the real driving testing that is a key fundamental of a new and better system, and we will also be discussing and voting on the type-approval system. I therefore believe that we will end up with a much better system which will make it more difficult and more costly for people to cheat. But, at the same time, there is still some disappointing information. First of all, the reaction of both national governments and the Commission on Dieselgate is not sufficient and not clear enough. Here I do not mean compensation for car owners. It is not mainly car owners who are affected by the scandal, but the people living in cities, walking on the pavements and waiting at crossroads who have to breathe the air that has been polluted by non-compliant cars. This is quite disappointing and, as a consequence, I would propose to put together a fund that will ensure that we will fight for programmes in air quality and achieve an improvement. Secondly it is quite important that cars that still emitting more than ten times the limits in real driving are still on sale and causing air quality to be worse. It will take time before we improve the air quality that that was devastated by non—compliant cars, but I call on the Commission and Governments to act much more quickly to improve the confidence of our citizens in their actions.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir. Chairman! Why is it at all necessary to investigate this whole diesel scandal? Yes, first and foremost because the manipulation and cheating of car manufacturers has had some very serious environmental and health consequences for the citizens. We know that thousands of citizens have died prematurely due to the illegal NOx emissions. When something goes so wrong without being stopped by the authorities, we have to find out why. The conclusion of the EMIS is quite clear: there are mistakes, failures and unwillingness to act at all levels. Member States have not carried out adequate checks, either in the context of type-approval or subsequently on the road. Nor has the European Commission acted on the knowledge it had. It has not examined it further and it has not pressured the Member States to do more. The result is a serious failure. But now we have a chance to repair and repair the damage in the system. We have that when we vote on the Dalton report today, and I hope we get an agency and consumer compensation on top of that.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to make three comments. My first comment goes to the rapporteurs and also to the chairmen of the committee: thank you very much for presenting the report. The committee has done a really good job. There have been 47 hearings. At the hearings I was able to attend - there weren't many - there was a very intense, detailed discussion with critical questions. It was really good. The second point I want to make is the question: what lesson are we drawing from the Dieselgate scandal? For me the most important thing is that we have testing on the road in the future, that we have testing under real driving conditions. For myself, I have to admit frankly, it is a bit inexplicable and really incomprehensible that we will only achieve this in 2017. It has been mentioned: The subject of “testing in the laboratory with incorrect values ​​compared to testing under real driving conditions” is an ancient topic. I can still remember: That was also an issue with the climate protection package that we discussed in Parliament in 2007/2008. So it's a failure on all channels. I do not know whether we in Parliament are primarily to blame. I don't think so, because we are legislators and we don't have to ensure that it is enforced. But that it takes so long is actually completely incomprehensible and incomprehensible. All those politically responsible should touch their own noses. My third comment is also very important to me: We have Euro 5 and Euro 6 standards, we have strict values, strict CO2 requirements and want our cars to be low-polluting and low-emission. If you look at today's diesels - technologically it is absolutely no problem to meet Euro 5, Euro 6 standards. The same applies to the strict upper limits. I say this because I think it would be completely wrong to take the diesel out of circulation now.No, we will need diesel technology for many, many years to come.And, as I said, the new cars can meet these strict limits.Therefore, please do not generally declare war on diesel.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, it has already become clear that the European Parliament has done its job. Those who had not done so were the European Commission and the Member States. By action or omission they have failed. By action, because the prevention and control mechanisms failed; and by omission, because when the first alarms were known, the European Commission and the Member States looked the other way. And of course yes, future decisions must be taken, which are those proposed by this European Parliament. Of course, an agency must be created, an agency that has the capacity to prevent, that has the capacity with broad powers to impose fines, that has the capacity to remove vehicles. There are not too many administrative burdens, as they say, what they are left over are bad practices and, for that, the agency is a very proper mechanism to deal with them. Of course, it is necessary to compensate the people who have been deceived: the users and the consumers. Of course, you have to be consistent and meet the objectives set. And, as the rapporteur for the future Renewable Energy Directive, I too will advocate for greater decarbonisation in the transport sector.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Mr President, recent developments show that it is important to improve the procedure for type approval of cars in the European Union. We need stronger rules that will effectively deal with the emission problems for diesel cars. In past years, all our attention was focused on the lowering of CO2 emissions and particulate matter, without devoting enough attention to NOx. Today we cannot punish customers for buying diesel cars. With the new proposal we are introducing new real-driving emissions tests that are closest to real-world use, and we will also introduce new type-approval legislation that will help diesel cars to become much cleaner, but we do not need new agencies for that. For the upcoming years the classic technologies based on fossil fuels and the alternative solutions will be present side by side. We should use this period to prepare new development plans focusing on new innovative technologies in order to safeguard Europe’s position as the number one car maker in the world.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, I too would like to congratulate the EMIS Commission of Inquiry on the results and proposals made. However, I am surprised by the EPP rapporteur, who does not agree with consumer compensation. I hope that this is not the position of the EPP group. Of course, we must not deindustrialise Europe. Of course we have to have industry, but it depends on the means by which we do this. We cannot follow the "purpose excuses the means" principle. We cannot accept to make fictitious, superficial approvals, just so as not to be accused of working against our own industry. I'm an industrialist and I know what I'm talking about. The Commission is tasked with finding appropriate trade defense measures in relation to third countries that introduce products that do not comply with European rules into the internal market. But we must demand proper approval and we must fight for consumer compensation. Commissioner, it is now your responsibility to capitalize on the two reports, the investigation report and the Dalton report. Until the establishment of an organism, you have to take over these things, control.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Mr President, it is now clear that this is a scandal, with the responsibility of the car industry, the Member States and the European Commission. That is why we need to have an independent European vehicle inspection body, which will be able to monitor the market at European level and, if necessary, request the recall of car types and impose fines. Also, another issue is compensation. In the United States, consumers have been compensated. In the European Union, why not? In a single market there needs to be a common protection framework. As the European Commission acknowledged in a recent question, unfortunately this is not possible today. This must change immediately. We cannot talk about a single market without strong and equal protection for all consumers, regardless of the Member State in which they live. Finally, it is unacceptable, after what we have learned, for the European Commission to continue to legitimize part of the illegality by keeping compliance rates so high, effectively doubling the permissible emissions.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, when I first heard of the emissions scandal I could not believe it. I could not believe that such reputable businesses would go to such lengths to treat both consumers and the system ... especially in relation to emissions reductions, which are so much part of the European profile at the minute, when we are leading the world in relation to COP21 and COP22.  So I think there is no need here for sympathy for those who were involved, and for that reason we need a few things to ensure it does not happen again. One: deterrents, and two: vigilance. If compensation is given to people in the United States then it is very difficult to say why it should not happen here in Europe. And vigilance means that we have to be sure that the supervisory agencies do their job.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the committee of inquiry set up by the European Parliament in the aftermath of the "Dieselgate" scandal has brought to light a picture that is anything but reassuring, highlighting responsibilities at every level. The Commission should have acted to mitigate the central role played by industry representatives, which are over-represented in the meetings of the Working Group on Real Emissions from Light Vehicles. And this the Commission has not done. The Member States themselves have circumvented their legal obligation to monitor and enforce the ban on defeat devices. They should have ensured that their approval authorities had adequate human and financial resources to carry out in-house tests, and not let them rely on tests carried out in certified car manufacturers' laboratories. The rigorous work carried out by the parliamentary commission of inquiry delivers an uncompromising final report, testifying to the value of democratic control in European institutions and the distance between reality and the law, which citizens are asking us to bridge.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, Member States failed to monitor cars for illegal emissions and turned a blind eye to cheating by Volkswagen and other manufacturers in tests. Meanwhile, the Commission did not enforce its own legislation, eroding consumer trust in the car industry and putting public health at risk. After Dieselgate, business as usual is simply not an option. We want to see a stronger oversight, in the form of an independent EU agency for vehicles surveillance, put in place to ensure that cars are not only clean in the lab, but also on the road. Those countries which continue to block an independent and transparent systems for type-approval of European vehicles and the strengthening of market surveillance at EU level must stop putting the interest of their own car industry above those of consumers and the citizens of Europe.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you, also for keeping the time extremely well.(End of the catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
