text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Members for their speeches and for the views expressed today. I want to express my feelings and make a few remarks. Firstly, it is very clear that the adoption of the report and the recommendation does not mark the end of our cooperation on this topic. I can comment on this, but I also seek your strong support, which I have had so far. We need to be engaged not only on the follow-up of the recommendation but, I think, most importantly on ensuring that the legislation changes. We need to see early and effective adoption of the new type-approval reform, because this will be a game-changer. We must continue to hold car manufacturers and Member State authorities accountable. It is increasingly important that our consumers have confidence in the industry and in the national authorities overseeing it. Many of you mentioned compensation, and some of you mentioned that we have to protect our car manufacturers. As you noticed, I have not yet succeeded in getting a response from the car manufacturers on compensation to Europeans, but this not a matter of my personal success or otherwise. It is just the failure of the European car manufacturers to find a proper and fair response to Europeans, comparable to the Americans’ response. We just need an initial public gesture and a change of attitude, which has not happened so far. This would be the best protection and the best shield for our car manufacturers and for our automotive industry in the future. They have not done it so far. We must ensure that the law is monitored and enforced on the ground, and we have to work together on the future of the automotive sector. We know that diesel will not disappear overnight, but after this year of work and exchange of views with you, I am quite sure that they will disappear much faster than we think and we can imagine. We have to be prepared for this. We will come forward with a mobility package in May to address these issues. We will be prepared for the future with zero-emission cars, with the focus on batteries, on battery-charging infrastructure and regulatory incentives. We will prepare the future to ensure similar cross-border mobility and, finally, together with my colleagues the other Commissioners, we will prepare for the future of new demand models where public and private transport models are integrated. I urge you to work with me in the future and the longer term, because we need both the Member States and industry on board to get these changes right. I am sure that 2017 will be a decisive year for this. Thank you very much for everything achieved so far, especially by the committee. I am looking to working with you because I will need your strong support, as before. Lastly, I want to thank you for your high flexibility on arranging our work. Unfortunately – and I would like to apologise for this – I will not be able to stay with you throughout the debate on Mr Dalton’s report. The Commission will be represented on this by Commissioner Vella, who is also partly responsible for the file. However I will remain at your disposal for further discussion and, of course, at any moment you need me.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner.That was an important debate.The debate is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written. - The dieselgate affair leaves us all with a wry feeling. Who was responsible? Why could things have gone so wrong despite legislation we thought was conclusive? The responsibility was collective, that much is now clear after a year of research. What counts now is that we take measures to prevent such a fraud from ever repeating itself. Because the fraud happened at the expense of public health and the consumers, who were outright deceived. The good news is that a number of structural, fundamental interventions are already in the pipeline or have already been completed. Nitrogen oxide emissions will soon be measured in real driving conditions and no longer in the laboratory. In addition, European control on emissions will be drastically tightened. Today's citizens expect us to close all loopholes. We must now prove that effective European supervision is the most effective solution in this case and we must not lose any more time in this regard.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I support measures to reduce emissions of pollutants from motor vehicles. The scandal with the adjusted results of laboratory tests showed that there is an urgent need for changes in the rules for measuring emissions to bring the tests closer to the real road conditions. The introduction of stricter conditions for the type-approval of motor vehicles in the European Union and stronger European supervision are measures that will lead to improved air quality and public health. Air pollution every year leads to the premature death of more than 400,000 Europeans. One of the main sources of harmful gases is cars. That is why I support the introduction of sanctions for car manufacturers who falsify test results. Revenue from administrative fines should be used to support market surveillance, consumer redress and environmental protection. Emissions problems do not only affect car owners, but the health of all European citizens.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Emission scandals were the result of insufficient control.Both the Commission and the Member States must realize that the free market does not mean relinquishing responsibility for exercising control.If the Union wants to protect consumers' rights, ensure a high level of protection of health and the environment, control mechanisms must be a mandatory part of every policy, every piece of legislation, every act.The control must be preventive in nature and cannot be the result of negative consequences.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I strongly support the need to achieve the EU's air quality goals. That is why it is necessary to constantly strive to reduce emissions from vehicles, establish certain standards and better control this area, and above all to prevent manipulation within the automotive industry, as happened in the case of the Volkswagen affair. Fraud needs to be condemned. Of course, the final price for this manipulation, in the case of the VW affair, is paid by consumers. We all pay, too, because we all breathe the same air, which affects our health. Part of the internal market is also the protection of consumer rights, not just industry. However, I do not agree with the proposal to set up a new EU agency. I believe that in this case, there would only be additional administrative and financial burdens, while control would be questionable and the added value would be minimal. I believe that it is the EC and the Member States that must ensure that the car industry implements the legislation in practice. However, it should also be borne in mind that fraud in measurements does not bring anything good in the long run - certain companies cast a bad light on the entire automotive industry, have a negative impact on public health, and consumer confidence is lost. The rules of the game must be followed. Today's vote is an additional step towards achieving that.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Before we get to the next item on the agenda, I have to make an announcement. As you will recall, on March 14, 2017, the President decided to sanction Mr Korwin-Mikke for making unacceptable remarks about women at the March 1 session. This sanction consists of three measures: 1) the loss of the right to daily allowance for a period of 30 days, 2) without prejudice to the exercise of voting rights in plenary, the suspension from participating in all activities of Parliament for a period of ten days Parliament or one of its organs, one of its committees or one of its delegations holds meetings, and 3) the ban on representing Parliament in an inter-parliamentary delegation or in an inter-institutional forum for a period of one year. Mr. Korwin-Mikke filed a complaint against this decision on March 27th. The Bureau examined this complaint yesterday and confirmed the President's decision. The sanction then comes into force.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Daniel Dalton, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the authorization and market surveillance of motor vehicles and their trailers, and of systems, components and devicesseparate technical units for these vehicles (COM (2016) 0031 - C8-0015 / 2016 - 2016/0014 (COD)) (A8-0048 / 2017).

name: Daniel DALTON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the shadow rapporteurs, as is customary. We got to know each other very well during the many hours of discussions we had on this report. We had some disagreements, as is expected on a file of this importance, but I believe that we have come to a very good compromise in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection in the end. Let us be clear: the Volkswagen scandal – and it was not just Volkswagen, but we have called it the Volkswagen scandal – was the tip of the iceberg. Consumers have been treated with contempt for a long, long time. They long ago gave up any trust in the fuel consumption claims that are made by manufacturers, and now they know that the emissions claims are wrong as well. This was a scandal that was waiting to happen. But what we have here in front of us now is a fundamental change from the current system and a very good compromise. It is far from the status quo. Firstly, we have new tests. The RDE testing means cars that will be tested on the roads, not just in the labs. That is a fundamental change from the system that existed before. Secondly, we have a new market-surveillance system. Member States have an obligation under this proposal to test 20% of types every year. They have to have their plans approved by the Commission, and the Commission is also empowered to do whatever tests it wants to do in addition. Thirdly, we have a new forum, which the Commission will direct and with independent peer review. So the Commission will get all the information it needs from Member States, stakeholders, NGOs and civil society in order to know the problems much, much earlier and have the tools to deal with them. Every Member State has to apply the same rules. There are fewer opportunities now for forum shopping and independent auditors will check on a periodic basis that rules are applied fairly and clearly. Fees cannot be paid directly by manufacturers to testing centres, which deals with the concerns that many had about manufacturers’ influence. And we have a proposal on consumer redress. The fines will go into a fund that will help consumers and the environment. This is a big, broad and ambitious package which got huge support in the Internal Market Committee. No one change in the system will prevent fraud, but together all these changes will guard against, firstly, cars incorrectly being put on the market, and, secondly, cars being on the market for a long time before a fault is found. We cannot stop all non-compliant products getting on the market. If someone wants to cheat the system, they are going to try and cheat the system, but we need to make sure that we have a system that is as strong as possible to catch them when they do it. I would also remind everyone that type-approval is not just about emissions. It is primarily about safety standards for cars on our roads. I also want to touch on the agency because we have had a big debate about the agency, which is still raging today. I am not against an agency if it can be proven that there is a benefit from the agency, but so far I have not seen a benefit. I have yet to see a consumer who wants an agency that is remote from the market and hidden from the consumer. The justification also seems to be weak. Agencies are just as susceptible to political pressure as the Commission or Member States, and this gives an excuse for national Member States not to act when they should be acting. It has not been costed, there is no detailed impact assessment and there is no idea how it is going to manage the market surveillance system. Let us be clear: this will cost a lot of money and we need to be right, sure and confident that it is going to do the job before we propose it. I also have a bit of concern with one of the amendments from the Greens: Amendment 343, on what I would call a ‘victim’s levy’. This will effectively be a fine on people who want to buy new cars. This is a little bit like you getting mugged, the police coming to you and saying ‘we’re terribly sorry we didn’t stop you getting mugged, but we’ll take a bit more money out your pocket to try and stop it happening again’. This is not the right way to deal with the issue. It is not the right way to fund an agency or any of these measures. So I do not think we should be going down that line. As I said before, we have got a good agreement in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection that was supported by most Members. It is robust, good for consumers, good for the environment and fair for industry. I do not think we should confuse that issue with an agency. But now I am looking forward to hearing all your remarks. I know that there are going to be plenty of remarks, and I am looking forward to a very good debate.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, on behalf of the Commission and on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Bieńkowska, who, as she said, had to leave us, I welcome today’s debate on the type approval proposal. I thank Mr Dalton, as the rapporteur on this file, and also his shadow rapporteurs. We welcome the opportunity it gives us to reiterate the importance that we attach to this proposal. It is the most important measure to restore confidence in our system and the credibility of the industry.  It is very timely to hold this debate just after the debate on the report and recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector (EMIS). If there is a clear lesson to learn from the car industry’s emission manipulations it is that our system was not fit for purpose. Yes, we knew that emissions were higher on the road than in the laboratories, so already way back in 2012 we started a review of the EU type approval framework for motor vehicles, but the events of September 2015 really opened our eyes. The Volkswagen case showed that there is a massive problem and further revelations have underlined that. They have shown that this is not only about Volkswagen. There has been a systematic failure of the type approval system right across Europe – a system that could not prevent one of the biggest ever industrial scandals in Europe.  So maintaining the status quo is not even an option; we need real change, we need a 180° shift to our regulatory system. We have to show that Europe can make a difference to people’s lives. Air quality in many of our cities is unacceptably poor and it causes premature deaths, and citizens have been cheated. It is time for citizens to see that we are all pulling in the same direction and that we are all putting their interests, their health and their environmental concerns first.  So the Commission very much welcomes the good progress made by Parliament. We commend the hard work of the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs. This was a huge effort and we know it has not been an easy process. You are sending a strong and a clear message to our citizens and to our industry. Type approval must put safety, environmental protection and the well-being of citizens first. When they buy a car, consumers must be able to trust the promises on emission limits, fuel consumption, safety rules and so on.  This is the aim of our proposal and we are very pleased that the Internal Market Committee report supports the main pillars of our proposal, namely reinforcing the independence and quality of the car testing system, introducing a system to control cars on the road, and reinforcing the type approval system with greater European oversight. These pillars are fundamental to ensure that industry will comply with the rules, and that there will be high quality, high transparency and a level playing field between manufacturers.  It is not only manufacturers who need to change. Everyone involved will have to follow the rules strictly and to apply the requirements in a harmonised manner, whether they be importers, testing bodies and laboratories, or type approval and market surveillance authorities. No exceptions, no gaps.  You push us for even stronger actions, for instance mandatory targets for national market surveillance or reinforcing the Commission’s powers. These proposals go in the right direction and we are ready to consider them constructively. I believe that we should concentrate our efforts on these main pillars, so that we can make swift and effective progress. Other issues such as the provision of repair and maintenance information can be better addressed through parallel strands of work.  Let me tackle now the main open issue, which is the creation of an EU agency for vehicle market surveillance. I know that you discussed this at length and that you will continue discussing this today. In fact we already assessed the possibility of creating an EU agency as part of our type approval proposal. We discarded the idea at the time, mainly in the interest of speed, efficiency and budgetary resource implications.  In the meantime, we have seen how difficult it is to ensure proper enforcement in a system of 28 different national authorities. So far, only a handful of them have taken action against emissions cheating and only one Member State seems truly decisive, so effectively the remaining Member States are making the case for an agency by not acting. You will have noticed that the White Paper on the Future of Europe refers to a possible enforcement agency. Let us take the discussion further in that context. We are eager to listen to your opinions and concrete proposals today.  Mr President, honourable Members, whichever option we finally choose we need to make certain that it delivers a real 180° change. We have a duty to our citizens. They have been badly let down and they need to see that there has been real change. This is not just important for their health and their safety, it is also important for the environment and the future of the planet. By the way, it is important also for the future competitiveness of our car industry.

name: Karima DELLI
text: rapporteur for opinion TRAN. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 30 million garbage vehicles are on our roads. These are vehicles which do not meet the standards voted in this chamber ten years ago and which exceed them ten times, or even fifteen times for some. In other words, during these famous episodes of air pollution, it is the health of our citizens that is directly affected. Admittedly, these exceedances of standards are directly caused by the fraud of the manufacturers during the homologation tests. But it is also because of a complacent system between manufacturers and authorities that a vehicle does not meet the standards on the road and, coincidentally, does meet them in laboratory tests. With this report, Mr Dalton, you have the opportunity to bring order to a failing European certification system by establishing more independent and transparent tests and, above all, by allocating the means of monitoring the markets throughout. the life of vehicles. For me, there is only one thing left to do: reassure our citizens and show them that the European Parliament can say that there will never be Dieselgate again. The solution is simple - the European Commission has said it, many of us have also been saying this since this morning -, we must create a European market surveillance agency. We need a European gendarme against cheating. The citizens are waiting for us at the turn and they are by our side.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by thanking the rapporteur, Dan Dalton and other colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, for a really huge piece of work, for being able to communicate, be open and, above all, find the common solutions we really need. I am glad that we in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection have really succeeded in finding these solutions. It is clear to everyone that we need new legislation for the approval of new vehicles. It is clear to everyone that the 'diesel gate' cannot be repeated and our citizens cannot be deceived. At the same time, we need to better protect our environment, but also to think about the development of new technologies and employment in the European Union. We have been debating this final form of the new legislation in our committee for more than a year. The result is a change in methodology, new competencies, but also synergies between the European level and nation states. Full-scale testing is being introduced, the Commission's competences are being strengthened and a uniform procedure and interpretation of the rules is ensured throughout the Union. Last year's events have shown that this is really, very much needed. I am sure that we do not need new institutions, but we need a rapid substantial change that will work. We do not need new costs, but we need clear and enforceable rules. We do not need quarrelsome Member States, but we need the same rules for our entire European common market. I am pleased that the European Commission itself is not proposing new institutions, but is proposing a change in the current way, as is our committee. The exit from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection is a really good proposal, and I believe that it will be supported by everyone who cares about real change and the protection of the interests of our citizens.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. - Sir. Chairman! Volkswagen cheating with diesel emissions is a scandal. Unfortunately, it has turned out that it was not just Volkswagen that did not care about our European rules. Large parts of the automotive industry have put economic considerations over the environment and health. For us Social Democrats, it is therefore absolutely crucial to ensure new and tighter EU legislation that can prevent similar scandals in the future. Greater independence is required in type approval. Those who check that the cars comply with the rules must not be dependent on money from the car industry. Furthermore, Member States need to be made far more responsible for ensuring better type approval and control of cars when driving on the road. In addition, the European Commission must have more competences so that it is obliged to intervene and not sit idly by if it suspects failure and fraud. All this is part of and ensured by the Dalton report. All levels are committed to making work better, faster, more comprehensive and independent of the automotive industry. But we Social Democrats want to go one step further. We want the control of the cars to be concentrated in an EU agency. We know from experience in other areas that Member States often do not have the money, manpower or political will to control cars adequately. That is why we are proposing the creation of an EU agency to assemble and ensure that control of the cars takes place. It is both the cheapest and best way to ensure equal and real enforcement. We Social Democrats also want consumers to be compensated when damage occurs. In the US, Volkswagen's diesel cars have already been removed from the roads, faults have been rectified and consumers have been compensated. In the EU, consumers are still completely without compensation. We want this to change, and we believe that the extra penalty for companies to pay compensation can have a preventive effect. Overall, however, we Social Democrats are really happy about it result that has come, and we hope that this report can help ensure that a new diesel scandal is avoided in the future.

name: Vicky FORD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the mutual recognition of product standards is a cornerstone of trade within Europe and the type approval process for new cars is a prime example. Once a vehicle has passed its safety and emission tests in one country it can then be put on the market across all other countries without having to undergo further tests. It saves manufacturers millions in costs which would otherwise be spent on duplicative bureaucracy.  Buying a new car is the single largest purchase most individuals make and it is important that consumers trust the system and therefore the test process must be thorough and robust in every country. This new report tightens the tests of vehicles on and off the road, it introduces new tests for the testers and regular re-testing of existing models. Penalties are introduced for those who try to cheat the tests.  This is a fundamental review of the approval process for cars in Europe and I would like to thank my British Conservative colleague Dan Dalton for leading this piece of work and my colleagues from all across Europe who have worked with him. In a post-Brexit world it is in no one’s interest to re-introduce unnecessary red tape and I hope both sides will continue to cooperate on regulatory matters to enable mutual recognition to continue and work together for strong standards not only in the UK and Europe, but also across the rest of the world.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and my shadow rapporteurs for the work done. I think that the outcome is well balanced. It provides the EU with more efficient and stronger mechanisms for type approval of cars before they enter European markets and for their actual monitoring when they are already present on the market.  Over a year ago, when this House discussed the car emissions inquiry committee, our Group called for an EU-level surveillance system which would contribute to better enforcement of EU legislation. Today that proposal is here and it means that we will not continue business as usual. Not only has it restated the obligations for Member States to actively engage in market surveillance, but it also provides the Commission with a new set of competences to act on its own behalf or as a safeguard when the Member States fail to do so. This is a major contribution to the legislation, which aims to restore consumers’ trust in our control mechanisms and in the European car industry. It is in the interest of us all to provide Europeans with the right to reliable and transparent information about their vehicles.  Some of our colleagues have been talking about the need to establish an EU market surveillance agency, which would take over all the tasks in this field. Our Group does not believe this to be a good idea. The agency definitely does not meet the need to respond quickly to scandal. It would only create a supplementary layer of administration at high cost with little added value.  And finally, there is no competence that an agency could have which could not be given to the Commission directly. Our Group believes that the Commission is the right institution to assume oversight powers at EU level and that the new system introduced in this report should prevent Member States from interfering with those new powers. So I hope that we can adopt this report today in plenary.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - First some facts in a row. We have an internal market. So if a new type of car is approved in one Member State, it applies to the entire EU. So far so good. As a manufacturer you can go to any test institute in the EU and then to any supervisor for approval. This is useful for the manufacturer, because if you cannot get it done at one supervisor, you just go to the next. And then it goes wrong. Car manufacturers are introducing fraudulent software for diesel cars, but no Member State detects it. Regulators fail. Could that have something to do with competition between regulators? The European Commission is also not doing anything. Commissioner Verheugen was too concerned with promoting the auto industry through his CARS 21 Group and Commissioner Tajani knowingly ignored all indications about cheating software. Turning to the Dalton report: competition between regulators is simply maintained. We could also have chosen to refer manufacturers to the regulator in the country of the manufacturer's headquarters. But we don't. Although Member States and the Commission have all failed, Parliament is putting all the cards on the Commission through this report. He may carry out inspections himself. What a mess! How will citizens react when European inspectors come to check your car? Hopefully in the garage, but it is also allowed on the road. European diesel police, can it get any crazier? Inspections and enforcement in general are powers of the state and the EU is not a state. This report does not really solve the problem of cheating. But it does give the extreme right yet another trump card to say that the citizens are bit by bit torn into a superstate of Europe. And that of a British Conservative rapporteur. I am deeply disappointed and the majority of my group will also vote against this report. [The speaker answers on a “blue card” question under Rule 162 (8).]

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Mr. Representative!I would like to ask you that, although we both see similarly that there are vehicles and trailers to be inspected, it is also possible that there may be some kind of inspection system.But are you aware that there is a common European methodology by which these workshops or these institutions could be examined?

name: Dennis de JONG
text: "blue card" answer.- I certainly think that it is possible to come to a peer review system with the Member States in which you combine car-producing countries with non-car-producing countries and carry out these checks together.That makes perfect sense in the current system.Now we are saying that the Commission may start carrying out the inspections and that is going a step too far.We have discussed those proposals with the rapporteur.It seemed that we would be moving towards peer review.Clearly, this has not been chosen.And that is why we are so disappointed.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, this dossier is emblematic of the added value that the European Union can bring to the daily lives of 500 million consumers. In fact, this issue first touches on the conflict of interests between manufacturers - and therefore private interests - States and the general interest. This is the first point. Then it touches on particulate matter emissions, NOx emissions as well as fraud on these emissions and, therefore, directly to health. This issue also concerns CO2 emissions, an area in which we have led the fight against climate change, as well as state aid, since states subsidize low-emission vehicles. Finally, this issue naturally touches on the role the European Union plays in preventing competition between States and the distortion of competition in the markets. We have here all the criteria that can effectively allow the European legislator to intervene. I would like to pay tribute to the work of Mr Dalton and all of the shadow rapporteurs. In fact, on the issue of vehicle homologation, we have made some progress, in particular - this is a very important point that you recalled - by cutting the umbilical cord between the homologation authorities and the manufacturers and by having European transparency, which is also very important. On the other hand, Commissioner, I would like you to be even clearer in supporting the modification of market surveillance. In the past, we have had a very serious failure and I say this to all those who say that a European agency would be useless. However, we have a clear and proven failure of the States and of the European Commission. We therefore need an independent agency that would spearhead the control and objective monitoring of markets.In addition, we must also compensate consumers who suffer prejudice on major health issues.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in many European countries, such as Italy, France and Germany, the political link between car manufacturers and the governments that issue homologations is known, and it is known how the "Dieselgate" has brought out a dramatic fact, namely the conflict of interest between the controller (the State) and the controlled (the car manufacturers). Today we have a great opportunity to change this system. We have the opportunity to offer citizens legislation that can overcome national conflicts of interest. I ask my colleagues to be ambitious in this. In the report that we are going to vote on today on the supervision of motor vehicles, we have the possibility to introduce improvements, to make this proposal more ambitious, first of all by asking that 20% of the new models placed on the market be checked for each Member State. In this way, for example, a vehicle launched by Fiat would be controlled throughout Europe, and this would make manipulations much less frequent, if not impossible. Then, we all talked about an independent third party, able to control what the national authorities approve, and we focused on the agency, which on average is perceived as a bandwagon. So we want to be proactive: we propose an authority, not an agency, an authority that is in charge of the Commission and that can use existing structures. In particular, we have identified the laboratory of the Joint Research Center of Ispra, which is already equipped from an instrumental point of view with many instruments. And to those who say that there is no funding to support this type of approach, we point out that, without asking the citizens for anything, but simply with a small charge for the manufacturers, we would have these resources. We are talking about ten euros per vehicle. And finally, we ask that the tests made on the road, which represent a very positive thing, are not made on prototypes, but on vehicles that are already ready for the market.So I reiterate that today we have this opportunity to be ambitious and I ask my colleagues to be ambitious, and I hope you will welcome this invitation.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The automobile is a European invention, but the European Union has no part in it. The major European car brands are the result of French ingenuity, German engineering and Italian daring and Italian design. The European Commission did not invent anything. It merely regulates, and if it had existed 150 years ago, we might not have had any major European automobile groups today. The Commission is putting forward a draft in which a whole network of authorities is spun, the strings of which ultimately come together in the hands of the Commission, and the rapporteur contributes those passages which, as a German, one would almost have missed in the Commission text. The hatred of the German automotive industry drips from the amendments in the report. Car manufacturers, who make customers around the world happy and to whom we owe a large part of Germany's prosperity, appear as environmentally damaging sexual offenders, as felons, whom the Commission and its thousands of authorities have to find out about with increasingly sophisticated investigative methods if the continent is not in the catastrophe should end. Mr. Dalton, what do you have against Volkswagen? And why do you think that the Commission of all people could improve something? Have you forgotten that the 2007 Type Approval Directive found meaningless test cycles in the laboratory sufficient? Have you forgotten that the Commission had been aware of the different emission values ​​since 2010 at the latest and closed its eyes? And do you think the new regulation will actually protect consumer health? Your party has proven in Britain that it is capable of anywhere near destroying the automotive industry. The fact that you are now trying again shortly before Brexit to enforce this also for continental Europe has one special note.But the Committee on the Environment, which asked for an opinion, tops it all off.He calls for a new monster authority, a vehicle market surveillance agency of the EU, which should still control all the pseudo-national authorities and should be financed by an administration fee on new vehicles.And in the aisles of Parliament there are advertising stands for the vehicle market surveillance agency with huge purple pillows that look like the vagina costumes of the Trump opponents in the USA.Ladies and gentlemen, we have no lack of control.We had unrealistic rules that were not based on real driving conditions, and we had a commission that closed its eyes.That is the cause of the scandal.You will not change that with this report, Mr Dalton.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! Daniel Dalton's draft report gives a very clear answer to the central question, namely the question of whether in Europe - with Italy, Germany and France, as just mentioned - there are ultimately uniform answers to uniform problems. We sorely missed that in the whole discussion about vehicle registrations. It simply cannot be that the type approval authority in one country of the European Union comes to the conclusion that a car can be approved while the authority in another country comes to a different view for exactly the same car. If we allow such conditions in Europe, we will in fact run into a catastrophe because the internal market will then lose its acceptance and its basis. That is why the most important step that we are taking now is to ensure that an authorization is ultimately an authorization for the entire internal market. And if there are misunderstandings between different authorities, then and only then does the European Commission have the responsibility to scientifically unambiguously determine which elements must be taken into account in the approval and which not. This is progress for all of us. And that’s why I’m totally happy that the Greens and Pascal Durand, the Social Democrats, the Liberals, that we are all pulling together, that above all we are trying to get things on the right track with a focus on results. This European agency, which is always floating around in the debate, is, of course, to a certain extent a favorite project for some, which is also politically okay. In my opinion, however, it would not accelerate the process of getting the results for the users, for the consumers, but slow it down. And that is why the EPP Group is rather skeptical of this proposal across from.But if one day the system really works, then we will be the last ones who want to shut ourselves completely off this fundamentally European idea.Good compromises have also been achieved in a number of other areas, and it is a proposal that will help the Member States to do their job better in future and that we can achieve this together, above all, in a European sense.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I listened to the speech with interest. My question is about economics, as opposed to regulation. How much regulation do you think is too much? The cost of all this will ultimately impact on the market, ultimately impact on the cost of the vehicles, ultimately impact on the desire of consumers to purchase and on how many jobs there are across Europe in the automotive sector. So my question to you, sir, is: how far is too far in regulation, and where do we have the balance?

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, colleague, for your interesting question. From my point of view, there is no further burden with this regulation. For the car manufacturers the big advantage will be that they can be sure that if they have one type approval it is a type approval for the whole European Union. That is cheaper than everything we have seen in the past and therefore I think we are reducing the burden for companies with that proposal, not raising it. It is fine if this is ultimately done by the Commission, if national authorities are not able to find the right way between themselves.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I think that today we are giving the European Union a more certain and effective regulatory framework, more capable of avoiding new scandals. I therefore consider it important to thank the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs, in particular our shadow rapporteur, my colleague Mrs. Schaldemose, for the important work they have done and which we will approve here today. This text contains some important points, and therefore I would like to highlight them. The first: the absolute prohibition of the possibility of installing manipulation software on motor vehicles, and the fact that from now on there will be an approval and surveillance system, which will be constant throughout the life of the vehicle, as well as greater powers of control and monitoring by the European Commission, which will certainly tend to harmonize the European supervisory system. There will ultimately be greater consumer power. I believe this is really a strong disincentive against fraudulent actions. They were, I said, very important results, but we would have liked even more ambitious ones to break once and for all the links that exist between car manufacturers, their technical services and national approval authorities, which in many cases are even private. Therefore it would be necessary to define a single and independent vehicle surveillance system at European level. Dear colleagues, we still have time to respond to these needs, and therefore to vote for the establishment of a European vehicle surveillance agency that delivers a more efficient and more transparent system, and that is finally able to restore the betrayed trust of citizens and consumers and ensure a high level of protection of health and the environment.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, it is clear that the rules for the approval of motor vehicles need to be modernized. We need to strengthen market surveillance, more thorough checks on in-service vehicles and so on. But, as usual, we are faced with the question of how to achieve this. Some new control mechanisms and obligations seem problematic to me. I would also personally have more confidence in the national authorities and not give so much space to the Commission. Yes, I would personally opt for other solutions in some provisions, but I understand that this is a compromise and a solid basis for negotiating with the Council in a very complex matter. In other words, the rapporteur, my colleague Daniel Dalton, has done a very good job and he deserves his thanks. I just hope that a pan-European supervisory agency will not be added to the report at the last minute, and we have had a very long discussion in the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. We simply cannot solve every problem by creating a new European Supervisory Authority. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: the question he asked by raising the blue card.- Mr. President, Mr. Tošenovsky, I have listened to you carefully and I know that you belong to a political group that is not inclined to solve problems at European level, at least to some extent it is not, but don't you think we should still have a European vehicle monitoring agency?and fish, and we know we have a common fisheries policy.Cars are driven and sold all over Europe, and beyond, and that’s our cars.Does it not seem to you that, in addition to the need to monitor cars at national level, we should also have a serious European car monitoring agency?

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Thank you for your question, I belong to a group that makes a great distinction between what should and should not be done at European level and what should remain at national level.In this case, I think that the same rules that will apply to individual national controllers are sufficient, it is more cost-effective than if there is one large agency across Europe.I think it will only bring bigger problems.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: – Mr President, I believe yellow and red cards were being pulled in the previous debates to the Commission and Council. Let me start by congratulating the Commission on its quick and right response to the Dieselgate scandal by coming forward with the new type-approval proposal. It creates more transparency and it creates the strong European oversight that is so badly needed. I think the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) has been right in embracing, and even enforcing, these proposals. I do have a few concerns, and I will mention just one here today, and that is that IMCO is weakening the fee structure. In the inquiry committee we found out that insufficient financing at national level was one of the reasons, or excuses, for Member States not to enforce the legislation as they should have done. The fee structure proposed by the Commission would have been the right solution for that and, unfortunately, that has been weakened.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: - Mr President, if the Commission and the national parliaments had been active as required by law, the emissions scam would not have been possible. When the scam was exposed, I did not think it was tackled with sufficient effectiveness. It was believed when automotive lobbyists threatened with job losses. It is now known that what the car industry won thanks to its lobbying is paid for by people who suffer from the effects of air pollution. More people die from transport emissions than from road accidents, and yet there has been silence from both a human and an economic point of view. The most frightening idea, after all the research and studies, is that at the moment, no one can reliably estimate the actual emissions from transport. Although the European Commission is currently developing tests to measure actual emissions while driving, Vastamäki is still steep in terms of combating climate change. There was no desire to impose any kind of sanctions when dealing with type-approval legislation, which is special because when a citizen commits an offense, he is punished. But when large industries or member states fail to comply with the laws, they are treated with the most silk gloves. If we set up a new agency, it too must not be treated with silk gloves, but must really be monitored and have real tools to tackle the problems. The people of Europe have earned solutions that protect their lives and health - not destroy them.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for their work on this file. This will be the first report. This will be the first legislative action after Dieselgate, so this is going to be the big question of our citizens: have we learned from Dieselgate? That is going to be the question. I think we are making steps forward but it is not sufficient. Of course most of the debate is on the famous independent agency. Why are we pushing for that? Read the conclusions from the Inquiry Committee – seven counts of maladministration against the Commission. One of the problems was that we had people in the Commission who carried out measurements at the Ispra Joint Research Centre years ago. They had the information. The information was not communicated to the outside world. Reports that went out were anonymous on purpose. This means that what you saw was that the Commission was part of the problem.  What we are suggesting is an agency that is doing the surveillance, that is doing the testing. Their results will be communicated to the Commission in an open, transparent way, so it will improve transparency and then the Commission will be obliged to react to that. Will there be much more bureaucracy? No! This is people who are already working for Europe, but who will now become independent so they can make independent decisions and are not part of the Commission that is there to regulate, check and also to do something if something goes wrong. That is too much in one hand and therefore we need an independent structure around it.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under rule 162(8))

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: blue-card question. – I was glad to listen to Bas Eickhout’s explanations on the agency, and I would like to come back on his point and ask a question. For what reason do you believe that an independent agency, as opposed to all the agencies we already have, will really bring the advantages that you have explained here? Would it not be better to keep this Chamber here as a control on the Commission, as a political authority, to make sure that what happened in the past will definitely not happen again?

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. Very simply: first of all, third parties can now directly ask the agency to do the checking. They can answer to the Commission, but, in the last five years they did not follow up that much, did they? An agency would be there to do that specifically. They will be designed to do that. They will draft the report and then comes the control. If they find things that are not good, they will send the report to the Commission. It is still the Commission that will decide on whether to take action at the level of the type-approval authority or the national authority. The Commission is still there, and there we have control over the fining structure and making sure there is action, that corrective action is being taken by the Commission; and that is what we control. The testing, the surveillance, is independent. And in making it independent there is also more transparency in the communication between the agency and the Commission. This is really better on transparency and putting the pressure on the Commission when they are not acting, which we can still control. It works like with medicines and like with a lot of other controlling agencies we already have. It is about time we also had it for cars.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, the Volkswagen scandal of 2015 sent shockwaves across the world. Just how easy it was for Volkswagen to manipulate the emissions testing certainly raised many questions and concerns. Our consumers expect and deserve better from our businesses. But for all the faults that the Volkswagen scandal has exposed, the answer in this place is never to let the market decide or to allow national authorities to learn from mistakes. Instead, the EU takes the opportunity to engulf us in more legislation and more powers for bureaucrats and bureaucracy. For businesses, this is an eye-watering EUR 40 billion bill for the taxpayer. I am absolutely in favour of protecting consumers and holding businesses to account, but I simply cannot support legislation that is going to cost our taxpayers billions, and hand further powers away from the United Kingdom. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under rule 162(8))

name: Julie GIRLING
text: blue-card question. – I would like to know where your figure of EUR 40 billion comes from and how you justify it. Secondly, I would like to know why, as a representative of the UK, you have not mentioned the health issues here at all. You value business, but you do not seem to value the cost to people’s health. How do you expect health improvements to be made without some of the steps that are in this legislation?

name: Margot PARKER
text: blue-card answer. – [microphone off for opening words] a sovereign country to be able to look after the health and state of its own citizens. I also believe that you can actually allow the market to work in a sensible way. After all, if consumers are short—changed and if they are poisoned by inadequate consequences, they are not going to buy these products. I believe the market will find its level, but I also reject your question about not caring about consumer health. We most certainly do. In the short time we have here, we answer as best we can.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: - Mr Chairman! We all agree here that the car market in Europe needs more supervision, and I am very pleased that we are now going in the right direction. Here I would like to thank our colleague Ivan Štefanc. I hope that in negotiations with the Council he will be able to defend the demands that are important to consumers, so that the automotive market functions better and better. This new supervision means more competences for the European Commission to jointly manage the automotive market, as already mentioned by Andreas Schwab. And thanks to this, I hope that it will finally be possible to rebuild consumer confidence in the automotive sector, because it has been severely strained recently. In addition, it is important that this automotive market supports innovation: the use of the Internet, "big data" - all this gives great innovation opportunities in the automotive sector. And we must make sure that Europe is a leader in this field. Consumers want to take advantage of the revolution taking place in telematics, and we must ensure that they have the right to choose whether they want to use manufacturer's workshops or other small workshops not authorized by sellers. I am glad that we have managed to introduce into the regulation provisions securing the interests of consumers in this respect, but also millions of jobs for small and medium-sized enterprises. Thank you very much for your great cooperation.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - Mister President! We are on a very important piece of legislation here, in which we have to ensure that the safety and health of the citizens are given priority, and that is one of the very important questions. We must also learn the right lessons from the report by the EMIS Committee, namely that we cannot leave it to the Member States alone to decide what should and should not be done here. And there is also a very important question that needs to be clarified as to whether we need a European agency or not, and like my colleague Christel Schaldemose, I am absolutely convinced that we need one. And I have to honestly say that the right side, the EPP, showed its true colors again. In the EMIS committee, you are voting in favor - this is a report that is very important, very, very important, but not legally binding. In the Internal Market Committee it is about legislation, that is, about making a binding decision, and you are voting against that. So what's that supposed to be? Yes to make big slogans but when it comes to making this a reality they are no longer there! So I would ask you to be a little more honest in what you are doing and work with us to ensure that we really have these regulatory measures that are really so important for the future. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I know Evelyne Gebhardt's commitment to consumer issues and I know it is genuine, but I would like to ask whether adding agencies, further bureaucracy and more institutions is really on the consumer's side?Is it not enough to give more rights to those institutions that already exist and operate, like the European Commission, under our control?

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, we need this European agency because it means precisely more consumer protection.The European Commission itself has confirmed to us that the Member States are really willing to actually implement European legislation, and we need an independent agency that really does its job, and we have also seen that it is not enough to just put it into your handsto the European Commission.That's why I say: yes, we need them!This is no longer bureaucracy.It is more security for the citizens.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, are there problems in the field of vehicle approval and inspection? Yes, there is. Have major deficiencies been revealed in the national systems of market surveillance and homologation control in force? Yes, they were. Has the Volkswagen case shaken citizens' confidence in this system? Yes, it did. If we agree with these three statements, we must be consistent and review and deepen the approval system as an immediate response to the revealed anomalies. We must prevent cases of non-compliance from recurring. And we saw that it did not work to leave that control to the Member States alone. This review guarantees, and I applaud, a double vigilance by the European Commission that, for this, gains new powers. The Internal Market Commission and its rapporteur, Mr Dalton, are also to be congratulated. We have achieved a good result by improving the Commission's proposal. This is a good example that consumer protection must be at the heart of the Union's priorities. We must demand that car manufacturers operating in the Union have their vehicles tested before they are placed on the market and during the its life cycle. We will only be able to restore the confidence of citizens and the market in this sector with a robust, transparent, predictable and sustainable regulatory framework that guarantees a high level of safety and protection of health, the environment and consumers. This also involves rapid, appropriate and coordinated corrective measures.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a regulation on type-approval is extremely important, as can be seen from the debates we have and from the debates in the public system. As an alternative rapporteur on the opinion to the TRAN Commission, we worked a lot with the shadow rapporteurs, we met many times to find an optimal solution and compromises for the opinion given to the IMCO Commission. I am also a member of the IMCO Committee and I have thought of all the amendments from the perspective of consumer protection and environmental safety. First of all, our common point was that there is a need to improve the type-approval and verification system, as well as supervision and control. Secondly, we have supported and continue to support more demanding approval procedures and reliable, harmonized and transparent supervision. There is a need to improve the institutional framework for market surveillance and control of type-approval, but also for consumer compensation. I believe that the report needs to be voted on, it is important that market surveillance authorities ensure the uniform application of this regulation in order to provide certainty to producers as well as consumers. This Regulation should not demotivate producers. But it must lead to fair competition and respect for consumer rights and environmental standards. It is important that this regulation improves cooperation between Member States, improves communication through the market information system, and I agree: Member States and producers must be responsible, because otherwise we cannot solve anything. Thanks.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - Cooperation between the Committee on the Environment, the Committee on the Internal Market and the Committee on Transport is not always easy when it comes to the interests of the transport sector. But today we have an exception with the Committee on the Internal Market. The cooperation between the Committee on Transport and the Committee on the Internal Market on this file was exceptionally good and clear. And, Mr President, that is also necessary. Earlier this morning we discussed the so-called emissions scandal, in which many politicians, but especially consumers, are disappointed with what the European car industry has done to us in recent years, to use that word for once. I think that with this report by Daniel Dalton we can take a new path. As the Commissioner also said: it must be more transparent and it must also be more realistic, this entire test cycle. Then the agency totem pole. It seems like this debate should be reduced to an agency. We in the PPE Group and the Committee on Transport believe that a forum for enforcement is a good start that can also take place quickly, without a new tribal struggle, but transparent with the Member States!

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - in the case of a Member State of the European Parliament, the European Parliament and the Council of the European Parliament taċ-ċittadini. In the case of partisanship of the political group, the policy should be taken as a matter of urgency in the case of the Member States. The opportunity to use a high-powered Volkswagen car is only possible. Imma biex dan isir, irridu sorveljanza indipendenti li tista ‘tielu l-forma ta’ aenzenzija. Irridu naraw li l-konsumaturi jkunu kumensati meta ma jingħatawx dak li ħallsu għalih. In fact, the volume or volume of the water is significantly reduced; Madankollu dan m’għandux isir għad-detriment tal-ambjent, għaliex id-dinja li qegħdin ngħixu fiha qed tinbidel b’pass imgħaġġel u aħna rridu naħdmu ħafna aktar biex inżommu ma ’dan l-istess pass. Issa huwa ż-żmien li l-ħidma li għamilna realtà nsarrfuha f’riżultati.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, in my speech, I want to support the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, it seems to me to be sensible and balanced. It is clear that we need new rules governing the type-approval of motor vehicles, such rules that, in the form of a regulation, will apply to the whole market, to the whole of the European Union. It is therefore good that we will replace the directive, which each country translates into its legal systems in different ways, with one valid regulation. It seems to me that this will strengthen the market and it will be an advantage for the manufacturers themselves. There is a very debated issue of the agency, I am glad that in the end this solution did not win. On the one hand, the supporters of the agency are talking about consumer rights here, I want to say here that in the Czech Republic, most consumer citizens view with distrust the establishment of more and more agencies. If we set up another agency, I am telling you here that for most citizens in the Czech Republic, it would be a strengthening of the Brussels bureaucracy, and most citizens in our country would not agree with such a solution. So, in my opinion, there is a much better way if we do not create another body, but strengthen the powers of the Commission, although I have doubts about some of the powers that we are giving to the Commission. I think that the supervision and oversight activities should be carried out primarily by the individual Member States, and only if they do not do so should the Commission take on the role. I am also pleased that the charging for such services has fallen, and it is up to the Member States.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! We have noticed that there is a discrepancy: on the one hand we have good emissions legislation and on the other hand bad controls. As the rapporteur for Euro 3 and Euro 4, I introduced the ban on electronic defeat devices back then and already said at the time: We need more monitoring. We need stronger market surveillance and a change in the type approval directive. The Council - which is once again not here today - rejected that with force at the time. And that led to precisely this result, that we had to establish that gaps had apparently been searched for and which automobile companies were also using. That is why we need clear European monitoring of compliance with our regulations, and that must be the result of this legislative process. I can only give our negotiating team all the power on earth so that they can prevail against the Council and really create a sensible monitoring system.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  Mr President, I welcome Mr Dalton’s good work and again congratulate him on it. This is a regulation that is so important to our citizens, not only in terms of consumer confidence and information, but also to prevent the damaging effects of emissions on public health and on climate change. In this regard we must do everything we can to prevent cheating by car manufacturers aiming to manipulate emissions and fuel consumption tests and produce false results for financial gain. We must do our utmost to ensure that consumers are protected at all times and that the quality of goods is as described at the point of sale.  A number of measures here are worthy of support. Random market surveillance to be carried out by Member States on at least 20% of new models on the market is a very good idea. Unfortunately, given the proven dishonesty of certain players in the market, this is a necessary step to prevent manipulation of testing. I am pleased also that the Commission will be given responsibility for insisting on the recalling of vehicles, for example in order to bring non-compliant vehicles into conformity.  Above all, I welcome the penalties. A fine of EUR 30 000 per vehicle in breach of regulations might seem a lot, but in actual fact it is nothing. The solution is simple: comply with the regulatory requirements and the penalty will not apply to you.  From the point of view of reducing harmful emissions etc. this is a very good report and I commend everybody involved in it.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is clear that the report approved in the IMCO committee contains elements of novelty, which are important.Anything that introduces transparency into relations between producers and consumers goes in the right direction;intervention to limit conflicts of interest between those who produce and those who use is also a positive novelty.I would also add that it is important that there is a minimum quota, a defined threshold of cars to check.However, the agency is missing.The agency is not an overlap, it is not the creation of a new level of bureaucracy.We are talking about an independent and self-financed agency.What is the task, the function, of the agency?To break one of the negative phenomena that the surveys of recent years have shown us, which is the negative relationship between producers and who should control them.An independent agency would instead entrench a completely different behavior.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: - L-iskandlu tal-Volkswagen ħasseb lill-konsumaturi Ewropej, u tellfilhom il-fiduċja li hija dgħajfa u li ma tipproteġihomx - sistema li ffaċilitat frodi u ingann billi nstabu kemm setgħu loopholes u qarrqu b’milju. Li huwa aktar ta ’tħassib huwa, li dan il-frodi qarrieqi ma nkixifx mill-Unjoni Ewropea, minkejja l-fatt li probabbli għandna waħda mill-aħjar leġiżlazzjonijiet għall-protezzjoni tal-konsumatur. Huwa proprju għalhekk li huwa tant diffiċli, f’dan il-każ particolari, nammettu magħna nfusna li l-Ewropa ma rnexxilhiex tipproteġi liċ-ċittadini u l-konsumaturi tagħha. L-Europa ma rnexxilhiex tassigura li l-karozzi fl-Europa jkunu effiċjenti fl-enerġija nadifa fit-toroq, bħalma jkunu fil-laboratorji. Madankollu, illum għandna opportunità li nirranġaw dan kollu billi nadottaw regoli aktar b’saħħithom li jibqgħu jgħoddu għall-futur u jtejbu s-sitwazzjoni kurrenti u jipprovdu kundizzjonijiet ekwi fl-industrija tal-karoz. Għalhekk inħeġġiġkom, biex meta tivvotaw illum, tiftakru li f’din il-kwistjoni huma involuti saħħet, is-suretà u l-fiduċja taċ-ċittadini fis-sistema u fil-kapaċità tagħna li noħolqu regoliu li jipprote.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: - Mr President, when the Volkswagen scandal emerged, we talked about three types of messages: we talked about responsibility, we talked about restoration or rectification and we also talked about trust. Debugging is still on its way through European courts, but what will really restore consumer confidence in the automotive industry is the rectification that we are introducing today into European law. It is true that the extreme left is not going to support it because it is insufficient and joins, with this, once again, the extreme right, which is not going to support it either because it thinks it will place an excessive burden on the industry. But they do not realize that what really hurts the company is the shadow of doubt about its social and environmental responsibility. For this reason, this Regulation improves the control capacity, avoids conflicts of interest between manufacturers and approval authorities and increases the penalties for those who defraud. We socialists are concerned about the environment. That is why we want the laws to be clear and enforced. That is why we call for the introduction of a European agency with responsibility in the matter. We are concerned about citizens, their health and their trust and, therefore, we establish greater mechanisms to avoid and compensate for fraud. And we are concerned about workers, exemplary in the collective bargaining model and, therefore, we want to send them a message of gratitude and reassurance, that we are with them and that their concerns and their way of acting have also been at work of the S & amp; D Group.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unlike what is happening in the United States, the European authorities have so far had little room for maneuver in imposing specific actions on car manufacturers. While it is true that the automotive industry must be protected, not by imposing economic burdens or excessively burdensome procedures, it is equally necessary to guarantee a high level of compliance between operating standards and Community principles, starting with more effective controls, using independent in the approval process and respect for the principle of free competition. However, the shortcomings in national market surveillance systems are not eliminated simply by delegating the control activity to other authorities, but by creating collaboration models that eliminate possible national conflicts of interest and above all protect consumers when they are exposed. to irregular practices by industry. In this sense, it is also important to encourage the opening of the market by eliminating de facto monopolies that manufacturers hold on some automobile components, in particular electronic ones.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: –  Domnule președinte, apreciez că dați cuvântul tuturor colegilor care s-au înscris la catch the eye. Este un mod în care ne putem exprima și noi poziția atunci când grupul nu ne trece pe lista de vorbitori pentru diferite subiecte pe care le solicităm. Vă mulțumesc încă o dată foarte mult. I believe this report contains improvements, but we have to be more ambitious and equip the EU with a strong, independent watchdog able to act independently to prevent future crises. We have to think of a future-proof solution, given the challenges posed by connected cars. A clear chain of liabilities must be defined and the missing piece is a strong technical body, as budget-neutral as possible, for EU citizens, which is capable of identifying and supporting risks and failures. Second, we should be committed to a real consumer empowerment in contractual relations with any trader. This regulation is a piece of the puzzle. I support the call for the highest level of consumer protection when it comes to remedies and producer liability under consumer contracts proposals, and a strong role to be played by the national competent authorities and the EU in launching actions against fraudulent traders who cheat EU consumers.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I welcome the views that were expressed today and I welcome the support for the high level of ambition in this proposal expressed by many of you. This fundamental reform is vital to ensure sufficient EU oversight and it aims at preventing any future misconduct. It will be key in restoring public confidence and I would like to make some comments.  The independence of approval authorities was raised. Yes, the Commission insists on independence of approval authorities and technical services. Some type-approval authorities and technical services appear to apply lighter interpretations of type-approval requirements than others, and this has to change, undisputedly. We need a level playing field, and fairness and clarity for consumers.  Some Members mentioned that they supported the Commission’s proposal on a fee structure. Under the current system, the technical services that carry out certification testing for manufacturers are, in fact, directly paid by these manufacturers. This undermines the notion of ‘independent’ and that is why we proposed a pooled fee structure on a national basis, which would cover the costs for testing and inspections carried out by the designated technical services, as well as covering the costs for the type-approval certification, market surveillance activities and conformity of production review assessments.  There were some comments that I could not understand. Honestly, I could not understand the question to Mr Dalton along the lines of ‘What is it that you have against Volkswagen?’ and words concerning hatred against the German industry. I think this is total nonsense. This is not about hating the automotive industry, it is all about respecting our citizens’ right not to be cheated and it is all about respecting our citizens’ right to clean, unpolluted air.  The issue of the Agency seems to be the main topic of this debate. I was listening carefully and with interest to the arguments in favour of, and also against, a European Agency and I will watch carefully the results of the vote later today.  One Member also suggested that this will destroy, or words to that effect, the UK car industry. This is not supported by any facts. In fact, the UK car industry has a higher turnover than any other Member State, helped obviously by its access to the EU market. Here, I think I would agree with the comment made by another Member that no-one is against positive economic performance, but no one wants this to be at the expense of citizens’ health.  In Europe, 28 national authorities are responsible for checking car manufacturers’ compliance and most checks occur before the product is put on the market. That is what our type-approval proposal is all about: more checks on the market, better coordination of recalls at EU level, and EU harmonised sanctions. Following the adoption of the real driving emissions act, Europe will be the only region in the world that will measure real driving emissions. Everyone agreed, and I think there were a lot of comments about the fact that we need more market surveillance.  Today’s plenary debate shows the political importance of this proposal as a key response to what has happened regarding exhaust emissions. The European Parliament is sending a strong and clear message to Member States, and to the other players in the sector, that they will no longer get away with not taking safety, environmental protection and the wellbeing of our citizens seriously. I fully agree with this approach and the Commission counts on your further support in the upcoming negotiations with the Council. The Commission’s proposal to strengthen type approval and market surveillance are part of a series of other measures, including the real driving emissions testing, which will mean that the Volkswagen scandal can, and will, never happen again.  More than a year has passed since the Commission tabled this proposal but to the outside world we still have little progress to show, so I would encourage you to start trilogue meetings with the Council as soon as possible. For our part, we are determined to do all it takes to ensure quick progress. We never again want to see a scandal such as the one which has tarnished the reputation of the industry for almost 18 months and this proposal is a key tool to ensure that it will never be repeated. I am certain, and the Commission is certain, that we can get it right by working together. We owe this to our citizens. Thank you very much for contributing and I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all colleagues for their comments. The general view, I think, is that the proposal by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) is a good one. It is a compromise. Everyone has had to move from their original positions, everyone has had to give things up, and I think we need to recognise that. I just wanted to make it clear what type approval is, because I think that there is some confusion, especially on my right, as to what exactly the system is. We have a national system of type approval with mutual recognition across Europe and, as Mr Schwab said, one type approval for the whole of the EU. That is good for consumers, it is good for jobs, it is good for industry, but it is in everyone’s interests to know that the system works in other EU countries because this affects everyone. People in Germany, for example, need to be confident that the system in Italy, say, works, as cars approved in Italy will be driven in Germany. So we need an umpire. We need a role for the Commission, as the report recognises. Now most speakers wanted more independence, transparency, obligations on Member States, compensation, a stronger system: all of that is in this IMCO report.  On the agency – this is the last time I talk about the agency, I promise! – that is not actually the key thing in this report. The details are much more important. I think that the Commissioner is sitting on the fence a little bit, clearly not convinced about the agency; but Bas Eickhout’s answer was, I think, actually the most instructive: the cost and bureaucracy of setting up the agency just to send the results to the same people in the Commission who will deal with the info under the system that we are proposing. It will always come back to the Commission to act, but it is clear that as a Parliament we are split down the middle on this issue. We have to sort it out in a vote and I will support the outcome whichever way it goes. No system will stop people who want to cheat the system, but I think that we have got a stronger system now. The key is to make sure that we get them once they have cheated the system. I think that we can do that. It has been 18 months since the Volkswagen scandal. It has been 15 months since the Commission came forward with its proposal. It is time now for us to get on with it, so I effectively commend this report to the vote later today and I look forward to starting negotiations with the Commission and Council as soon as possible.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, 4 April 2017. (The sitting was suspended at 11.35 am pending a solemn sitting.) Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
