text: in writing. –According to the EMIS committee, most manufacturers abuse the rule which allows them to reduce the efficiency of pollution control systems, in the event that the latter risk damaging the engine, thanks to article 5 of the regulation Community N ° 715/2007. The report deplores the lack of a supranational European accreditation body. However, as a French MP, I cannot ignore that a manufacturer from my country, namely Renault, claims not to have violated European or national rules. French manufacturers are subject to strong competition within the European Union, but especially from Asian countries or the United States. However, the report we are talking about praises the respect by American manufacturers of anti-pollution standards which it claims to be comparable to European standards. However, the situation in the United States is by no means comparable since the use of diesel is in the minority among light vehicles. Sales of French vehicles are also penalized by the euro exchange rate. We therefore reject this text which is contrary to the interests of France, advocating the strengthening of the European Commission and reproaching it for not having used all the means at its disposal against the Member States.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - After the Dieselgate affair, it became clear that the emissions of dirty emissions from most diesel vehicles on the roads are much higher than allowed by EU standards, usually five times higher than the limits. If the existing institutions were to work, I am of the opinion that the Dieselgate affair would not have taken place at all, but at the same time it is clear that this is not an isolated case at all, as confirmed by the EMIS Committee of Inquiry. He concluded that the supervisory authorities at national level were not doing their job properly, thus putting the interests of the car industry ahead of the interests of citizens and public health. The EMIS Committee also noted that there was strong evidence that the use of disconnectors was widespread. Obviously, the car industry has a very strong role to play in ensuring that controls are not exercised. It is unacceptable that the European Parliament did not support the amendments that would allow the establishment of an independent agency at EU level to monitor the vehicle market. The Authority would complement the current system of market surveillance of motor vehicles through independent and transparent supervision, thus ensuring that the vehicles sold meet safety and environmental standards. This would restore consumer confidence and avoid future similar scandals. I am sure that the European Parliament will regret this decision in the future.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear colleagues, It is with great pleasure that I welcome the President of the Federal Republic of Germany to today's plenary session. Dear President, I would like to thank you for this visit from him. We are honored that you have chosen the European Parliament for your second mission outside Germany, after the one in Paris last week and less than three weeks after his inauguration on 19 March. His presence today demonstrates your strong commitment to Europe. You asked for more courage for a better Europe, where freedom is guaranteed and where we all work for a future of peace, prosperity and justice. I am convinced that the courage you ask for can be found among the members of this Parliament. With your presence, dear President, you also remind us of your country's commitment to Europe. An even more important commitment today, given the decision of an important member country to leave the Union. We are certainly living in a difficult moment, others we have experienced in the past, and our Union has always been able to find the right way and to give adequate answers. Dear President, I don't want to ask you today for the right answers, but I do want to invite you to work together with this Parliament for our common future. To you, and thanks again for coming here to Strasbourg.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Federal President of the Federal Republic of Germany. - Mr President, dear Antonio, honorable Members, Mr President of the Commission, dear Jean-Claude, ladies and gentlemen! It is a real pleasure and honor for me to be with you today - in this place of free speech and open debate! But dear friends, my joy is not unclouded. It is bitter to address this plenary for the first time shortly after a Member State has initiated its exit from the European Union. I know you will be giving your position on this in this House tomorrow. I find that bitter - not just as a politician, but first and foremost as a citizen of Europe. You must know: I am about the same age as the European Union. When I was born, in 1956, the wounds left in our cities by the war unleashed by Hitler's Germany could still be seen across Europe. The wounds in the hearts of our neighbors were even bigger. And yet - at that time - they reached out to my country for peace, and together - in Rome 60 years ago - they laid the foundation for the “new Europe”! When I got to school, young people were already symbolically sawing the barriers at European borders to show at the time: We want more Europe! What we have achieved is not enough for us! In 1968 the customs barriers fell within Europe, the long truck lines in front of the barriers were history and the queues for cars were at least shorter. When I came to university, the pull of Europe was already so great that the people in the south of Europe - in Greece, in Spain, in Portugal - not only swept dictatorships aside, but paved the way for freedom and democracy in a common Europe. In 1989, when I was finishing my doctoral thesis, the Berlin Wall fell - brought down by the brave in Eastern Europe who had peacefully achieved freedom and democracy. you it was they who made not only the unity of my country possible, but the reunification of Europe. All this and much more is what is meant when the Rome Declaration says: “We are united for our happiness!” All this is the great legacy that the mothers and fathers of Europe have entrusted to us and on which our children build. We must not divulge this precious legacy and leave it to Europe's opponents. We have to preserve, maintain and improve it - that is our common historical mission! (Loud applause) When I look back on a good 60 years of my life and the same period of time in the European Union, then my view is shaped by the growth, development and success of the new Europe - the path then from the organization of the shortage economy in post-war Europe to one Hope for a more just and peaceful world. To some it seemed - and I do not exclude myself - that what has been achieved is guaranteed forever. But in my biography I have also seen the troubles of Europe: the crises, the contradictions, the setbacks. I had to learn that my belief and that of many in my generation that the path of Europe, the path of European unification, was irreversible, that was a mistake. No, Europe's future is not a certainty - it never was, and we haven't only known since Brexit. I remember 2005. I had just become foreign minister for my country when the dream of a European constitution had just burst. I remember exactly how many of us were disappointed back then. But I know just as well how we - and I suspect many of you here in this Chamber - got together again and did what Europe is particularly good at: get up and carry on. We picked up the telephone receiver, listened to each other, sat all night at the negotiating table - and forged, piece by piece, the Treaty of Lisbon. What I want to say: Europe was never one Walk! Europe is a complicated, yes, an exhausting project. But it's worth the effort! We can and must counter Europe's bad-talkers: cooperation, growing prosperity and, above all, 70 years of peace - that is Europe's promise to its citizens. But never in its history has this promise been fulfilled by itself. It has only been fulfilled when it is not national small spirit but European reason that determines the actions of the actors. That is the yardstick against which we have to stand! (Loud applause) That is exactly why I came to you today. I do not want to give my first speech, which I am giving as Federal President outside of Germany, anywhere else than here - in this Parliament. (Loud applause) Right now, in times of growing centrifugal forces, of noisy prophets of doom, I want to take sides with Europe. As a citizen, I confess, just as many citizens have recently confessed: Yes, I want Europe! And as Federal President I can say: Yes, the vast majority of Germans want Europe! We do not want the way back to an unpleasant past, but the common way to a better European future! That is the perspective! (Applause) If we say yes to Europe, then we don't have to gloss over it, and we don't have to shy away from objections. Anyone who says yes to Europe also says yes to the complicated, exhausting and unfinished of Europe! How complicated political solutions are, how laborious the process - who would know that better than you here in the European Parliament? Not only do conflicting interests meet here, but also different cultures, languages ​​and traditions. Europe's diversity is an adventure, but it is also exhausting. I think I just heard Antonio and the leaders of the political groups sigh about it. But that is precisely what is needed in this Europe today: that we do not entrench ourselves in opinion circles, that we Not only complain about the rifts that have opened up in Europe or withdraw into the national pout, but that we are seriously looking for ways on all sides to build bridges over these rifts. This includes - and it has always been part of Europe - the assumption that the other could be right too. Europe was founded on the assumption that others might be right. Europe's successes have always been compromises. Europe's successes were the laborious but peaceful balancing of interests. This is what this Parliament stands for, what you stand for in 28 nations. Who would become a parliamentarian at all without the will to convince and at the same time the willingness to be convinced, without the passion for the complicated, for the efforts of democracy! Everyone in this hall who has this passion - especially now, in these difficult times - has my great respect and certainly also my support. (Applause) Support because I know that there are others too. There are plenty of other forces who are always there with the very simple answers - answers from the strong hand, answers with clear images of the enemy. A new fascination with the authoritarian is spreading - not only far to the west and east of the European borders, but unfortunately also here with us, in the middle of Europe. Populists paint the world in black and white and turn fears into political capital. Anyone who knows me knows: I am not prone to alarmism. This Parliament can stand the argument - it even needs it. But I also say: Anyone who dismisses democratic institutions and parliaments as a waste of time, who declares willingness to compromise a weakness and, above all, who no longer adheres to the difference between fact and lies, touches the basic structure of democracy, and who becomes, must our decided, ours hear common contradiction as democrats! (Loud applause) The world we live in is more insecure and become more confusing. Many people worry about the future; Fear of losing control. They become receptive to the calls of those who say, “Come back behind the familiar slug of the nation! Borders closed, bulkheads closed - this is the only way we can regain our sovereignty! ”But it is not only naive, it is irresponsible to fool people into thinking that dangers such as terrorism or climate change that do not know any borders can be banished with walls and barriers. It is irresponsible to pretend that in a world that is getting more complicated, the answers get easier. And I am convinced that it is wrong to say that in this world a European country alone and without the EU can make its voice more audible or better assert its economic interests. (Applause) On the contrary: if we do not make Europe a fully fledged player on the world stage, then we will all individually become the plaything of other powers. This is probably exactly what Michael Heseltine, of all people, had in mind when he recently said in an interview that Brexit might be “the greatest loss of British sovereignty”. And he could be right with this prediction. (Applause) “Take back control” - that's how we hear it everywhere - that's a strong slogan, yes. But I predict: nationalists will not be able to redeem it! If at all, then we can make the sentence come true together: - if we don't make things too easy for ourselves; - if we do not shift responsibility to Brussels, but exercise it together; - if we strengthen the internal market and at the same time protect and support those who have been particularly hard hit by the hardships of globalization in recent years; - if we strengthen our innovative strength and creativity in such a way that Europe itself is the creator of change and does not just have to suffer it passively. Only then can we remove the breeding ground from the populists and say: We do not lose sovereignty to Europe, on the contrary. Only together do we gain strength and weight in this changing world! (Applause) The crisis gives us the chance to see Europe as it really is - without illusions, without false optimism, with all of its strengths and also with its weaknesses. And the crisis forces us to answer the question: what and how much European unity do we want? The Commission's White Paper has set out options for this. That is not the solution yet, only one thing seems to be clear to me: permanent self-blockade in the European Union is the worst possible option, it is not! If we want to move forward together, not everyone can ultimately prevail one hundred percent. The problems are too complex and the expectations too different for that: - Yes, we want a stronger Europe and more European solutions, but we also have to leave room for those members who cannot or do not yet want to take further steps towards integration. - Yes, we want to show solidarity with states that are suffering from the consequences of the financial and economic crisis and that have or had to initiate tough reforms. But European solidarity can only support national efforts, not replace them. - Yes, we want to help people who are fleeing war and persecution. But because our common possibilities are finite, we have to decide how and how much responsibility everyone has to bear. - Yes, we want to keep the European Union together internally. But we also know that Europe is bigger than the European Union, and without the involvement of our neighbors in the east and south there will be no lasting peace order on this continent. (Applause) I already know, ladies and gentlemen: none of these problems are easy and, in particular, we must not ignore people's concerns in all of this. But those who built Europe have certainly had tougher problems. You have replaced the battlefield with the negotiating table, the confrontation with a peaceful balance of interests. You have been clever; they have shown common sense. Today's world - a world full of new uncertainties - does not allow us to be any less clever than our predecessors. There is no lack of clarity about the questions that need to be resolved - they are on the table. What is missing is the courage - and sometimes the willingness to solve them on a European basis. And we have to change that! (Applause) The argument is part of balancing interests. We argue in Europe and from my point of view that is not a sign of decay. I, too, have argued in European politics over the past 25 years - not just occasionally, also more often - and I also met one or the other of you here in this room during the argument. But when we argue in Europe, we do so on a firm normative foundation. Many questions are complicated, but that must not cloud our view of the elementary, of the most important things: freedom and democracy, the rule of law and human rights are not up for discussion. It is enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on Union, and all Member States are obliged to do so. That is the essence of Europe, so to speak, that is what Europe is in the eyes of the world and what many people even envy us for. If we stand by it, if we want to be a beacon for the rule of law and human rights in the world, then we shouldn't be indifferent when this foundation shakes inside Europe. And then Europe must not be silent when civil society, even science - as is now the case at the Central European University in Budapest - is being deprived of its breath. Then Europe must not be silent! (Loud applause) But the role of my country is also discussed controversially. Some ask of Germany more leadership in Europe. Others warn of German dominance. And the newly elected President of our most important ally recently said that the European Union was nothing more than “a means to an end for Germany”. I want to say: That is at least a misunderstanding! Europe's strength cannot be based on the leadership of individuals, but only on the responsibility of all. As the largest and most populous state, Germany naturally bears a special responsibility. But we know about our possibilities, also about their limits. And we will not forget that others in Europe might be right when we argue about solutions. We know what we owe to this Europe. I say: The united Europe is the successful answer to our history and our geography - for ourselves and for our neighbors. And we feel that a strong Europe is not only in our own interest, but that it has become part of our identity. You should therefore know that we Germans want to hold the European Union together. We want to build on the common future in Europe, together with our partners, large and small, with equal rights and obligations. In the end, however, there is something completely different and perhaps something much more important beyond all state reasons: Europe is a matter close to the heart not for everyone, but for most of the people in Germany. That is why I told you my own story of Europe. And that's why a lot of people, especially young people in Germany, have told me their stories about Europe in the past few weeks. The young - I've learned that - are fed up with only those who talk badly about Europe. They don't want their hopes and their future to be stolen from them by populists or lost through lethargy. That's why they went out and are now showing on the streets that the The pulse of Europe still beats on the streets and squares in almost all European capitals and larger cities! (Applause) Even if we in my generation don't call it that yet - for many of our children and grandchildren Europe has long become a second fatherland! These boys have long known that loving your own country and being a good European at the same time is not a contradiction in terms. And I think the boys are right about that! (Applause) Last year I went to Wroclaw privately with my family. I wanted to explore the hometown of my mother, which I knew mainly from her dark memories. She told me about her experiences of war and devastation, of fleeing to the West with her mother, aunt, sisters and their children - seven women in total. The unleashed nationalism and its consequences had overshadowed her young life and in this way also shaped my image of this city, of Breslau. But last year, 2016, I came to a completely different city: a city that shone as the European Capital of Culture, with lively and intelligent discussions everywhere, with music on the streets and squares, where young people from Vilnius, Wuppertal and Verona share their Europe have celebrated. There was nothing faint-hearted! There he lived again, the dream of the European future! Honorable Members, it is now up to us to ensure that the European dream is not over for the next generation either. That is the message that I bring from my country. Yes, we want Europe, we want to build a better Europe, and we want to be a European Germany. (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I want to thank the President of the Federal Republic of Germany once again for accepting Parliament's invitation to make a speech which will certainly stimulate debate in this House in the coming weeks as well.This Europe certainly needs to be corrected, it needs to be changed, but I believe that the positive, trusting message that President Steinmeier has addressed must be held in high regard.Thanks again for accepting our invitation.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I will be very quick as I know everyone wants to get on with the voting. Under Rule 59(4), I would like to request to refer this matter back to the committee responsible in order that we can begin interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom tagairt do reachtaíocht uimhir 2 ansan. Sílim go bhfuil sé scannalach go bhfuilimid ag úsáid an fhocail “Mompreneur” agus tá sé scannalach agus náireach ar bhonn mná, tá sé scannalach agus náireach ar bhonn cothrom inscne. Agus ní dócha sa tigh seo gur chóir go mbeimis ag cur teachtaireacht mar sin chun cinn, a rá gurb é seo an tslí bhfuilimid ag tabhairt aghaidh ar ár mná. Mar sin, ceapaim gur chóir an focal sin a thógaint amach as an reachtaíocht.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We take note of your comment and we will ask the language services to the look at the issue.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We are now going to have our explanations of vote, so I would ask you to clear the Chamber.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today I voted in favor of this report because it is appropriate, for reasons of clarity, to recast the regulation defining the characteristics of fishing vessels. It is essential to codify all regulations from 1986 to today, with the aim of simplifying this rule and making it more understandable and accessible to operators in the fishing sector and citizens of the European Union. I regret that the Council did not consider it appropriate to protect small-scale artisanal fishing by keeping it distinct from industrial fishing. In fact, a legal definition is needed as regards the characteristics of large-scale fishing and artisanal fishing, in order to distinguish them from a legal point of view. This definition, which unfortunately is not present in the regulation in question, should include, in addition to the size of the boat, attributes such as the length of the vessels, the variables relating to their range of action, their social role in coastal communities, ecological impact, fishing capacity and economic data relating to the enterprise.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - It is extremely important to harmonize the legal rules in this area, including for all citizens in the European Union, and to codify this area, because certain sectors are, of course, concerned about what this will bring to fisheries policy in practice.It is true that it is a technical document, that it is in fact a recast of the 1968 document, and above all it is a very important common fisheries policy for all the countries involved in this field, and it also plays an extremely important social role;in particular, of course, environmental aspects must be taken into account, including local specificities, and of course this distinction between t.i.industrial fishing of large vessels and small-scale fishermen, for whom this is a traditional way of fishing.Above all, it is important that these rules clearly record dictations and definitions in order to avoid different interpretations then in practice.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Mister President! It is excellent that we are finally introducing mandatory efficient market surveillance. The fact that, with this legislation, vehicles can and should now be subjected to an investigation even after they have been put into service is an important step in the right direction in order to uncover fraudulent intentions in emissions measurements. I am glad that we have also succeeded in putting an end to any conflicts of interest, among other things, by strengthening the independence of the national type approval authorities from the automotive industry. However, I am strictly against a new EU authority, and not just because I fear additional bureaucracy. We have to get out of the reflex to see the solution to every problem in the creation of a new agency, instead of using the existing structures and making existing structures more efficient. Let us strengthen the European Commission by giving it the power to carry out the relevant supervisory activities.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Therefore, if the existing institutions were to function, the dieselgate affair would not have taken place.And also to the fact that, of course, this is not an isolated case, but obviously the car industry also has a very strong role to play in ensuring that control is not exercised.The EMIS committee of inquiry, which was set up to clarify this in the European Parliament, also said this: that supervisory authorities at national level are not doing their job, which, of course, puts the interests of the car industry before the interests of their citizens.Therefore, it seems to me inadmissible that we did not vote today on these amendments, which would also enable the introduction of t.i.authority at the level of the European Union, and I think that we will regret such a decision in the future and, of course, we will not prevent new scandals and new consumer misleading.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report because I believe that it is an adequate response to the defense of the internal market and consumer rights, allowing vehicles, including those already in circulation, to comply with safety requirements and environment. The unprecedented scandal over the handling of tests on car emissions revealed flaws in the approval system for new cars. We cannot be deceived. This situation has weakened citizens' confidence in the European institutions and the automotive industry. After more than a year of intense work, we now come to the moment of discussing and voting on this important report so that this scandal does not happen again. The rationalization and strengthening of competences in the field of car emissions, greater European supervision by the competent national authorities, the creation of vehicle type-approval procedures and tests, the existence of tighter market controls and a strict exchange of information between European Union and the Member States, and a system of dissuasive sanctions, will allow for more effective results in the defense of consumer rights. The successful implementation and enforcement of legislation on car emissions depends on the committed involvement of European institutions, economic agents and, in particular, the car industry and citizens.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, palm oil is a raw material that is used not only in the production of biofuels but also in the food industry. According to expert estimates, about 50% of all foods in the European Union contain palm oil. Unfortunately, in my country Bulgaria for the last few years there has been an increase in the import of palm oil, which presupposes a wider use of the product in the various sectors. Tempted by the lower value of palm oil-based foods, lower-income consumers fall victim to this substitution, such as real dairy ingredients with plant-based ones. Thus, the danger of deteriorating health increases, and hence the burdens, both for the consumer himself and for the state through the national budget. In the name of the public health of the Bulgarians, I call on the Bulgarian Food Safety Agency to take quick steps to ban the use of the raw material in the food industry.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the jungles of Sumatra and Borneo in Indonesia weep over the destruction to which they are subjected. Two million hectares of forest are lost each year, the irreplaceable habitat for many animal species such as the great apes of Borneo. Unsustainable production for an uncontrolled market, where transnational companies act uncontrollably, setting the forest on fire and then installing illegal palm oil plantations. And the European Union is no stranger to this reality: we are the second largest consumer of palm oil in the world. That is why we have supported this report that urges the European Commission to act, to abandon the use of vegetable oils by 2020 and to increase control of imported palm oil, to finally increase the traceability of these products. It is time for these institutions to protect the planet and its people and to control corporate power and enforce human rights in all corners of the planet.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President!We voted in favor of a report trying to address the problem of the ecological disaster of the 21st century, poisoning people and diseases in Indonesia, Borneo, Sumatra and surrounding areas, destroying animals from deforestation and burning tropical forests for palm oil cultivation, which is unfortunately not the best, butthe cheapest version of vegetable oils used in the production of oil, in the wood, food and cosmetics industries.According to the UN, up to 98% of rainforests will be destroyed by 2020.This will lead to environmental pollution, in which we indirectly participate, as 46% of palm oil is imported to the European Union.Despite the previous attempts to regulate, the greed of companies leads to the use of uncertified oil, which, apart from the negative impact of palm oil on health, also contributes to an increase in the amount of carbon dioxide and climate change.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Amnesty International has denounced how the world's leading brands of food and household products containing palm oil are responsible for serious human rights violations in a sector where children as young as eight work in dangerous conditions and where discrimination against women employed on a day-to-day basis without guarantees of permanent employment and social benefits such as health and personal insurance is ascertained. This situation is particularly serious considering that a large part of this product is obtained in Indonesian plantations belonging to the world's largest oil palm farmer, the agribusiness giant Wilmar, from which 8 of the largest multinational palm oil users are supplied. , which in turn are part of the RSPO certification circuit. That's right: while on the one hand the major companies in the world reassure consumers to make ethical choices by purchasing products that declare the use of sustainable palm oil, on the other hand they continue to close their eyes to the exploitation of millions of workers in their own supply chains. This is why the report, to which I voted in favor, finally calls for multinationals to be more transparent about what their products contain, stating where the raw materials contained in the products found on supermarket shelves come from.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!We are talking about a topic that is multidimensional: it concerns the specificity of the economy, social matters, energy and health, but the most touching is the ecological aspect.It is about the industrial use of palm oil, very often to the detriment of human health, equally often disregarding the labor rights of people employed in plantations, as well as using child labor and causing deforestation in countries where palm oil is grown.Undoubtedly, the European Union should put pressure on the countries we cooperate with to apply national and international regulations in this area, striving to eliminate this harmfulness.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, the production of palm oil has resulted in deforestation across Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Malaysia and parts of Africa. It is directly responsible for huge swathes of destruction to natural habitats, flora and fauna. It is also completely out of control, with corporates using it in everyday items such as shampoo and doughnuts, and it is now even being proposed for use in United Kingdom banknotes. To take global action on the production of palm oil and mitigate the environmental consequences, it is vital that international commitments are honoured, in particular the United Nations Forum on Forests, the United Nations Convention on Biological Biodiversity, the New York Declaration on Forests and the Sustainable Development Goal to halt deforestation by 2020. The United Kingdom has a record of doing, not just saying, and with Brexit I trust this will set an international example for the remaining 27 Member States.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: –  Madam President, while illegal logging in my country still represents an immense problem and an issue of national security, I am glad to see that the EU in general is becoming more and more self-aware of its ecological footprint.  However, our internal impact on nature is no less important than the one which our consumption habits and policies have externally. As the second biggest palm oil importer in the world, we are largely contributing to massive deforestation of rainforests that leads to wildfires and biodiversity loss; and, moreover, we are endangering the lives of indigenous people.  I welcome the call in the report for the establishment of strong standards for sustainable palm oil production. Our priority should not only concern bilateral relations with producing countries, but should also be to help create a strong international consensus in this field involving clear, transparent and enforceable regulations.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the precious tropical ecosystems, which cover around 7% of the earth's surface, are under increasing pressure from deforestation. About half of the area of ​​illegally cleared forests is used for the production of palm oil destined for the European market, which represents the third largest market in the world. In the report we approved today, the European Parliament calls for the introduction of minimum sustainability criteria for palm oil and the adoption of a binding regulatory framework to ensure that all supply chains of importers of basic agricultural products are traceable up to the origin of the raw material. The report highlights the need to replace the existing voluntary certification schemes, some of which have revealed limitations, with a single certification system to ensure that only sustainably produced palm oil can enter the EU market. For these reasons I decided to cast my vote in favor.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, until two years ago, in Spain there was no awareness about the omnipresence of palm oil in our diet, but the truth is that the obligation to indicate on the labels the type of vegetable oil that is used as an ingredient has allowed make a little revolution. This week, the large distribution food chains in my country —Alcampo, Eroski, Mercadona, Lidl— announced the withdrawal of their shelves of products made with palm oil. Social pressure is increasing because people want to protect the environment and also want to know what they eat. Both, the environment and the right to food, go hand in hand. The public knows this and is telling us and demanding that we take notice. But taking note is not patching. The objective of this report is the elimination of palm oil in biofuels by 2020. That is why we have supported it, because it is a beginning to begin to combat the paradoxes of the fight against climate change. But we understand that we have to go much further: we must rethink the global food distribution system. Otherwise, we will continue to patch up one of the greatest challenges facing humanity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the report because it is complete and well-documented. Illegal conversion of rainforests to commercial agriculture is estimated to produce huge amounts of carbon dioxide, accounting for 25% of the European Union's annual fossil fuel emissions. Fires in Indonesia are usually due to land clearing for palm oil plantations, while from the 1970s to the present, 90% of the increase in palm oil production is concentrated in Indonesia and Malaysia. The situation with deforestation, land grabbing, violation of the rights of indigenous communities is now becoming critical and dangerous, with further damage to the environment. The European Union must therefore take steps to phase out, by 2020, the use of vegetable oils, in particular palm oil, as a biofuel component, in order to drastically reduce deforestation and protect the environment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Research shows that around one million hectares in the tropics are used for the production of palm oil imported into the EU.And can you imagine what that means for ecosystems?Tropical ecosystems, especially rainforests, are being destroyed, surfaces and groundwater are disappearing, forest fires are occurring and these changes are not only affecting ecosystems, they can also have a tragic impact on local populations, whose survival is closely linked to these ecosystems.which, of course, also means greater migration in the long run.In fact, it is important to pay more attention to this area, so of course I welcome this resolution adopted today and, of course, I also welcome the phasing out of biofuels and industrial oils by 2002. Of course, we must not close our eyes to labor exploitation.forces on these plantations.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report because this is the time for the European Union to promote an action plan against deforestation and forest degradation. Public calamities are occurring all over the world due to intense rains and landslides, affecting the poorest and most vulnerable, and the cause is always the same: the intensive destruction of forest habitats through constant deforestation for agricultural exploitation and for the construction of infrastructure such as dikes or dams. Despite the European Union's commitments to reduce gross tropical deforestation by 50% by 2020, we are a long way from that goal. Between 1990 and 2008 Europe imported and consumed around nine million hectares of deforested land, making it the third largest market for palm oil. Palm oil is increasingly being used as biofuel and a substantial part of its production does not respect human rights, using child labor. The European Union must therefore assume its responsibilities and fulfill international commitments. With the approval of this report, the European Union has objective conditions to urgently take the measures and actions in order to allow, by 2020, the totality of palm oil consumed in Europe to be sustainable.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Resolution, which talks about the extraction of palm oil and burning or.deforestation, I supported, as it draws attention primarily to the environmental aspect.Because deforestation has a very large impact on biodiversity, an impact on greenhouse gases through combustion, and we need to be aware that Indonesia and Malaysia have already cleared as many forests for these purposes as there are forests in Austria.That is to say, it is a large scale, and it is right to point this out.On the other hand, there is a negative impact on people, on the natives, because in this part it is primarily the business of large companies.This is not a business to be done by small farmers, but it is primarily about exploiting labor.Europe has its share of responsibility, because we are large importers of palm oil, and therefore it is necessary to work on transparency, control, certification of this production and ultimately decide to import only palm oil that is produced in a sustainable way.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: –  Madam President, the role of women in society has changed considerably across the EU.  Today women are making important contributions to the EU agriculture sector. However, this contribution has always been underestimated and that is still the case. The huge inequalities that still exist between men and women cannot be excused. Today, only 29% of farms in Europe are run by women. The lack of ownership and control over land affects women negatively in terms of economic dependence. Women farmers want nothing more than appropriate representation. That is why it is important to support equal opportunities, better access to education, vocational training and new skills to develop entrepreneurial initiatives.  I welcome this report, which sends a strong signal to aim for gender equality. Women have huge potential to make agriculture a more dynamic, innovative and more profitable sector if they receive proper support.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President!Although the report offers a number of solutions, I voted against because of the heavy interference in the field of social policy and employment.While I am in favor of equality for women, I believe that introducing a gender dimension and even female partnerships into the common agricultural policy will not rebuild family farms, which were eliminated by a previous policy that led to farmers' flight and unemployment.Even such multifaceted reports, which also contain controversial and ambiguous terms such as green jobs, promoting full equality between women and men in rural areas, gender neutrality of all occupations, calling for a break with the traditional division of tasks in agriculture, especially in Poland, do not counteract this,where, according to the constitution, a family farm is the basis of the agricultural system of the Republic of Poland.Similarly, it is ambiguous to promote equal access to land.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: - (FI) Mr President, the economic structure of the countryside has been changing for a long time.More and more farms are diversifying, and new sources of income are being sought alongside agriculture and forestry.Creating and maintaining jobs in rural areas is absolutely vital to maintaining a vibrant countryside.The courage and entrepreneurship of women is needed to keep the countryside alive and attractive.With the restructuring of the countryside, many families and women have had to rethink their way of life.The EU Structural Funds must also support women's entrepreneurship and small-scale entrepreneurship much more than at present, so that the countryside will provide employment opportunities for men and women in the future.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!The issues of equality between men and women, and especially the promotion of women in their role in modern society in Europe, are looking much better in most countries than they used to be.Progress has undoubtedly been made here.But still, in most areas, women are still treated differently, unequally to men.That is why I supported this resolution and all previous documents on equality between men and women, and I intend to support it in the future.In this case, when we talk about the special situation of women in rural areas, in small towns, we must remember that these inequalities are greater than in large centers, in large cities.All the more I voted for this document.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Madam President, when we talk about the pay gap or the glass ceiling, we think of offices, large companies and cities, but the inequality is even deeper in rural areas. There, women suffer multiplied discrimination: in their decision-making capacity, in their remuneration and in the recognition of their contribution and ownership. I met Maribel Sánchez Vadillo the day she took the first flight of her life. She came to Brussels to collect an award for her verata goat exploitation in Candeleda (Spain). Maribel is an example of what women can achieve in a traditionally masculine world: success, recognition, and ownership of her business. I ask the Spanish and European authorities to guarantee full access for women to the ownership and management of farms and farms. Women transform entire communities when they participate fully in the economy, especially in the agricultural sector, and multiply the benefits for all of society exponentially.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Madam President, I also wanted to make an explanation of vote in this report, which seems to me a step forward.It is only an initiative report, but it is good that we give visibility to rural women.Women in rural areas have particular difficulties.A good number of them are collected here, but I wanted to highlight especially that role of invisibility that they have, especially in the capacity for work.We are seeing how in these rural areas, 50% of the population are women.However, 40% of women are unemployed.What's going on?That many of them do not even register or even register in unemployment systems.Therefore, there is a double invisibility: their lower contribution to the labor system —which then leads them to have fewer rights when it comes to a pension— and their lack of recognition in the role of agricultural activity.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, rural areas represent 93% of the territory in the EU and 20% of the population live in predominantly rural areas. These regions have a lower level of socio-economic development than urban areas. People living in rural areas are more likely to be exposed to poverty and exclusion, and the risk is generally higher for women than for men. These problems are of greater significance in some Member States with a high level of overall poverty, where the poverty gap between rural and urban areas is even wider, as is the case in Romania, Bulgaria or Malta, where it is more than 20 percentage points. The issues discussed in the report have great relevance, especially because any improvement in the situation of women living in rural areas would have a correspondingly high impact on the living standards of women and people in general in the EU as a whole.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, the role of women in rural areas is often underestimated. For this reason, I supported the report and the calls in it. Women have a very important role to play in preserving cultural and culinary traditions in rural areas. Preserving these traditions can contribute to building and strengthening regional identity in rural areas, which in turn helps to develop local livelihoods and tourism. In this connection, I would like to emphasize the role of European quality schemes, and in particular geographical indication schemes, through which traditional and local products can be protected. In many cases, these products might not be part of our living culinary heritage if it were not for the spirit of women who have passed on knowledge through the generations. As a socialist, I believe that equality between men and women must be guaranteed. Rural areas must once again become a decent place to live, where young people, including women, can find livelihoods and livelihoods, and the elderly must welcome and live their old days there with dignity.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, the common agricultural policy has historically turned its back on the crucial role of women. For example, in Spain it is difficult to find a single line in rural development plans that specifically addresses the situation of invisibility and gender inequality in rural areas, much less in the agricultural and livestock sector. It is time for the PAC to put on the purple glasses, the purple glasses, because they are the ones that sustained and sustain the rural world, the ones who worked the hardest, the ones who fed us, took care of everything and everyone. They, the ones who never had time for themselves, are the great forgotten. One of these women said recently in a newspaper in my country that “the rural environment is dying, every year a piece of the space I inhabit dies; and he dies because we are all killing him ». The future of the rural world depends on policies that put women at the center. Let's not forget that leaving the field is above all a female exodus. Therefore, guaranteeing that they stay is guaranteeing tomorrow. Let's put on the purple glasses also to look at the field and, above all, let's put on the purple glasses to look at the primary sector.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I personally supported this report, even though I have a big problem with subsidiarity.Personally, I think that this report does not belong to the plenary of the European Parliament, but in a way we can also say that it can help to open this issue in many Member States.I personally come from a small village and I know the role of women and how difficult it is for women to live in the village.That is why I respect women who remain in the village environment in a huge way.A lot of the urban population thinks, and here, I think, little has been said that the people in the village are stupid, and then they are surprised at how the people in the village vote.Because the people of the village may not have so much education and so much experience, but they have hearts and I think that is very often forgotten in the European Parliament as well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the report because it is complete and well-documented. Women in rural areas play a key role in the development of agriculture and animal husbandry. Despite the European Union's rhetoric about the so-called development dimension of the Common Agricultural Policy, the poverty and underdevelopment of rural areas in the south of Europe prove the failure of the European Union in this area as well. After all, it is characteristic that in recent years millions of agricultural holdings have disappeared, leading to crisis and unemployment in rural areas, with the main victims being women farmers. Especially in Greece, the agricultural memorandum of the troika and the creditors dramatically worsens and further degrades the position of the Greek peasant woman. Therefore, as I said here yesterday in my speech, drastic measures must be taken in favor of the peasant woman in order to strengthen her pension, to support women's entrepreneurship, for further education and training and for the creation of specialized women's cooperatives.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - (do not hear the speaker because he does not have the microphone on) ... good news for women facing problems in rural areas. I thank Mrs Petir and the rapporteurs who have done a good job on it. Rural communities really show us the power of families working together and using their entrepreneurial skills to build their own businesses, which are often passed down from generation to generation, which would not be possible without the unique, irreplaceable contribution and contribution of wives, mothers and daughters. However, their good and hard work is often forgotten, so I am glad that this report can focus on the specific needs of these women. However, I could not vote in favor of this report, for a serious reason. It again calls for the signing and ratification of the controversial Istanbul Convention. This convention is legally flawed, it promotes gender confusion and this should upset anyone who wants to highlight the true femininity of women. The European Union must find a better instrument to protect women from violence and reject the Istanbul Convention, and not put pressure on it to be adopted as a whole without the consent of all the Member States, as it has not 22 ratified it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - I really consider the report on women in rural areas by Mrs Rodriguez and Mrs Petir to be very good.It contains many good, concrete proposals that would undoubtedly improve the position of women living in rural areas.Unfortunately, I had to abstain in the final vote.The report cites the Treaties and the European Charter untruthfully, and at the same time two unacceptable demands have been made on the text in committee: that the Member States accede to the Istanbul Convention and that the Commission prepare a proposal for a directive on violence against women.I consider violence against women to be intolerable.However, the adoption of the Istanbul Convention, which introduces a meaningless gender ideology, is fully within the competence of the Member States.And the EU does not need a new directive, it is important that the Member States comply with the European treaties and their own laws.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Madam President, the dieselgate is the symbol of what we could call 'the European plot'. For two years, the European Commission knew that vehicle emissions tests were being tampered with and did nothing, as if the pufo would solve itself. In fact, the former industrial policy commissioner, Antonio Tajani, was aware of it, but instead of sanctioning him, the European People's Party has awarded him the post of president of this very Chamber. Dieselgate is not only a deception to consumers but, due to pollution, it is also a very serious public health problem and a threat to climate change. Despite this, both the European Commission and the Member States decided not to act, to stick their heads in a hole. Why? Because revolving doors keep revolving around Commission members, lobbyists, and auto companies. This network of interests endangers health and endangers democracy itself.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, I welcome these recommendations made by Parliament following the inquiry into the Dieselgate scandal. The people I represent are horrified that car manufacturers have been cheating on emissions tests, and they demand strong action from the European Parliament to stand up to this corporate abuse of power. I am disappointed that the Green proposal for an independent agency to regulate and monitor emissions was not passed. Such a body is essential to safeguard the health of the people in south-west England. Air pollution is responsible for 40 000 deaths a year in the UK and 300 every year in the city of Bristol, and the issue has not been taken seriously enough.  During this process, we have witnessed the power of the car industry lobby and sadly we have seen conservative forces in this Parliament working with them to water down the protections that citizens need. While this report represents a step in the right direction, we need to put citizens and their health first and demand that car manufacturers do not cheat the tests and cheat people of their health and their future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the report because it is complete and well-documented. At the moment when Schäuble is waving his finger in Greece and asking my country to take additional tough memorandum measures to supposedly improve the competitiveness of the country's economy, the Volkswagen scandal proves, once again, that the famous German competitiveness is almost entirely due to the kickbacks and illegal and dirty practices they use to deceive auditors and consumers. In addition, investigations into the car industry in other Member States have shown that there have been misconduct and circumvention methods by other manufacturers. The European Union must take immediate action, carrying out strict controls on the cars of all companies, throughout Europe, to protect the environment, health and consumers themselves.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Madam President, eighteen months after the Dieselgate scandal came to light on the other side of the Atlantic and fifteen months after the establishment of our committee of inquiry, consumer associations in the Member States are maintaining pressure on manufacturers. In Belgium, 10,300 customers have joined in a collective action to denounce a deception on the sale and we understand them. Just look at the efficiency of this system in the United States, where Volkswagen has pledged more than $ 23 billion to its customers to settle the lawsuits. As of today, 475,000 American customers have already received their compensation. All this to say that I regret the timid and mixed signal sent this afternoon by our Parliament. We have declared ourselves in favor of the principle of this collective action for injured consumers, but we have refused its formal establishment and its implementation at European level. Madam President, I will say that this is not how we are going to re-knit trust.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  Madam President, along with my colleagues in the EPP Group, I welcome the findings of this report which sought to explore the actual implementation of Union law in the automotive sector. The findings of this report proved both unacceptable and disappointing. Nonetheless, I appreciate the initiative and dedication evidenced by the Committee of Inquiry in their thorough investigation of the contraventions and maladministration in this area. A range of discrepancies, as well as their negative impact on the attainment of our air quality objectives, were duly identified.  However, I believe that the findings of this report provide us with an opportunity to re-evaluate and improve upon the existing EU framework on emission measurements. Enhanced regulation and discipline will therefore provide the keystone for future procedures. This is an issue of huge importance and so we must act strongly on any manufacturer that cheats the system and harms our citizens in this way. We simply cannot have another Volkswagen scandal and the impacts on climate and public health are too great not to take decisive action.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the state of play of the second review of the economic adjustment program for Greece.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, as you have already highlighted, you have added the topic ‘State of play of the second review of the economic adjustment programme for Greece’ to today’s agenda and you will appreciate that I will limit my intervention on this process. In line with the European legal framework, the institutions, that is the Commission, the ECB, the ESM and IMF, are entrusted with the design and monitoring of adjustment programmes. This also includes negotiations of updated policy conditionality with the national authorities.  The Eurogroup is regularly informed of the state of play of the adjustment programme by the institutions and also the authorities, and on occasion the Eurogroup provides political guidance on open issues. The second review of the Greece programme is on the agenda of the next Eurogroup meeting later this week on 7 April. The Council is not intervening in ongoing programme reviews and I can confirm that it has not discussed the issue at hand either in March or at earlier meetings. The Commission is also, I think, much better placed to provide you with the information on the subject than I am, and I see that Commissioner Moscovici is here and he will address you just after me. The Commission informing the European Parliament is also in line with the EU provisions, the two-pack provisions, on adjustment programmes. So for now I thank you very much and I will listen with great attention to the interventions by the honourable Members and by Commissioner Moscovici.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, it is with pleasure that I am with you today to discuss the second review of the Greek program. Let's start with the situation of the Greek economy, which has shown resilience in the face of the turbulence of 2015 and 2016 as well as the effects of capital controls. As early as 2016, positive trends emerged, including the return, which surprised us, of positive growth faster than expected for some quarters and the fall in unemployment, which was at an absolutely unacceptable level and which remains much too high. Today, however, this positive development - it must be admitted - is starting to slip. Why exactly do we observe this hesitation? Because we are closing the review late. What I have observed from my own responsibility is that there is a very close link between the return of growth in Greece and success in the negotiations. When negotiations advance, growth and confidence pick up. When trading is slow, then growth waits, as do investors. All of Greece's partners must therefore now come together to put an end to this harmful uncertainty and to finally create a lasting cycle of virtuous recovery. Greece deserves it. Its authorities, government and parliament have made considerable progress since the launch of the current program. The progress which has been made over the past eighteen months must be sustained and consolidated to ensure what the country and the euro area need, namely a sustainable recovery. We remain convinced that following substantial reforms and forthcoming implementation efforts, the Greek economy, which is very flexible, very creative and very responsive, is able to move on. But it must be helped and must not be hampered further by uncertainty. For its part, as the Minister recalled, the Commission is doing everything in its power and falls within its role, in a way, of honest broker to achieve a fair and balanced agreement, which we want quickly. Why is this agreement possible? First, because the budgetary targets have largely been achieved. I repeat here that the 2016 primary surplus target, which was 0.5% under the program, was significantly exceeded. Eurostat will release the result at the end of April, but we expect the primary surplus to be simply over 3%. Greece is also on track to meet its target of 1.75% of GDP in 2017 and 3.5% in 2018. These results are not surprising. They are the product of a series of extremely tough fiscal consolidations that include high-quality parametric measures adopted in 2015 and 2016, with a cumulative fiscal return of 4.5 percent of GDP, a hefty figure. Which European country has experienced such an adjustment? Whatever political preferences - and the Commission has no political preferences - such efforts must not be forgotten or ignored, but they must be anchored, deepened and continued. Regarding the reform program, the authorities have already implemented much of what was required. I will cite a few examples that do not always receive the attention they deserve: Greece has for the first time equipped itself with a national social security net that will guarantee a subsistence or basic income as well as strengthen education and vocational training in these times of high unemployment. Finally, an independent authority for public revenue has been created. Greece needed it with, among other things, the objective of improving revenue collection. Legislation to reduce non-performing loans has been passed and we are now moving to implementation. A new privatization and investment fund, the HCAP, is now operational and its supervisory and management boards have already begun to discharge their responsibilities. It follows, of course, that significant progress has already been made in major privatization projects. I encourage the Greek authorities to maintain this momentum which is essential to attract the investment and private investors that Greece needs. Finally, I will mention the various measures adopted in the areas of product markets, the business environment or the legal system. All of these examples are, in fact, only a small part of the roughly 200 steps that have been taken since the program began in the summer of 2015. The first months of this year have been spent negotiating two critical elements. The first concerns the measures necessary to terminate the second review. In this regard, the main outstanding issues are known. The first is labor market reform, an issue of great importance for many of you and also of great importance for the Commission. It is essential that the Greek labor market takes into account the difficulties on the employment front, but also the current economic challenges specific to the country, so that the reforms can support the recovery as well as the creation of jobs. I would like to say that the Commission, attached to the European social model, continues to support collective bargaining systems which are fair and efficient. For its part, Greece should respect European best practices in areas such as collective dismissals and trade union action. In this regard, we take into account the work of the group of independent experts tasked with formulating recommendations in the light of European and international best practices. We also know that not all of them had support unanimous. From experience, I believe that what matters most is not necessarily how the system works on paper, but how it works in life, i.e. how the social partners take ownership and engage. jointly, autonomously and in collaboration with public authorities. The second major topic of negotiation relates to the energy market. In this sector, it is important to increase competition taking into account European rules and also, of course, recent court decisions. A more competitive and efficient market is in the interests of all consumers. I believe that with some technical adjustments we should be able to quickly agree on the necessary reform elements which are good for all and, first and foremost, for the Greek economy. In recent weeks, another element of discussion has focused on a budget arrangement that would allow the International Monetary Fund to participate with its own agenda. I know that for many of you, for the Commission and for the Member States, the participation of the International Monetary Fund is really a major guarantee of security. This is an essential condition. What is unprecedented is that this device would take effect in the years immediately following the end of the program. So we are thinking not about what will happen by the end of 2018, but in the years immediately after 2018, without asking for a primary effort for too long, because it is neither viable nor democratic. The aim must be to achieve a balanced package, which will ensure that Greece meets this primary surplus target in the medium term. This concept was repeated at Eurogroup meetings in February and March. It has served and still serves as a basis for the discussions of the last few weeks which must be concluded very soon because we have another Eurogroup meeting in Valletta in three days. Discussions are continuing. You will excuse me for leaving this chamber before the end of our debate to reach Brussels, where important meetings with the Greek authorities and the European institutions will take place this evening. However, I wanted to be in Strasbourg for your debate and then return to Brussels, which is never very easy. I would like to stress that this arrangement includes measures aimed at further rationalizing expenditure. The Commission and I welcome the progress made so far, including on issues which are necessary preconditions for the involvement of the IMF. We have already come a long way since the mandate given to the Eurogroup at the end of February. We will have the opportunity to measure it this week with ministers in Valletta. I hope that the meeting there will be a good one that will show that we are really heading towards a satisfactory conclusion. I continue to believe that a technical agreement at the level of institutions preceding and following a political agreement is not only possible, but also imperative to limit the risks of delay and avoid compromising last year's positive budget performance. . But that requires real commitment and a willingness to conclude on everyone's part, and I stress the word "all". To reach a comprehensive agreement, difficult political choices have to be made. We are aware of this. This is especially true for Greece. We are therefore counting on the constructive attitude of the other institutions concerned and I would like to say in this forum, without joking, that this also includes the International Monetary Fund, which has actively participated in all aspects of the negotiations since the creation of the MES program in 2015 and which must also do its part to understand Greece's specific difficulties. The Commission will therefore continue to support constructive discussions among all partners and promote a rapid conclusion of the review. Finally, the Commission will also continue to encourage all efforts which go in the direction of a more sustainable Greek debt. We have been signaling for some time that a more realistic primary surplus path is needed after the program ends. It is not possible to ask for years and years for levels of primary surpluses that are too high if we are to restart growth in the country and return employment. Without it, the markets will not be willing to lend at reasonable rates and Greece will continue to depend on the support of its European partners. At the end of the day, I think it's a matter of burden sharing between Greece and the Eurogroup. In short, the Commission wishes to underline the progress already made. She knows that there is still some effort to be made for the discussion to be successful. I repeat how much it is for us, and for me personally, really something which is not only desirable but possible and necessary for our economic and monetary union, for the euro area, for Greece and for the Greek people, which has suffered greatly from the crisis, which must see the light at the end of this long austerity tunnel and find its way back to growth and employment.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem is absent to hear all parties ’comments. He should have been here in the European Parliament to apologize to the people of southern Europe and if not, to resign from his post. Mr President, two messages on evaluation in Greece. Message first to the institutions: close the evaluation immediately! The devil is hidden in the details. The Greek people have made many great sacrifices. Second message to the Greek government: do not play with fire! Watch out for the accident! The policy reminds you of the Tsipra-Varoufaki policy of the summer of 2015, when we reached a step before the precipice, in the drachma, outside the euro and the eurozone, in the naughty bankruptcy. Greece today needs solidarity from abroad, consensus and seriousness at home. This is the only way out of this great protracted crisis at the lowest possible cost to the Greek people.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, time is running out and the Greek people can no longer wait. They deserve a swift and positive conclusion to the second review. We think that a positive conclusion is at hand. The implementation of structural reform, a balanced solution for the labour market which would safeguard the right of collective bargaining, and additional fiscal safeguards – and also the possibility of expansionary measures if Greece outperforms its targets, as it is currently doing – could be the basis for an agreement to put Greece on the path towards sustainable growth.  This is why the Greek Government is right to negotiate constructively in order to get an agreement: prolonging the uncertainty would have negative consequences for the economy, and it would be a terrible mistake to throw away the positive results that have been achieved so far. But the IMF and some Member States should not abuse this situation and should also do their part in order to achieve a positive result. In particular they should not play with fire. I want to be very clear: given the sense of responsibility shown by the Greek Government and given the significant concessions agreed in order to have the IMF on board, to insist on asking for an unsustainable additional fiscal effort to be concentrated in a single year after the end of the programme would be irresponsible and unacceptable. I would even say that it would be shameful. Finally, creditors should recognise that the primary surplus of 3.5% is achievable, but it is sustainable only for a very short time. This clear recognition is necessary in order to give credibility to the commitment made by the Eurogroup in May 2016 to implementing medium—term debt relief measures. Those measures are necessary in order to meet the agreed benchmarks for growth financing needs in a context of social cohesion, as well as financial, economic and political stability, and should be further specified. A positive solution to the Greek crisis would be a major success for the Greek people and for the entire European Union in these difficult times. Parliament calls on all the relevant actors to take a responsible attitude in order to achieve this historic result.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Mr Moscovici, the troika wants it to be its own. Although you refuse to grant the remaining € 19.5 billion of the third loan, you still require the memorandum measures to be implemented at 100%. You must either reduce the memorandum measures by 25% or make the rest of the loan available, in order to recapitalize the insurance funds looted by the PSI with this money, to establish a special public fund for the red loans and to finance the establishment Development Bank for investments in the Greek economy and reduction of unemployment. Finally, as a troika, return the 3.5 billion euros that the ESM has encapsulated, money that belongs to Greece and concerns the return of the ECB 2014 profits from Greek bonds, in order to finance a broad development plan for creating 300,000 new jobs. Stop, Mr Moscovici, the policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment, which has turned Greece into a vast social graveyard. Stop, as a troika, pushing and demanding reduction of pensions, increase of taxes, sale of PPC and state property instead of a lentil plate. The Greek people do not tolerate humiliation and will soon give the government and the troika and Mr. Dijsselbloem, who did not dare to appear here to apologize, the answer they deserve. Because there is another way.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President! I will address some basic structural issues concerning Greece. The first structural problem concerns the budget structure. Every country that has its pension policy embedded in the state budget orders a problem. You can check with the Russian state budget, where they have made the same, in itself short-term, solution. You think that there is always money in the treasury and then you think that you can pay the pensions from that budget. When you take a look at the population pyramid for Greece, we see that soon a majority of the population will be retired, and a minority of the population will earn the money for the treasury. If people paid their taxes in Greece, this could possibly be an affordable problem. As you now pay tax in that country, this problem is not solvable. That is the first problem. The second problem concerns a mismatch between the right decisions and the lack of administration. We know that the Greek Government has made the right decisions and we know that the Greek Parliament, with some reluctance, has made the right decisions, but we still do not see, to this day, that these decisions are being realized in real life. For that reason, I belong to a minority in this House that was not terribly frightened by Dijsselbloem's statement on how to spend his money. Some of my fellow Members showed a great lack of sense of humor when, so to speak, "raised hell" on that issue. A little better discipline, a little more self-criticism, so maybe we can handle this thing.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the Greek people have made great sacrifices, made great changes and the Greek economy has made significant progress in the last year and a half, as Commissioner Moscovici acknowledged. Now, however, is the time for creditors to live up to their obligation, because the continuing delay, Commissioner, is hurting both the Greek economy and the eurozone itself. This delay is due, as the Commission's representative in Brussels said yesterday, to unreasonable last-minute demands from the International Monetary Fund and Mr Schäuble, the German Minister for Finance. There is a need for those who have a mind in their head to defend the economic and geopolitical interests of both Greece and the eurozone. This means completing the technical agreement yesterday and not tomorrow and completing the whole package of the agreement in April, Mr Moscovici, with a balanced budget package, as you said, after 2018, with sustainable debt, with realistic primary surpluses and with the return of collective bargaining in Greece, because Greece is part of Europe. Only in this way can my country and my people, but also the eurozone, benefit both economically and geopolitically. Do not forget that Greek women and men guard European borders, they are next to the factor of instability called Erdoğan and the 27 have every reason, after Brexit, to show that they are united and respect in practice, and not only in words, the sacrifices of the Greek of the people.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, on Friday we will have a Eurogroup meeting. Again and again it looks like there might not actually be real progress on the Greek programme and the Eurogroup, as we know, is led by a man who told us very clearly what he thinks about women and what he thinks about southern Member States. By his absence today he shows us also what he thinks about the European Parliament.  While he is a very big problem, he is not our only problem in that matter. The whole Eurozone, and hence also the whole future of the European Union, is being held hostage by the dogma of austerity. To believe growth will come if households are shrinking, if they have to be cut and also the state expenditure is being cut – well, that is not going to happen. That is just economic nonsense.  Extreme poverty has increased by almost seven times in the last years in Greece while state spending has been cut by more than 30%, which is the biggest reduction per capita in the whole Eurozone. While all of that is happening the IMF and also some Member States are demanding more and more cuts. They ask for further reductions in pensions, saying that the Greek pension system is too generous, but actually the truth is that Greek pensioners are much worse off than pensioners anywhere else in Europe. In Greece 43% of pensioners live on less than EUR 660 per month, making those who worked hard for their whole life extremely vulnerable to poverty and to social exclusion. The whole future of Europe is also being held hostage by some Member States who think they can win elections by causing hardship elsewhere, and that should not happen. Labour rights, social rights and EU law are applicable everywhere in the European Union and by telling Greece that it should not apply collective bargaining we are imposing an arbitrary deviation from that European social model.
