While we are saying the whole time that Greece should follow European rules, what we are actually telling them to do is abandon those very rules and that is just schizophrenic. If we truly want recovery in Greece, if we truly want to work together for a common future we cannot allow Greece to be made into an experimental ground for zero labour rights. And sure, to overcome the dogma of austerity, to invest in a sustainable economy, to carry out intelligent reforms and to get real on debt relief, that might not be popular in every single Member State. It actually takes courage to argue that we are all going to benefit from this in the long term, that we should invest in our common good rather than cutting the ground from under our feet, to show solidarity instead of contempt. But this courage is necessary if we want to build our common future.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I wanted to say that I would have liked to talk about this program for Greece with Eurogroup President Dijsselbloem, who apparently has taken the legacy of his predecessor Juncker very well: both are leading in fact, of two tax havens that on the one hand encourage the tax avoidance of large multinationals and on the other dictate, have dictated - Juncker before and Dijsselbloem today - the programs to Greece, programs that serve to repay the debts that this country has taken , but this country has to pay very large interest on these unsustainable debts, and I don't think there are such sustainable measures in the program. Let's talk about pension cuts - and we are on the thirteenth cut in five years, tell me if this is sustainable . Let's talk about lowering the threshold for tax exemption for minimum incomes: we harass even more those who are poor! And the privatization, now, of the energy company, after ports and airports. This is the usual troika bankruptcy recipe, it is an arrangement that does not work. As long as it is not seriously questioned, as long as people like Dijsselbloem and Juncker rule the European institutions, we will never get out of this crisis, the eurozone will never get out of this crisis. So we strongly demand the resignation of this character who has insulted the countries of the South and women, and we want these things to be debated more heatedly, because it is not possible not to talk about the problems of the eurozone, the euro and economic governance. .

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after so many lies that have been heard about Greece, not only today but in recent years, it is necessary to re-establish some truth about this disastrous approach orchestrated by the institutions of the European Union, which in the name of euro have knowingly destroyed a country. We are here to take stock of the results of these memorandums and let's make the point. Greek industrial production fell by 30% over the period, real GDP fell by 25%, a quarter of the Greek population lives below the poverty line and the Greek population is facing one of the biggest crises ever - hardly ever lived - in its history. In 2013 the same International Monetary Fund had declared the failure of austerity policies, had declared that it had underestimated the destructive effects of austerity. But not only did none of those responsible at the time pay, neither Dijsselbloem nor Juncker resigned - indeed, some have been promoted - but the third program approach is even more austere. You made us believe that Greece's problem was the high level of public debt to GDP, and therefore that austerity was necessary. Instead it is false. From 1993 to 2007, Greece's public debt / GDP ratio was around 100%, completely constant and lower than that of countries such as Belgium and Italy, which are considered more virtuous. What was the problem? Vítor Constâncio tells us this in a speech on May 23, 2013, in which he says that the problem was not the public debt but the foreign private debt. Why what happened to the Greek citizens with the euro? With the currency risk eliminated, banks in the North poured credit into these countries by speculating on higher interest rates. Your goal was clear from the start: it was not to save Greek citizens with these programs, but to allow these banks that had speculated to recover their credits and transfer debts from private bank balance sheets to public balance sheets.This is the purpose of the bailout funds.Italy, through bilateral contributions and contributions to the two bailout funds, has contributed more than 60 billion euros of public money to save the northern banks.You have forced the Italian citizens to do this.The euro will collapse under its lies and you will be held accountable for this disaster you have caused.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, do you have the audacity to talk about evaluation, new pension cuts and new austerity measures that will bring the Greek people to their knees again? Official figures that come to light every day rank Greece among the poorest countries. We are on the list of the most unhappy citizens, we hold the European lead in suicides, the European lead in unemployment, one in two Greek children are malnourished and we sit and talk with Dijsselbloem in the Eurogroup about new cuts, abolition of labor rights and redundancies. Dijsselbloem, who refused to appear before MEPs, who, unlike his nominee, are elected by European citizens to defend the interests of their countries, but also of Europe as a whole. He dares to offend countries and peoples, with his provocative statements, but at the same time women, for whom he obviously considers to be generally issued for money. Do not be surprised, then, that Great Britain chose the exit. Continue to give Dijsselbloem the right to decide the fate of our countries and very soon other countries will follow.

name: Markus FERBER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It has now been almost exactly seven years since the then Greek Prime Minister Papandreou addressed the Europeans that the country was on the verge of insolvency. Seven years! - and yet we still have to have such debates here. That shows the real problem: In these seven years we have succeeded in taking other countries under the rescue package in order to release them back to the capital markets, and one country has not succeeded. If I have heard all the speeches so far that say: “It's everyone else's fault and the country itself isn't,” then I just don't understand, because others have managed to implement adjustment programs in less time. I am already asking myself a few questions: Why is Greece one of the few countries where shipowners are not taxed at all? Even under a communist, Mr Tsipras, that has not changed. Why is Greece a country that fails to tax its own citizens' foreign assets? All countries in the European Union can do it, the Greeks can't. Why is Greece in this position, even though it is supposedly so desperately poor that it can invest over two percent of its economic power in defense and is therefore highly regarded by Mr Trump? I ask myself the question: is it right to look better with Mr Trump than with those from whom solidarity is demanded? And that's why I say very clearly: homework has to be done here and not always just appealing to others. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Sławomir KŁOSOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!I have a question for the Commissioner and for Mrs Keller.On the one hand, I would like to ask, because I must admit that some issues ...

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Hon. Ferber, there is a question for you, do you accept it?Mr Kłosowski, please, your question.

name: Sławomir KŁOSOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Well, I have a similar question to Mr. Ferber.Economics is an exact science, so there are some issues to enumerate here.Very often in today's debate, typically social voices were heard, talking about a certain solidarity, about sympathy for the Greek nation, which is in difficulties, is in trouble because of its internal budgetary situation.In this regard, I have a question for Mr. Ferber.How do you see the practical reconciliation of these two issues: the issue of calculable economics on the one hand, and social issues on the other?

name: Markus FERBER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I do not now know which part of my speech you are referring to, because of course I do not see myself in a position to answer questions that were actually addressed to other colleagues.I just want to point out that, according to the Commission's documents, Greece alone has tax outstanding amounts of over EUR 80 billion, in other words on the order of magnitude that corresponds to the third aid package.If it were only possible to collect these tax arrears, nothing would have to be cut, nor would European donors have to continue to demand money.And that's why I say: At home things have to be done, and then there is solidarity from us.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, exactly two months ago we had the same debate in this Chamber in which you announced good forecasts and good results for Greece. We had the impression that there was no longer any reason for blocking the Council or the Eurogroup. Nothing has progressed since. The name of Mr. Dijsselbloem is sometimes mentioned in this Chamber, but we no doubt forget to quote Mr. Schäuble or their accomplices, these gentlemen and this lady from the IMF. Because, in reality, we have the impression that by dint of not wanting to create moral hazard, it is those who denounce this moral hazard who are creating it in Greece, producing here the miracle of bringing together all the Greek political class, contrary to what is happening in the country, against this austerity policy initially wanted by Mr. Schäuble for reasons, it seems to me, which have neither to do with Greece , neither with the euro zone, nor with the European Union, but simply with an electoral calendar in Germany. But I don't think the eurozone economy can be held hostage by someone playing the sorcerer's apprentice or implementing a strategy of self-fulfilling prophecy. Because how can one reproach Mr. Tsipras for reminding his partners that they have made commitments on the subject of the debt when the latter, in view of the results which are up to what was expected of his country, ask him to double setting and further aggravate the situation of retirees? Last Friday it seemed to me that everything was in order and that an agreement was possible. However, today, we see that the prospect of an agreement and a conclusion of the review of the program at the next Eurogroup, this Friday, is almost blocked. This is dangerous. We need - and we repeat - to give Greece sources of confidence. This is necessary for Greece, but also for the euro area and for the Union European, because this situation weakens the whole balance.Mr Schäuble urgently needs to stop his Eurogroup maneuvers, which are simply to import German domestic policy debates into the euro zone.(The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!Ms. Berès is an outspoken economic expert.I would like to ask you: How do you think we can manage to invest more in Greece again, to create new jobs and, above all, to make Greece more competitive so that it can export what is available at homeneeds consumption?

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: answer "blue card".- Dear colleague, that is what is at stake in the discussion which we have now had for months and, at least, since the Commission put Greece's new results on the table.How do you expect investors to want to return to this country when the program review is not complete?This means that the partners are not giving this country the necessary credit to be able to restart.All this country needs is a sign showing that those who have concluded a memorandum with Mr. Tsipras and his government to redress the situation take note of the efforts made, of the reality of the results and of theopportunity for foreign investors to reinvest in the country to restart the economy.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici! How often have I heard this here: “We are approaching the safe shore.” Now you say: The Greeks can see light at the end of the tunnel and unemployment has also fallen. It went back because people were emigrating! And you said it could be better - Greece is in its ninth year of recession! Year after year we get wrong numbers in this Parliament. I compared it: There is a difference of 4.95 percentage points between the forecasts and the actual figures. That is no longer information for Parliament, it is demagoguery of numbers! And then it is said: Yes, the primary surplus has increased. I know that, I'm a finance scientist. You just leave out expenses or stop paying bills. This is how you can reduce the deficit. It is not a way of giving a country a future! I say very clearly: It's not about Greece at all, it's about the cohesion of the euro area! I want Greece not to be sacrificed on the altar of the euro. I don't want the euro ideology to destroy Europe. I want peoples and people to be able to live in Greece again!

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, those who are calling for this assessment to be closed ostensibly for the good of Greece are essentially calling for new pension cuts, new tax-free incomes, a new sale of public property and the dissolution of labor relations. Dear colleagues, since 2010, for seven years now, the Greek people have been living in a state of constant blackmail. Lenders and the government are shifting responsibility for the failure of a program, the one described in the memoranda, that has led the Greek people to poverty and misery. Mr Moscovici, you once again told us, in essence, that if we reduce pensions in Greece, if we sell out public wealth, in this case PPC, and if we devalue our lives and the future of our children, we will recover. Instead, ladies and gentlemen, the implementation of troika and eurozone policies has resulted in huge income losses, higher unemployment in the European Union, the migration of 500,000 young scientists and an increase in public debt. The issue, dear colleagues, is not to close the second evaluation, but to enable the Greek people to resist and break with the policies of austerity and the eurozone in order to grow.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Mr President, as mentioned before, a few months ago we were having a debate, here, in which it seemed that there were good macroeconomic data, that Greece could gradually close the program and that we had a good perspective. What has happened? Well, it seems that someone has been more interested in straining the negotiations and creating problems than going to the end, among other things because they are asking Greece for things that are not even in the memorandum. Because I want to recall that in the memorandum, which was totally ignominious, there were the issue of debt and debt restructuring. Where is that on the bargaining table? We do not know. And, on the other hand, Greece began to be required to carry out labor reforms that even go against European law itself, because what is being required of it in terms of collective bargaining goes against the foundations of European law. Therefore, it seems that we are more before the interests of some people, of some international institution that wants to destabilize a government, than before people who really want to help the country move forward. Frankly - and I want to end this - that the president of the Eurogroup, after what he said the other day, did not deign to come is further proof that what he has to do is resign immediately.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - I do not think that a country whose gross domestic product fell by more than 25% a few years ago cannot be required to reach not only zero GDP in a few years' time, but also the Maastricht criteria, which, incidentally, not only Greece but and other Community countries. Requirements for Greece must be measured, sensible, the proposed reforms implemented without shock therapy for Greek society. The cartel of claims from the European Union institutions must be at a reasonable height, not only because it can be overcome by Greece, but also because Greece has been planted on the needle of the loan, not without the lack of responsibility on the part of those institutions. I would fully agree with the International Monetary Fund's contribution to the Greek financing process. And yet, in addition to the debate on reforms in Greece, there should be another debate: what proportion of the debts this country has creditors are willing to write off, despite the fact that some countries do not like it.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici! According to expert estimates, the slow evaluation of the second adjustment program is already costing the Greek economy two billion euros, against the backdrop of unemployment of over 27% and capital outflows like at the beginning of the crisis. Greece is currently experiencing a creeping bank run. In March of this year alone, 1.5 billion euros flowed abroad, in addition to the 4 billion that has flowed abroad since the beginning of the year. So, in my view, there can be no talk of a robust economy, as you said, Commissioner, and neither is the economic program and the economic data for 2017 being revised downwards. The President of the Greek central bank, Mr Stournaras, has already warned of further delays in the negotiations. He sees severe setbacks for the Greek economy and especially for the Greek banks, and he calls for structural reforms - much to the displeasure of the Greek government. And there will be no agreement on Friday at Ecofin either, Mr Dijsselbloem let us know in an interview. And the reason for this is that the Tsipras government is delaying the reform steps that were promised when the third aid package was concluded in summer 2015. According to Tsipras, all implementation commitments to the donors should be postponed until after the 2019 elections, and all internal critics such as the central bank chief should no longer express themselves politically if possible. Otherwise a fate similar to that of the former head of the Greek statistical office, Mr Georgiou, who was sentenced to eight months in prison for reporting correct statistics to Brussels, threatens. A worrying development. That is not what Greece needs. Greece needs a liberation, an economic and stability program that creates growth and jobs. The Tsipras government has up to that not presented today.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Mr President, before anything else, because this has been said in here, I would like to say that the Greek people are really laughing at the anecdote that Tsipras is a communist. Well, the troika and the SYRIZA-ANEL government are in a hurry to bring the fourth toughest memorandum, while the other parties are arguing over who brings the best memoranda. Everyone agrees: new 15th cut in pensions and salaries, taxation of the poorest to exempt the richest, mass redundancies, strike strike, privatizations. All for the recovery not of the people, but of capital. These are the best practices and the acquis of the European Union: when everyone is worried about the delay of the fourth memorandum, the workers are worried about their lives. No assignment to new saviors, just as barbaric as the previous ones. Capitalist barbarism, with or without memoranda, has no end unless it is stopped by the organized working class and the popular strata. European Union and capitalism are not humanized. So, on April 7, the day of the Eurogroup, the street workers give an answer. With the Communists at the forefront, the Communist Party of Greece is paving the way for overthrow.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: - Mr President, I believe that there is little we can do in the European Parliament to speed up the closing of the second evaluation of the third program, which was originally scheduled for February 2016, but has been delayed for 14 months. Almost everything depends on the negotiation of the Tsipras government with the ruling party, SYRIZA, which at least we do not influence. Two typical examples: the Tsipras government has signed the privatization of all public companies, including the partial privatization of the Public Electricity Company. However, he tries to delay it, because the party executives and the trade unionists who are close to SYRIZA do not accept it. Second example: the Tsipras government has accepted new large reductions in pensions, bigger than the ones it imposed in 2015 and 2016. However, it wants them not to be implemented this four years, but at the beginning of the next, when SYRIZA will be in opposition, in an attempt to create trouble for the future Mitsotakis government. I believe that the Tsipras government will ultimately contribute to closing the second evaluation. She would rather deal with a large part of SYRIZA than anger the majority of the Greek people, returning the national economy to the crisis of 2015. Besides, she has shown that she is not so much interested in the policy she implements as in staying in power. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Hon.Rübig made a reference to the regulation.Mrs, what is it about?

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: - Mister President!The colleague who spoke to Mr Kyrtsos, who has now very much praised the communist march, said that he was in favor of an overthrow in Greece.Could he perhaps explain exactly how it works with the principles of democracy?

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Rübig, this is not a reference to the regulation, it is a question to ask the speaker, it is a "blue card" question.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: question with blue card. - Mr. Kyrtsos, both you and your former colleague, Mr. Kefalogiannis, have accused the Greek government of playing with fire. Here Mr Gualtieri from the Socialist Group accused Mr Schäuble of playing with fire and Ms Keller of the Greens and other colleagues who do not belong to the Left or support the Tsipras government accused Mr Schäuble and the International Committee of the Red Cross. for delaying evaluation. So I wanted a clear answer. Do you consider the Greek government or the creditors, and in particular Mr Schäuble and the International Monetary Fund, to be responsible for the delay in the assessment?

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: answer to a question with a blue card. - The Greek government is responsible, because, no matter how difficult the situation is - because indeed both European partners and creditors, many times, have requirements that must not be met - we have a delay from February 2016, we are in April, we probably go for May and, because we have to get the installment in June, to pay in July, we probably get to the end of this series. But I think the problem is internal and you will give us the answer, not me. That is, how can Tsipras sign the privatization of DEKO and SYRIZA object? How can Tsipras accept a new reduction in pensions and have your party object? So, there's the problem. As others say, I think I know the Greek situation better than, for example, Mr. Gualtieri. It was as if I was explaining to him what the Democratic Party should do in Italy.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem's offensive language proves, in fact, that he is not up to the task of serving as president of the Eurogroup and does not make a difference in relation to Mr Schäuble's positions. No to this wrong narrative about the reasons for the eurozone crisis and not to these wrong solutions. There are national responsibilities, but above all, there are great responsibilities in the way the European Union has responded to the crisis in the eurozone and has responded to Greece's dramatic situation. Let us see the great differences between the program that is being tried to be applied in Greece and the alternative solution that Portugal, led by the socialist government, has been able to put into practice. First big difference: respect workers' social rights, their wages, and use that as a lever to increase domestic demand, while promoting exports; second: to ensure that reforms focus not only on the labor market but, above all, on education, on innovation, on better services provided to the population; third: to be able to put investment at the top of the priorities by leveraging a future for the country for a new energy and digital transition and, fourth, not to subordinate growth to fiscal consolidation, on the contrary, more growth facilitates the process of fiscal consolidation. But, above all, to ensure that the country is not limited to a subordinate position in the European discussion, assumes itself as a partner of the entire part of the reform of the eurozone, which must be conducted for us to restore the principle of convergence. This requires completing the banking union, it requires building budgetary capacity and only then will not only the eurozone have a future, but the European Union will have the future it deserves.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Commissioner Moscovici had said at the beginning that he had to leave us to go to a very important meeting, and in his place the Commission is well represented by Commissioner Andriukaitis.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: - Mr President, I am sorry that the Commissioner is not in the room now, but I will ask him as if he were here and I would like to ask him directly: what is your real goal? Because it is an insult to tell the Greek people that the continuation of the policy that reached them in a state of begging will lead to their salvation. Seven years now, with willing governments, threatening and blackmailing the Greek people, you have degraded parliamentary democracy, imposed colonial agreements for 100 years and, at the same time, dissolved society. As for the debt, from 120% in 2010 it went to 180% today, with your own rescue programs, at inconceivable heights and, admittedly, it is impossible to service. What more do you ask from the Greek people? Stop talking about crisis plans, though. Commissioner, even if you are not here, I want to tell you that your policies are producing Brexit, bringing the far right to the forefront in your home country and in the Netherlands almost bringing them into government. Tell me, what did you celebrate the day before yesterday in Rome? The European authorities being trampled on or the multi-speed Europe you are promoting? It seems that Greece at this juncture is your useful tool to consolidate the results of this crisis, which ultimately seems to serve you. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: blue-card question. –  Mr President, you will find no country happy to see an austerity programme but listening to this Greek drama where both sides are blaming each other every time, would you tell me, if you were the Prime Minister of Greece, what decisions you would take first and second? What concrete decisions would help your country come out of the economic crisis? Be pragmatic. First and second decisions.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: answer to a question with a blue card. - Mr President, my answer will be very brief. I would do what no one else did and what the European Union itself is imposing with its directive: I would control the debt from the beginning. You imposed a debt on the Greek people without having checked it, while Directive 247 requires financially controlled countries to control their debt first and then, if in the case of Greece, the Greek people really owed, to pay up to the antenna. At the moment, the Greek people are in this situation, without knowing how, when and why this debt was created and who imposed it. We know very well that the Greek people are currently paying the gamble of the banks of all peoples.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, a child is left on the steps of a church. The mother cannot afford it. A pensioner jumps from a high place, faced with a winter without winter fuel. This, honourable ladies and gentlemen, Members of this Parliament, is Greece, as created by the EU and the euro. It is not about resources, it is about debt in the wrong currency. The Greek debt is now 177% of GDP. It grows as the Greek economy shrinks so it can never, ever, be paid off. Instead, it grows larger. Edinburgh is described as the Athens of the north because of its classical architecture and its learning. Nicola Sturgeon wants to make this manifest and all too real. An independent Scotland with an SNP deficit of GBP 15 billion is bigger than that of Greece. Scotland would have to adopt the catastrophic euro and the consequent ‘austerity max’ Greece has had to suffer. I weep for the people of Greece, but Sturgeon’s desire to emulate them beggars belief and will beggar Scotland.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - The downfall here yesterday in the plenary meeting of Jeroen Dijsselbloem actually symbolizes the political basis of it, namely the downfall of the social democracy in the Netherlands a few weeks earlier during the elections. What I want to say is, it is not the task of the Social Democracy to want to keep the euro alive per se, because then it goes against its foundations and against the foundations that the population gives to democratically elected politicians. For the reform policy, as it is always euphemically referred to here, is nothing more than unifying all socio-economic spaces within the eurozone. Making it one, federalizing a state that should be the European state and of which you want to make one state instead of a European cooperation. That is not a natural state of affairs, because for that you have to do things that are not normal and certainly not for Social Democrats. You have to create poverty, you have to strangle peoples, as you have done with the Greek people, and you have to create debt, debt and more debt with the ECB at the same time, thanks to Mr Draghi. It's madness. Stop it!

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, I came here to listen to a debate about Greece and not about Scotland and Brexit. I was looking forward to hearing the opinion of the head of the Eurogroup, and it is a little unfortunate that he is not here. Still, there is a very interesting debate that is raising some concerns. When I look at the data, I can see the enormous effort made by the Greek Government and the high cost paid by the Greek people to stabilise the fiscal situation. This has been reached. Unfortunately, data on economic growth are much gloomier. After some very bad times we saw some signs of recovery that have now been replaced by much weaker data. This is really the key concern. First of all, in this situation the Greek Government should not give up on fiscal improvement and the vast effort and money it has taken to maintain the fiscal situation. It would be good if the government could explain to people that this is unfortunately the cost of the bad governance of Greece before the crisis. At the same time we should better understand what is going on in Greece and, as partners, work out the measures that will get Greece back on its feet. I am not talking about revisiting the agreements or resetting the targets, because I do not believe that the country can get out of trouble through fiscal expansion, but find a good combination of reforms and involvement of EU policy like the cohesion funds or EFSE to help Greece to recover. I guess it is feasible. We are still missing one component, and this is trust. Unfortunately the debate is supporting that.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, at the start, let me make clear that Jeroen Dijsselbloem should apologise for his remarks. These remarks ignore the fact that people have made sacrifices, and the Greeks especially have suffered and paid in terms of high unemployment and high income loss, and still the prospects are uncertain. Yet the adjustment programme for Greece continues, even if the results are not always encouraging. Indeed, the IMF is right that the required fiscal surplus is too high to be sustainable, and that the debt is unsustainable, undermining collective bargaining. Further flexibilisation of the labour market is not an answer to these problems. We need the second review to be completed, but we need more. We need politicians that face their voters and tell the truth about unsustainability. We need politicians who admit to that unsustainability for, as voters know perfectly well, you cannot get blood from stone, and let us say so.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: - Mr President, this debate summarizes in particular the worst of this European Union. An adjustment program that produced disastrous results from the economic, social and public accounts. Yes, we are talking about the case of Greece, which is not exactly a normal case, it is more obscene than normal. An ultimatum was issued to the Greek people, which was probably the lowest and most degrading point in the history of European integration. But as if authoritarianism was not enough, the European Commission decided to go further and violated its commitment to the Greek government to restructure the Greek debt. The European Commission's agreements are therefore not only bad policy agreements and documents, but also bad faith documents. But lastly, this debate shows how ridiculous we are: Mr Moscovici and Mr Borg came here to replace Mr Dijsselbloem who, in an attack of cowardice, refused to be accountable to citizens' representatives and see , we have the Commission and the Council replacing a group that does not even exist formally, which is the Eurogroup. The European Parliament has already asked Mr Dijsselbloem to resign, whether he wants Mr Dijsselbloem on the street. What are the Commission and the Council waiting for to do the same?

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Matias, I remind you that the Commission and the Council are not here to replace anyone.We have organized a different discussion than the one that was planned because President Dijsselbloem did not want to speak in the Chamber, and of course everyone knows the criticism that this has entailed.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yes, that's right, the Eurogroup is an informal body, as per the Lisbon Treaty, and it should discuss accountability. Just think: of responsibility and growth in the euro area. In fact, it has no formal obligations towards the only elected body, the European Parliament, but takes decisions that impact on fiscal, monetary and structural policies of the member states. Its president, let us remember, minister of finance of Holland - a country that encourages international tax avoidance - is guilty of unacceptable offenses against the peoples of southern Europe, and today he refuses the invitation to speak before us, defenders of all the people who shed tears and blood to respect the unsustainable rules of economic governance. Colleagues in Parliament, do you still want to believe in the goodness of the work of the troika and the ESM, which in Greece, since the beginning of the crisis, have provided well over two thirds of the aid to pay off the same debt contracted with the international banking system and with European financial institutions? This is not the way to build a Europe of solidarity with citizens. Do not accuse us of being populists when we point out these anomalies. Fighting for transparency, for democracy, fighting for a more central Parliament in decisions that impact the lives of 500 million European citizens is not populism, gentlemen. This is called responsibility. This is called will.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - Greece has a problem with the truth.Andreas Georgiou, the head of the statistics office, found that the shortages were much greater than the Greeks themselves had always claimed.He was sentenced to one year in prison for this last week.That is disgraceful and it shows where Greece stands.A mature society will fight deficits of its own accord, but Greece will only move if the lenders demand it.Why do we have to tell the Greeks that they pay out more than anyone else in pensions?That tax revenues are lagging?That loans have to be paid off?You know that yourself.Mr President, the idea that Greece is adult can no longer be defended, because adulthood is characterized by independence and a sense of responsibility, and Greece shows neither.Therefore the key question, Mr President, why do we continue to transfer money to small children?

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Mr President, the European Union will only overcome the challenges it faces if it acts in a united, coordinated and solidary manner. We must all pull in the same direction and, therefore, the Manichean statements by the President of the Eurogroup, who, by the way, are also socialist, Mr Dijsselbloem, are unacceptable. It is that on the one hand there are no pure and on the other side sinners, on the one hand the good, on the other hand the bad, on the one hand the northern ones, on the other side the southern ones, on the one hand the net contributors, the the other hand the net beneficiaries. We are all citizens of the European Union and there are victims and victims of the irresponsibility of the leaders who lead countries to bankruptcy, as happened in my country in 2011, and representatives of institutions such as the President of the Eurogroup who do not realize the enormous sacrifices made by the peoples that had adjustment programs. We need to strengthen the funds, the programs financed by the European Union budget, which have helped social cohesion, territorial cohesion and economic cohesion. A European stability mechanism that helps those Member States that are in difficulty is further proof of solidarity. But the eurozone needs to be strengthened and the banking union concluded, for example. We all know that the European Union's budget is small and corresponds to less than 1% of GDP and that skills, for example in the area of ​​health, in the area of ​​education, in the area of ​​employment, in the area of ​​justice and taxation, are nationals, but that does not prevent us from strengthening the European Union's budget to promote growth, to promote employment and to have the necessary investment in the European Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Mr President, Mr Zijlstra's statement to the Greek people that we are young children is racist and unacceptable.I believe that sanctions should be imposed on him, because it is not possible for MEPs in this Chamber to speak for an entire people in this way.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We take note of his statement.Hon. Fernandes, there is a question for you.Do you accept it?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Fernandes!I am surprised that after so many years in Greece, reforms have still not been successful.You can describe it like this: EU policy has resulted in the Greek people bleeding and cashing in the capital.Why don't you just think about releasing this country from the EU, from the euro, so that the people can take their own future into their own hands?

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- I will answer with another question: if the intervener who asks me the question knows what the cost for Greece of leaving the euro zone is?And if I knew the cost, I would certainly rephrase the question.There are competences that are national and national competences and that responsibility must be assumed by the Member State, in this specific case, by Greece.But the European Union also has an obligation of solidarity, obviously requiring, in return, the responsibility that each Member State has to bear, and it is in this set, in this united way, in this solidarity and concerted way that we can solve the challenges, helpGreece and other Member States so that the citizens of the European Union all feel like real citizens and all have equal opportunities in this area.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: - Mr President, today I am angry. Anger over Parliament's role. Are we a step towards unrelated monologues or the body of democratic legitimacy? And why do we accept our marginalization? Anger about the role of institutions. The evaluation does not close and the already deeply ill Greek economy is threatened with collapse. But even after it closes, as the previous fourteen closed positively, Greece does not come out of the fiscal stagnation and the development lag. Anger for the easy condemnation of the Greek government, where everything else is to blame, some conspirators, who only aim to overthrow the faltering Tsipras government and so no responsibility falls on our shoulders, even when we do not implement what we vote in Parliament. Do we finally have to admit that for the past seven years, institutions and governments have been exchanging wage cuts, pension cuts and a welfare state with an amnesty for the deep client state, that is, organized corruption and distorted development? The evaluation should have already been closed, the Parliament should have taken on its democratic role and the Greek program should not be a game, among other things, for the German elections.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I'm only going to look at part of this problem, or perhaps its solution. I am asking the question: how and for what was and is structural fund money used in Greece? I am also investigating this specific question as Parliament's special rapporteur on aid to Greece in the area of ​​regional policy. Due to its really tight financial situation, Greece could no longer guarantee the necessary co-financing shares at the end of the last funding period. That is why the EU has allowed the country, as an exception, to forego its own co-financing share, which is otherwise required, and to use the existing EU funds for specific local projects. In addition, the EU granted Greece an advance of one billion euros for the new funding period. I have always emphasized, including on my committee, that this aid cannot of course be a blank check. These structural funds must be used sensibly and not disappear into any financial holes. This also means that Greece has to grow economically in order to combat high unemployment and create prospects for the people. As far as the control work for my committee is concerned, I am waiting for the report from the Commission, which will contain an evaluation of these projects which are exempt from co-financing - also in order to be able to assess whether this extraordinary measure has had the desired success. From this we may be able to draw conclusions about how Greece is managing these funds in the current funding period, because according to the information available to us, these structural funds are still being called up far too little and the Commission should very seriously examine why this is not happening. It would be a shame if good projects were not carried out for administrative reasons, because the country needs good projects, also in regional policy, if it wants to create prospects for the people.

name: Eva KAILI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, some time ago you argued that the evaluation would close in 2016, but the ELSTAT figures again exposed the failure of the Greek program. We are in 2017 and, of course, the evaluation is not closed again. Now you are asking for new measures for the period after 2018, a new eternal memorandum, and you are constantly giving us new, festive dates for the completion of the evaluation, without taking any responsibility. Apart from blaming the IMF and the Council, but also covering up Tsipras and his nationalist government, you have to tell us what the Commission will do to stop sending the bill of this failed assessment to the Greek taxpayers, but also of the failed program implemented by Greece?

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, many thanks to the Commissioner and the Minister for their interventions in a debate that should have taken place with the President of the Eurogroup. The President of the Eurogroup has replied a few minutes ago to the letter that many Members addressed to him last week. An answer that arrives late and badly, via email, after the unanimous agreement of this House to disapprove of his attitude, but it is already too late. Mr Dijsselbloem, with his absence today, has lost respect for Parliament, as before with his derogatory statements he had done with women and with the countries of the South. But he has lost something else: he has missed a new opportunity to apologize, surely the last chance. In his letter he tells us that he will be more careful in the future. No, Mr Dijsselbloem, for you there is no future, because the Eurogroup cannot continue to count for another minute with a president who loses his due neutrality, with a president who discriminates against some countries against others, and with a president who despises women or turning his back on Parliament. The only future left for you is knowing how you want to be remembered. If as a macho, sectarian and arrogant president, or as a president who made a mistake, he rectified, asked for forgiveness and had the dignity to resign. It is your decision. I hope you will not be wrong again.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, in 2015 we experienced a thriller here in the European Parliament, calling on the Greek government to finally show responsibility and discipline in taking action and tough policies. Greece did it. The Commission, demonstrating responsibility, acknowledged Greece's practical stance. Today, however, as the agreements are being fulfilled, new requirements are emerging without rationality. What was built with sacrifices and hard compromises is in danger of collapsing, leaving only ruins. Already, the estimate of the evaluation delay is estimated at around 20 billion. In the midst of such an economic crisis and deprivation, however, the Greek people, ladies and gentlemen, are defending the European Union's external borders against Erdoğan and are receiving irresponsibility, irony and expediency from some here. This is not the European Union that has a future.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: - Mr President, one of the great problems that we are having with regard to the bailouts of countries is precisely that of democratic legitimacy. And the fact that today the President of the Eurogroup failed this Parliament's appeal only increases the feeling of democratic delegitimacy throughout this process - one more reason why he has to resign. But it is true that we are here today to discuss Greece, and Greece needs to introduce the spirit of the European Semester into its rescue program, that is, fiscal responsibility - not this excessive austerity that we are imposing with primary surpluses of 3.5%, with a debt weight of 181% -, greater flexibility so that they can get out of the economic crisis in which they find themselves, and socially just structural reforms that also facilitate investment. And to that extent, we call for them to recover collective bargaining, so they can increase their minimum wages - in Greece, all wages have been devalued by 40%. Because we also need to give them a strong message of social responsibility, of maintaining the social model; that these economic improvements are also affecting all the workers and citizens of Greece. Therefore, we ask for that message of responsibility, yes, but also of socially just responsibility for all citizens.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Mr President, the GDP forecast for 2017 is now between 0.5% and 1.7%, instead of the 2.5% estimated by the budget. At the same time, there has been an outflow of deposits since the beginning of the year. If the agreement is not concluded soon, the targets for reducing red loans, which have even started to increase in recent months, will not be achieved. All parties must understand that every day that passes does not come back. Every day of delay is another blow to the Greek economy. The consequences of all this will be supplemented with new additional measures, which will be paid again by the Greek people, as always happens. Finally, I would like to refer to a statement by my colleague, Mr Ferber, who said that Greece is wrongly first in defense spending until 2015. Indeed, wrongly a Greece in a very difficult economic situation pays so much money for security. But instead of waving the finger at Greece, which is in a critical geopolitical position, the German government must put its hand in its pocket and pay more for European security in the coming years.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, this statement by Mr Dijsselbloem has been denounced many times and I have denounced it from the outset in a letter to the Commission. The reason I come back to is this: there is something much more important behind the statement that was not mentioned; there is a political conception that governed the negotiations. What matters and must be denounced is that this man with this perception is the one who imposed the specific memoranda. Finally, I have to say that the economy is too big a case to be left to economists alone. It is the political action, the political thinking, that had to determine how the debt case of Greece should move and I think that without a discussion about the debt there can be no substantial way out.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, I am very upset that Commissioner Moscovici, such a great benefactor of the Greek economy, has left. I would also like to congratulate Mr Dijsselbloem on his sincerity. He does not hide his disrespect for Greece and democracy and he shows it clearly. I wish the rest of the institutions were so honest. I do not blame them. I wonder how long the Greek people will tolerate them committing atrocities against them. A people who have been erected on the wall for seven years and executed. During the occupation, the Greeks, in front of the executive detachment, prayed to the Virgin Mary, sang the national anthem and shouted: "Long live Freedom!", "Long live Greece!", Even if some political politicians in Greece do not want to hear these the historical facts. Be aware that the Greeks have a long history of heroism rather than servitude. Beyond politics and parties, beyond the economy, you have imposed a pre-agreed and ratified by the memoranda enslavement of the Greek nation, corresponding to that of the Turkish conqueror, from which it took 400 years to liberate, a disguised, under the unholy alliance of the troika, barbarism. But do not be fooled by some. The Greeks will shout: "Goodbye Tsipras!", "Goodbye Europe!", "Goodbye barbarism!".

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has contributed to removing Greece from the dark days of the crisis, and it is right that this House should be aware of this to the citizens. This is democracy, and this is the path that Parliament wants to take, with all due respect to Dijsselbloem. On the other hand, what is not democratic, what alienates citizens and complicates the work of institutions is to insist on the idea that only austerity can offer solutions to the crisis affecting the Member States, and that there is an almost endemic or cultural imbalance in the management of public affairs in the Mediterranean regions. Greece has shown that it can follow the reform path envisaged by the Commission, albeit with foreseeable halts. In the first place remain the needs of the Greek people, such as the implementation of an immediate solution to the worrying situation of the health, judicial and school systems. The interest of European citizens is that Greece will go back to planning its future together with the EU institutions. This is no time for divisive words, no time for pointless accusations. It is time to think beyond the emergency and reconcile the needs of creditors with those of the Greek people, without impositions and without threats.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr. President, in Greece we are reliving the nightmare of uncertainty and this nightmare is repeated and severely hurts the lives of Greeks. Of course, we are not here to ignore the responsibilities of the Greek government, which delays sending the bill. But the question to the Commission, which is no longer represented here by Commissioner Moscovici, is whether you know what is really happening in the Greek economy. I heard Mr Moscovici talk about resilience and a high primary surplus. Did you know that the overdue debts of the Greek State now reach 500 million? Did you know that in the first quarter of 2017 alone, about three billion euros left the Greek banks? You talked about technical changes in the energy market. Did you know that the market value of the Public Electricity Company reached, at the end of 2014, 2.5 billion euros and is now only 600 million? Do you really control the course of structural change as a Commission? Can you make a safe prediction for the possibility of full access of Greece to the markets in 2018? We need serious reforms. We need a government committed to reform. Even if Mr. Dijsselbloem, who looks like a political corpse, leaves tomorrow morning, the course of our country will not change. We also need creditors who will not only see the numbers, but the essence of the Greek program and will not use it for pre-election purposes.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, first, second or third program, is that the right question? Basically, the situation in Greece is revealing of the result of the austerity policies too often practiced in recent years by the European Union. In Greece, it is admittedly more worrying than average, but it should warn of the risks facing the European Union as a whole, for the moment incapable of relaunching its economy on a lasting basis. How to allow this country to restore its economy by imposing insurmountable demands on the debt and the conditions of its repayment? I would like to remind you that in our common history there has been debt forgiveness precisely to revive the economy. Without going that far, we must now examine the conditions for a partial pooling that would allow countries in difficulty, including Greece, to get off to a good start without having to constantly be accountable or take new steps. austerity measures that the people no longer want, the Greeks like the others, for that matter.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Mr President, the second evaluation of the Greek program is delayed because the European institutions have been towed behind the irrational claims of the International Monetary Fund for new tougher austerity measures against low-wage earners and retirees. While, for example, the International Labor Organization estimates that the minimum threshold for a decent living in Greece is 7,000 euros per year, the Fund claims the tax-free rate to drop to around 5,500, seeking to suck out people who lack tax capacity. Lenders still claim the deregulation of collective redundancies and stubbornly refuse to resume collective bargaining, thus violating Articles 28 and 30 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and ignoring the findings of the committee of experts set up by the participation and consent. The negotiation must be completed immediately, on the basis of European principles and values, with the withdrawal of the unreasonable claims of the creditors.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of Commissioner Moscovici and of the Commission, I welcome your comments and interventions.  Emotions, difficulties and anger all of course show that we have a really very challenging situation and that it is not easy to reach agreement. The state of play on the Greek stability support programme is an important discussion to have and I think it is a discussion that we must have openly. Greece is now at an important juncture. It is one and a half years into its European Stability Mechanism support programme. This is a time to engrain the progress made to date in Greece, support the economic recovery which began to emerge in 2016, and thus secure a successful exit from the programme in 2018, as planned. Therefore, as Commissioner Moscovici outlined in his opening intervention, swift progress must now be quickly made in closing this second programme review. These elements of the post-programme package should be fair and balanced in order to avoid further uncertainty and come to an agreement on the elements that could help bring the IMF on board. Agreement on an overall package that also provides certainty on the primary surplus path and Greek debt sustainability among all partners should be reached swiftly in view of Friday’s Eurogroup. A sustainable recovery, and economic and financial stability, are not only in the interests of Greece and its citizens, but in the interests of us all, and the European Union as a whole.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Greece's public debt stock continues to be one of the fundamental challenges for the Eurozone. Its long-term sustainability is called into question by the International Monetary Fund, pointing towards the solution of a restructuring by reducing interest rates, increasing grace periods and repayment periods. The Eurogroup should take this analysis into account in the negotiations to renew the financial assistance program. In particular, conditionality needs to stop emphasizing the regressive reform of the labor market (collective bargaining must be recovered) and fiscal adjustment. Regarding the setting of budget balance objectives, these must be moderate and realistic, otherwise social conditions and political instability will worsen, in addition to damaging the economic growth rate. In any case, other countries such as Spain, Portugal and Italy meet or exceed the threshold of 100% sovereign debt on the Gross Domestic Product. Using the European Stability Mechanism as a fund for debt redemption could help to solve this problem for the whole of the Eurozone.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - Greece's public debt stock continues to be one of the fundamental challenges for the Eurozone. Its long-term sustainability is called into question by the International Monetary Fund, pointing towards the solution of a restructuring by reducing interest rates, increasing grace periods and repayment periods. The Eurogroup should take this analysis into account in the negotiations to renew the financial assistance program. In particular, conditionality needs to stop emphasizing the regressive reform of the labor market (collective bargaining must be recovered) and fiscal adjustment. Regarding the setting of budget balance objectives, these must be moderate and realistic, otherwise social conditions and political instability will worsen, in addition to damaging the economic growth rate. In any case, other countries such as Spain, Portugal and Italy meet or exceed the threshold of 100% sovereign debt on the Gross Domestic Product. Using the European Stability Mechanism as a fund for debt redemption could help to solve this problem for the whole of the Eurozone.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- This debate should have taken place in the presence of the President of the Eurogroup Jeroen Dijsselbloem, who instead turns out to be still the "stone guest" of this debate.I hope that the presidency wants to convey to Minister Dijsselbloem all our disappointment at having once again deserted Parliament on an occasion like this which would have allowed him to explain his latest statements addressing the Greek people and all of Europe.clarifying his conception of solidarity once and for all!

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The second review of the program, which is currently under way, complicates not only the slower adoption of reforms but also the dispute between Greece, European creditors and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).EU / IMF Heads of Mission were due to arrive in Athens for details of the agreement ahead of a meeting of finance ministers scheduled for the end of March 2017. However, new disagreements between Greece and the IMF over pensions and labor reforms blocked the agreement.The Commission announced that no new date for the mission's return to Athens had been set.The talks continue through teleconferences.The conclusion of the second revision is necessary for Greece to receive further support from the rescue program.Without it, it will not be able to cover the large loan repayment scheduled for July.The failure to conclude the second evaluation of the Greek program raises concerns about the return of the Greek crisis.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - Mr President, the delay in closing the second rating has literally frozen the Greek economy, causing investment inactivity, falling consumption, job losses, outflows of deposits, rising red loans and a revision of the current year's budget targets. The game of responsibilities between the Greek government, the European Union and the IMF is well known, as are the mistakes and omissions of each side. Undoubtedly, the Greek government must promote the necessary reforms, but the institutions, for their part, should not make excessive demands. Judging by the overall course of the Greek adjustment program, we cannot ignore the fact that in the 7 years of the crisis Greece has paid a very heavy price, losing, among many others, 25% of its GDP, one million jobs and half a million young scientists, who were forced to leave it in search of better fortune abroad. In a difficult period for Europe, with many and difficult open fronts, the return of Greece to conditions of stability clearly serves the common interest. The solution must not be based on recessionary measures, such as over-taxation, but on stimulating growth by attracting new investment.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing. - The evaluation we are discussing today should have been closed fourteen months ago. It did not close. About two months ago, we heard that the negotiations are going well and that the evaluation will close soon. It did not close. Today, Greece remains on the brink of collapse and uncertainty. Our country is among the tactics of a government that seeks responsibility and Mr. Dijsselbloem, who secretly plays the European Parliament and slanders to the detriment of our peoples. The Greek people can no longer stand the uncertainty, they can not stand another "fiasco", as in 2015. Our people are looking for solidarity, a European and fair treatment both from our partners and from the Greek leadership that is unable to give realistic answers.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the recommendation for second reading on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the Council position at first reading with regard to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on medical devices, amending Directive 2001 / 83 / EC, Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 and Regulation (EC) No 1223/2009 and repealing Council Directives 90/385 / EEC and 93/42 / EEC (10728/4/2016 - C8-0104 / 2017 - 2012/0266 (COD)) (rapporteur: Glenis Willmott) (A8-0068 / 2017) and - Recommendation for second reading by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting the regulation Of the European Parliament and of the Council on in vitro diagnostic medical devices and repealing Directive 98/79 / EC and Commission Decision 2010/227 / EU (10729 / 4/2016 - C8-0105 / 2017 - 2012/0267 (COD)) (rapporteur: Peter Liese) (A8-0069 / 2017).

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking all my shadow rapporteurs for their excellent support and cooperation including, of course, Mr Liese, the rapporteur on IVD. My thanks to the Commission and the Council, and I would also like to thank the Luxembourg – and, in particular – Dutch Presidencies for their determination to get the Council agreement that we have today.  We have put in place strong, clear rules for the whole life—cycle of devices, from design and manufacture through clinical testing and authorisation to vigilance and market surveillance, giving manufacturers legal certainty about what they have to do.  Protecting patients is at the heart of this legislation. We all remember the scandals of the past. I have heard from women whose lives have been turned upside down after having a pelvic mesh implant, women who are now living in constant pain. I have heard from women who are still not sure which breast implants they have had and whether they need to be worried about their future health.  It just is not right that people have not got sufficient information about devices that have been used in their medical procedures. So in future all devices will be traceable with a unique device identification number and patients will receive an implant card with this number, so we will all know which device has been implanted in which patient. If there is a problem with the device, patients deserve to be compensated, so it is clear that manufacturers must have sufficient financial coverage to deal with their potential liability.  We know that in the case of metal—on—metal hips there was little clarity for patients as to whether the problems were caused by the device or by the medical professionals treating them. When there is reason to believe a device has caused harm to a patient, information on that device must be made available to the patient and their doctor.  To ensure patient safety in the future we must make sure devices are safe before they reach the market. All devices will undergo a thorough clinical evaluation before marketing, and Parliament insisted that there should be additional scrutiny for the highest—risk devices. Things such as implants, insulin pumps and pacemakers will be referred to an expert panel for additional assessment.  Parliament also argued for restrictions on hazardous substances used in medical devices. Wherever possible, manufacturers will have to substitute materials that are carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic to reproduction, and justify where this is not possible. Notified bodies will still have responsibility for awarding a CE mark, but it is clear that these have to be up to the job. We have introduced strict new requirements for notified bodies, and they will be regularly inspected by Member States. Notified bodies will also have greater powers to carry out unannounced inspections and must inspect samples of all devices regularly. Any problem should be picked up early and action taken straight away.  While it is vital that we ensure devices are safe before they are placed on the market, it is also essential that they are carefully monitored afterwards. The new law will significantly strengthen requirements for post-market surveillance, including introducing periodic safety update reports similar to those that are now produced for medicines.  Finally, on reprocessing of single—use devices, this was one of the most difficult issues to get agreement on. For the Member States it is a very sensitive issue. Some wanted reprocessing to be banned entirely; others wanted no legislation at EU level. Therefore, reprocessing will only be allowed if it is permitted under national law. Those Member States that want to ban it can do so. For those that allow it, there are EU-wide standards that must be complied with, including reprocessors assuming all the obligations of the manufacturers. Colleagues, it has taken a long time and a lot of work to get to this point, so I hope you will support the final agreement as one which gives patients much more protection, while ensuring continued innovation.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, the rapporteur, Willmott.Congratulations on the ovation you received.They did belong.The next speaker is the rapporteur, Peter Liese.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It is really high time we got better medical device legislation. Numerous scandals have shaken patient confidence, and reputable companies have also fallen into disrepute because some have cheated on a massive scale. A few weeks ago the European Court of Justice dealt with the PIP scandal again, and the ECJ unfortunately found that there is currently no obligation under our law to inspect the products on site without prior notification. That's why we urgently need to change something. If we adopt the two reports tomorrow, we will introduce unannounced on-the-spot checks. Not only must the paper be checked, but what is really going on must also be checked. This will allow us to discover black sheep, and this will surely lead to a different spirit in companies too, if you know that you can be checked at any time without prior notice. There were scandals not only with breast implants, but also with hip implants, with stents that are implanted, for example, in the vessels that supply the brain, and with diagnostic tests such as genetic tests, DNA tests or HIV tests. There has been an HIV test on the market for years that has given false negative results significantly more often than others. That is, there was an HIV virus, but the test said there was no HIV virus. One can imagine the problems that would arise if someone donated blood or had unprotected sex because of such a false statement. That is why we have to control unannounced. That is why we also have to introduce other things with this legislation: a stronger review of the notified bodies. For high-risk products, the tests not only use the Scrutiny procedure, which is also used for other medical products There is a network of reference laboratories that monitor compliance with the standards, and we have also prescribed clinical evidence for the tests. The test must really say what it says it says. On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen - that was particularly important for my group: we do not want to adopt any rules that would only lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. The only thing that is of no use to the patient is paperwork, which is why we refused, for example, that the Council for Class A Medical Devices - such as simple things like a urine cup - stipulated that you have to fill out new papers on a regular basis the periodic safety update report. We need a balance of control, but also the opportunity for innovation and companies to develop, and we managed to do that quite well. Another aspect was very important for Parliament and for me personally: we not only wanted to better control the quality of the tests with the sensitive DNA tests, but also to lay down rules for their application. DNA testing can have a big impact, so people need to know what to expect and be free to decline a test. Unfortunately, the Council of Ministers was not prepared to accept literally the amendment, which this Parliament approved by a huge majority, but we have reached a compromise: there is an obligation to provide information on genetic tests and a detailed obligation to provide genetic advice in the case of diseases that occur after State of the art are not to be treated. And this also applies to most cases of prenatal diagnostics, so that a consultation must also take place here. We will pay close attention to the implementation of this point. Overall, I believe we have reached a good compromise, and I would also like to thank everyone who contributed: the Commission, the Council Presidency, with Mrs Glenis Willmott, as co-rapporteur, with all shadow rapporteurs, above all Mairead McGuinness for the EPP, and - ladies and gentlemen, allow me to finish with our staff.You cannot imagine how many hours, even in the evening and on weekends, that we invested so that we could achieve this good result.So once again, thank you very much, and I ask for your approval in plenary tomorrow.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President,   I would like to warmly thank your House and you, the Members of the European Parliament, for the determination that you have constantly shown. Over the past five years, you have striven for a successful outcome on such a technical and complex file. I know that many of you have worked on this issue. I would like to thank, in particular, the rapporteurs on the two regulations, Ms Willmott and Mr Liese, for their outstanding competence and dedication to this file. Thank you once again. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, and I have not forgotten the rapporteur on medical devices under the previous legislative term, Ms Dagmar Roth-Behrendt. As you know, the EU is world leader in the medical device field. In the EU the sector employs over half a million people in about 25 000 companies, of which around 90% are SMEs. Annual sales amount to EUR 100 billion, of which a significant part is invested annually in research. The availability of safe and innovative medical devices is a key factor in guaranteeing effective and affordable treatments for European patients. Designing a new regulatory framework for this sensitive and crucial sector is the joint responsibility of all the EU institutions. The Commission wholeheartedly welcomes the final compromise, which contains a series of crucial improvements to the current system. Let me mention some of them: first, strict market control for high—risk devices; second, reinforced criteria for the designation and oversight of notified bodies; third, the inclusion of certain aesthetic devices in the new legislation; fourth, the introduction of a new risk classification system for diagnostic in vitro medical devices; fifth, improved transparency via the establishment of an EU database on medical devices; sixth, a stability system based on unique device identification; seventh, the introduction of an implant card for patients; eighth, stricter and more detailed rules on clinical evidence and clinical investigation; and, ninth, an improved coordination mechanism between Member States for vigilance and market surveillance. The new European legislation will ensure a higher level of patient safety, provide legal certainty for economic operators and promote innovation and competitiveness in the sector. It consolidates the role of the EU as global leader in the field, while establishing a world-class reference for medical device regulation. Thank you once again.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner Andriukaitis, for your speech, for this atmosphere of mutual understanding.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I have to say that I thought this day would never come. I am relieved and happy to be here. Glenis Willmott and Peter Liese, who led us in these two important files, are to be congratulated for the work they did and the work we all did on this. And Commissioner, thanks go to your colleagues as well, and to the Council, because this was not just technical; it was political.  I am also glad that the Chamber is full with visitors, because what we are talking about today will affect each and every one of us, now and in the future. Also, Commissioner, thank you for acknowledging the importance of this industry in terms of both jobs and its output. This industry makes our lives better and extends our lives, and for that we should be grateful. Yes, we are talking about when things go wrong, and that spurs us to do more things, and to do them better. We should acknowledge that the industry is a very good industry that Europe should be proud of. What we are doing today is making it more certain for that industry to continue, so that when we get slightly older and may need things that are improved upon, we may live better and longer lives.  May I, at this point, say that Glenis Willmott has gone through the technical details, so there is no need for me to repeat that. What I think is most important is that we implement, and that the Member States who have signed up to this, and the Commission who are with us on this journey, realise that this Parliament will keep a watching brief and will make sure that resources are put in place so that we do put action on the words. Lastly, can I say that our staff – as has already been mentioned – are hugely important. I think it is very important that we say this openly, because on the technical side they were incredible – both our Group staff and our individual staff. If I may say so, I very carelessly lost two staff members during the course of this regulation, and both to the medical devices industry, because they are excellent workers on behalf of citizens: Mark Taylor and Sinead Duggan, who I know is watching this debate. I think that is the good thing about what we have done. We will make our industry more certain. We will make safer the lives of citizens, and we can grow jobs and grow our economy. So today, fingers crossed, is a good day.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Club. - Mr. President, we are not interested in medical devices until we need them, but the moment we need them, they become the most important thing in the world. The main goal we want to achieve with these regulations is better patient protection while encouraging innovation in the industry. Europe has the best doctors in the world, but both they and patients need to know that they have equipment that is high quality and safe. Confidence in the industry is capitalized through better product placement and sales, so the new rules will actually benefit everyone. The Commission published the initial proposal back in 2012, which means that European patients have been waiting for 5 years to close the loopholes in the regulations that caused the scandals with artificial hips, implants and HIV tests. When a scandal occurs in this sector, people unfortunately die. That is why we insisted that new and innovative in vitro medical devices of the highest risk class for which there are no references and common specifications be covered by an additional monitoring procedure. The new rules strengthen the capacities and structures of the designated bodies that play the most important role in placing devices on the market. Their responsibilities and obligations are increasing, and one of the novelties is unannounced inspections of producers. When scandals occur and patients suffer, the issue of fair and timely compensation becomes imperative. The new regulations oblige manufacturers of medical devices to have an appropriate system and resources for patient compensation in the event of an incident. Furthermore, manufacturers will have to provide victims and competent services with adequate access to information and documentation related to their case. As for the Committee on Ethics and Issues, such as clinical trials of devices on minors, from day one we insisted that the regulations be aligned with the regulations on drug trials. I think we have managed to reach a good compromise that raises the level of patient and user safety.
