New procedures and security mechanisms will not be an obstacle to the innovation and competitiveness of the European medical device industry.I therefore call on all of you to support this compromise, because it is in the interest of both patients and medical device manufacturers.In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleague Glenis Willmott, my colleague Peter Liese and all the other shadow rapporteurs I have worked with on this document.It was a really hard and arduous job, but the results will be to the delight of all of us, and especially the patients.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Colleagues! In the work on the reports, I have always tried to place great emphasis on ensuring the right balance between the priority of patient safety and technological progress, the competences of the Member States and the competences of the European Union institutions. The very fact that there were ten trilogue meetings where a fairly satisfactory inter-institutional agreement was reached shows how difficult the process was - but a possible process. On the one hand, the priority, i.e. patient safety, is described in the report by appointing special notified bodies, which are now obliged to carry out unannounced inspections at production plants, which means that in the case of devices, especially high-risk devices, it is not enough just to check the relevant documentation, but what's more - the product's manufacturing site should also be inspected and properly inspected. On the other hand, the report promotes new medical technologies as it opens the way to encourage manufacturers to look for - and where necessary also look for substitutes - substances that may be carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic. In addition, the improvement in the quality of patient safety has been ensured by the inclusion of dedicated expert teams for independent evaluation. I think this text is good. It will improve the legal framework applicable to medical devices and in vitro diagnostic medical devices so that they become safer, and at the same time the framework will not hinder qualitative progress in the process of medical technology development. The text also respects the division of competences between the European institutions and the Member States. And although I am not satisfied with all the proposed issues, such as genetic counseling, I voted in favor and will vote in favor.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. -  Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would also like to thank the two rapporteurs, Glenis Willmott and Peter Liese. At Glenis a little more, because their dossier was a little bigger. But they both fought tremendously and it was really a very difficult process. In this case, it is about medical products from adhesive plasters to walking aids to pacemakers. So it really is everything that people really need when they get sick. Expressed in hours, for example, we had 30 hours of trialogue, more than 200 hours of technical meeting, the dossier was 700 pages long and we had to work on it. I have never had such a complicated legal process before. It was blocked for a long time in the Council until an agreement was reached there. And in the end, we in Parliament were actually very united on a lot and were happy that we got it right. Indeed, as has already been said, we now have more patient safety. This is good after the breast implant scandal - that was what triggered it - but we still do not have a central approval, which is also good, because otherwise it would have made innovation and patient access to certain drugs more difficult. So it's good that we managed to do that too. What is it now? I would like to say a few things about it. First about risk classes. I also learned a lot, I have to say: Risk class 1 is, for example, a care bed, 2a are hearing aids, 2b are dental implants, and risk class 3 is cardiac catheters. And depending on which risk class that is, special approval procedures are required, and you then have more compensation obligations or liability with the producers. These are all things that we discussed. Reconditioning was a big problem. Up until then I had also thought that single-use products should not be reprocessed. Under However, under certain conditions, Member States may allow this, and we have also noticed that it is possible.Well, we've really dealt with such things down to the last detail.Even with tests - by the way, I disagree with Peter Liese.I think it's good that we have kept access to tests relatively low-threshold because I think that patients need it.Finally, an urgent request to the Commission: there are a large number of implementing acts and delegated acts that have to come now, in some cases before the notified bodies have even been designated.My warm request to the Commission: make sure that you have enough resources to do everything the way patients need in Europe.That would be great

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we have been negotiating these two regulations here for more than four and a half years. A huge amount of work has been done, after all, these are the largest legislative documents that have ever been discussed on this ground. Many thanks to both rapporteurs and all those who took part. I must say here that I completely disagree with the fact that these two documents, as colleagues from the factions opposite, think, should be rejected in any way or not dealt with further. We worked on them, the documents are good, although I don't have to agree with everything. It is very important that we finally, finally send them into force and finally make them available to European citizens, because we made them for them. The effectiveness of this regulation is theoretically planned for the end of May 2020 or May 2022. That is, it is ten years from the beginning of the negotiations until the European citizen can feel it at all. I would like to ask the Commissioner, I am concerned about some of the Member States' analyzes, which clearly show that neither the Commission nor the relevant supervisory authorities are still sufficiently equipped to implement these documents in time. Please, having worked on them for so long and so well, we must begin to implement them. It is our duty to implement and make them available to the Member States and the citizens of the European Union.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, I extend a big thank you to the rapporteurs, Mr Liese, and in particular Mrs Willmott, for this report. It took four and a half years to finally arrive at this compromise text, not to mention the many trilogues that had to be faced. These texts are always due to a scandal, for example the scandal of PIP breast prostheses in France, among others, but I believe that there has been significant progress. Among the strengths, I note the compensation insurance system for patients who suffer damage, which is very important. I note the progress on transparency and identification, in particular of medical devices, the creation of a public database - in this regard, we have written to Mr Juncker for financial means to be made available so that this Eudamed database can be functional - just like the publication of the declaration of interest of all the experts who will participate and, finally, the elimination as far as possible of carcinogens, mutagens and reprotoxic substances. I have a caveat to a few things: we did not get the centralized marketing authorization. We are therefore going to have several notified bodies, which entails the need for unannounced assessment and checks, as has been said, in order to ensure their expertise capacity. Indeed, the new scandal over Essure, a tubal sterilization implant, shows that the presence of nickel causes a huge number of side effects that are impacted by women. It is therefore important to ensure that certification bodies have very important clinical studies, also thanks to the committee of experts which must evaluate them. So I am quite optimistic about this text and I hope it will be voted on.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the delegation of the 5 Star Movement will vote positively on these proposals regarding medical devices and medical-diagnostic devices because they go in the direction we wish, namely that no low-quality medical device has yet to be marketed to the within the European Union. In Europe, we can no longer afford scandals such as those of silicone implants or low-quality HIV tests that have produced false negatives - as my colleague Liese said earlier - thus increasing the risk of contagion of a disease such as AIDS. We must say enough to formal and superficial controls, while we must favor direct and substantial controls that protect patients in a preventive way. We are in favor of a network of European reference laboratories for the control of high-risk devices, especially for innovative ones. Finally, we believe that it has been a success to have foreseen the obligation of a surveillance plan to monitor the safety of the devices during their life cycle and to allow patients and their doctors to always have timely information to detect any malfunctions. Now, however, we look forward to the adoption of the criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors, without which it will not be possible to select the dangerous substances, which may also be present in medical-surgical aids, and consequently not even apply the legislation we are about to take. vote, with very serious damage to the health of our patients.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, following the scandals of PIP breast prostheses fraudulently made from non-medical silicone and metal-to-metal hip prostheses which resulted in the spread of highly toxic cobalt, it was decided to overhaul the rules concerning medical devices. Sadly, these two contentious cases are said to be in part the consequence of a lack of vigilance by a national health agency. But that in no way justifies the total loss of the prerogatives of the States due to the establishment of the two regulations studied today. These new regulations will place unrealistic constraints on notified bodies which are, by virtue of their compulsory accreditation, the keystone of the value chain since they transfer the competences of the national authorities to these same notified bodies by transforming them into a real health police. The consequences are then twofold: the privatization of the health system when medical devices are placed on the market and, moreover, a considerable increase in certification costs in return for the responsibility that will weigh on these organizations and therefore on their premium. insurance in anticipation of future trials. While certain provisions are useful, such as improved traceability, the end result risks paralyzing quite quickly the European medical device sector, especially the French sector, unable to date to rely on a notified body that is essential. In so doing, these regulations violate our health sovereignty without precedent. Unable to supply their customers, due to the lack of mandatory CE marking, French SMEs are forced out of hospitals and pharmacies on the recommendation of the French National Medicines Safety Agency, itself, for the benefit of foreign companies, or even external to it. 'European Union, yet for products of lower quality.Of course, these foreign companies must also obtain the CE mark, but their profitability and their prevalence in their national market allow them to resist better, even if, in the long term, the potential lack of auditors will make the European market dependent on imports from countries.third.Recall that in France, the medical device industry concerns around 65,000 jobs out of a thousand companies which are more than 90% of very small companies (TPE), for a turnover of 20 billion euros..Ultimately, if this discussion was necessary and expected by the players in the sector, this revision entails a very significant modification of the regulatory requirements extending the certification deadlines.Conversely, the deadlines for the application of these regulations are desired in the very short term, almost by force.For all these reasons, we will oppose these texts.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it will have taken almost five years for us to be able to revise this legislation which is more than 20 years old and to close the loopholes which have unfortunately resulted in scandals like the scandal. global health of PIP breast prostheses. I regret the slowness of the procedure, but I want to congratulate the rapporteurs and, among others, Mrs Wilmott and Mr Liese as well as the shadow rapporteurs because they have really done an enormous job to bring about an ambitious revision of this regulation and meet two specific objectives, namely strengthening and guaranteeing patient safety and restoring their confidence while encouraging innovation in the field of medical technologies, and therefore job creation. These texts bring an end to an era where an implantable medical device met almost the same regulatory obligations as a simple toaster. Today, the strengthening of the surveillance of notified bodies, the obligations of unannounced checks by manufacturers, the attention given to category 3 and 2B devices, the most at risk, or the improvement of product traceability, all this should help prevent fraud and restore the credibility of the CE marking. I just regret that we have not found a uniform solution for the reprocessing of single use devices, which I am totally opposed to. I note, however, that if Member States allow them, hospitals will have to meet extremely strict obligations. In conclusion, Commissioner, I believe that we must ensure the implementation of these texts. Any delay in adopting implementing acts could have serious consequences. We are not yet at the end of our troubles. The, I hope, rapid and efficient application of these many advances will require significant resources and I hope that the Commission and Member States will be able to put these resources on the table.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, it has been a very long journey but, after four years, here we are and, yes, it is a good day. I would like to congratulate Glenis Willmott – I know you had a big task ahead of you, but you managed to do a great a job – and also our colleague, Peter Liese, and our shadow, Biljana Borzan, because together you managed to build on the spirit of compromise and really put at the heart of the policies you worked on our patients’ safety first and foremost. I am really glad also to see such a large attendance by the public in the galleries today because this field we are speaking about and discussing is diverse, competitive and highly innovative. It is an area of great promise – sometimes spectacular promise – but it can also be an area of a number of pitfalls. Devices are routinely implanted in our bodies. They replace limbs, bones, tissues and sometimes entire organs, but medical and diagnostic devices, when well designed, well made and properly used, can improve our quality of life and can save lives. If not, they can threaten and impair it. As the directly—elected representatives of our citizens, it is our mission to make sure that patients in the EU can access safe, effective and high—quality medical devices and diagnostics, and that they have timely access to medical technologies that will really help them.  We are living in a digital era where we need to be proactive and anticipate innovation. Our regulatory framework needs to be prepared for the type of technology that will come our way. It needs to help foster innovation and the development of life—saving and life—enhancing equipment. So yes, these pieces of legislation are a good example of how we can improve patient safety, and I look forward to Parliament building further on this spirit so as to ensure the highest level of patient safety throughout the EU, but maybe at a more rapid speed.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, can I give my congratulations and thanks to both of the rapporteurs and all of the teams. I have to say I admire your stamina. You are an example to us all. And so here we are at last.  Patient safety is of paramount importance and ensuring that this should always be so is our top priority. I am often one of the first to say that additional regulation can be burdensome, however when it comes to the realm of public health, especially when lives are in jeopardy and the safety of our healthcare system is questioned, tighter oversight and control mechanisms are vital. Indeed, in the wake of the breast implant and metal—on—metal hip scandals of 2012, it is now more important than ever that patient confidence be restored. I firmly believe that support for these proposals is warranted. With the introduction of more systematic post-market checks, as well as stricter monitoring and traceability measures, these proposals create a framework whereby errors are more easily identifiable, allowing for more targeted and efficient responses and minimising any negative fallout.  While focusing on consumer safety, I would also acknowledge the importance of innovation, and these proposals do exactly that. So I think you have got the balance right, and I will be very happy to vote for this tomorrow.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! Think it succeeded! After so many hours, days, years, it is truly impressive that we have now reached a result that almost all of us are well satisfied with. Thanks to Glenis Willmott and Peter Liese and also to Dagmar Roth-Behrendt for the work they have done. I will not repeat all the excellent technical things presented here, it would be too boring! But I would like to emphasize that it is also a huge advantage for the industry that we now have proper traceability, proper control, openness and liability. If this is really going to work across Europe, then it will mean that in future we can actually say, "We will be the best on the world market!", Instead of the reactionary forces that have so far said "Uh, we must finally have nothing at all, for we must be allowed to cheat and deceive ". I'm one of those people who has had both knees and hips replaced, etc., and I'm actually quite grateful not only that it can be done, but also that it can be done safely so that I can move fairly freely. Finally, let me emphasize the point that Peter Liese made, namely advice. Some of these things are actually a little more dramatic for humans than we have quite been able to get an impression of here. Getting a genetic test done is actually nothing. There is a risk that people will start amputating their breasts and arms and legs and will hardly dare to have children out of sheer fear of what might happen. Here it is important to emphasize that there must be advice, and it would be best if the Member States insisted that such advice be compulsory.

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, the role of medical devices in the UK, as well as in Europe, is of exceptional importance, and the medical devices sector plays a fundamental role in the diagnosis, prevention, monitoring and treatment of diseases. I share the concern about this issue with the rapporteur and the European Commission, and recognise that disgraceful things have happened in the past, where women having breast augmentation procedures were given Poly Implant Prostheses (PIPs) containing industrial silicone. Although I agree with the objectives of this report, which aims to influence the manufacturers at the site of production, as well as to increase transparency in instances where patients have had an adverse reaction to a medical device and are searching for information, I believe, however, that Member States are best placed to act in this field. My party and I believe that this is an issue best dealt with by national parliaments, therefore avoiding unnecessary bureaucracy.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andriukaitis, I believe we have come a long way and have traveled together, from the proposal five years ago to the agreement closed under the Dutch presidency. For this I believe that colleagues Willmott and Liese should be thanked for the role they had as speakers, and also personally I would like to thank them for the collaboration they have provided in the last phase of the negotiations during the trilogues to reach an understanding, an profitable with the Council and with the help of the Commission. The negotiation was complex and long, not only for the duration, but also for the complexity of the dossier, very technical, with a series of elements that we had to define during the work. But the final result is certainly an important result: we provide the industry with a clear picture that will allow investments to be made and will contribute to the goal we set ourselves from the beginning, which was to have greater patient safety. but also to stimulate innovation in medicine. We have worked to strongly raise the standards of quality and safety of products, to protect the health of European citizens, and embarked on a path that will force the industrial sector to make an important change of mentality. I am sure that these new rules will represent an opportunity for the European health and industrial system. There are many important measures, especially in terms of transparency, such as the establishment of the central database to create a system for collecting all information. Or I am thinking of patients with implanted devices, for whom key product information is required, including any precautions they may need. Ultimately, we have reached a compromise that took many hours of negotiation, but of which we as MEPs must certainly be proud. Tomorrow I hope that we will all support him in this House.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir. Chairman! From me, too, a huge congratulations to Mrs Willmott and Mr Liese for a great, great job. But most of all, there must be a huge congratulations to the European patients. Because with the proposal we have to vote on tomorrow, it will be significantly safer to be a patient in Europe if you need to get new hips or a new pacemaker or abdominal net, or whatever you might need. However, let me also say that it was probably time too! We have struggled with this for many many years, ever since the scandals of approx. 5-6 years ago spilled out of the closet. I am particularly pleased that we will have significantly stricter requirements for the equipment before it can be marketed, and significantly greater control of the equipment after it has been marketed. That's exactly what we need! I would also have liked to have seen a European central approval system, but unfortunately we did not achieve that. Either way, a huge congratulations to the European patients. It is now safer to be patient.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Unfortunately, it appears that a crisis often first has to break out before things can be changed. This morning we had the debate on “dieselgate” and now on medical devices. Here, too, several scandals made it painfully clear that the control mechanisms on medical devices are inadequate. Everyone remembers the problems with defective breast implants from the French manufacturer PIP. The existing legislation dates from the early 1990s and is therefore outdated, also due to technological progress. The new rules are intended to increase the safety and quality of medical devices, in the interest of the patient. Strict control before the product enters the market must go hand in hand with strict ex post market surveillance when the product is available. The rules for high-risk medical devices, such as certain implants, are necessary. In addition, better transparency and traceability are essential. The agreement before us is not perfect, but it is definitely a step forward and my delegation will support it.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: - Commissioner, there are currently more than 500 000 in vitro medical and diagnostic devices on the European market. Due to the rapid development, these devices are becoming more sophisticated, but the current regulation is not keeping pace with scientific progress. Due to several scandals where diagnostic aids have given patients incorrect results, I am convinced of the need to adapt the legislation to the real situation and to tighten the rules in order to eliminate cases of incorrect diagnosis. I agree with the current wording of the proposal for a new regulation, which aims to strengthen the process of monitoring in vitro diagnostic and post-marketing diagnostic devices, as well as the traceability of devices throughout the supply chain, and in addition to this support for research and innovation. bearing in mind patient safety, protection of life and health, which is our primary and highest goal. The implementation of the new legislation must be properly monitored by the European Commission, especially in the area of ​​professional genetic counseling, as we have called for in our parliamentary position. Neither the patient nor the consumer must be exposed to misleading information, or to misinterpretations of results or interpretations in such a sensitive area as health.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear co-rapporteurs, from a simple dressing to an artificial heart, including breast or hip prostheses, these medical devices are essential for our health and our daily quality of life. They occupy a central place in the European health economy - I think it is important to say this - and play a decisive role in our life expectancy, which continues to increase. This is a reality that should always be taken into account and this is the opportunity that this debate offers us. I remember being the co-rapporteur of a resolution in 2012: after the scandals of 2010 and 2012, it was absolutely necessary to ask the European Commission to offer us a protection mechanism. It is done after five years of victorious combat. Therefore, I thank Glenis Wilmott and Peter Liese, but also the European Commissioner, Mr Andriukaitis, for allowing us to offer a protective device to all Europeans.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! The introduction of changes to the law on medical devices and in vitro diagnostic devices was necessary not only to eliminate scandalous irregularities, but also to enable easier access of patients to modern technologies in medicine, which was not secured by the outdated twenty-year regulations. The introduction of the regime of unannounced inspections by legally strengthened notified bodies, assessing the compliance of the product with the applicable regulations, will probably improve the safety - especially of the highest risk products. It is a pity that there is no rule for producers to insure themselves, possibly due to possible increases in product prices. However, the positive thing is that the relevant authorities are obliged to provide injured parties with information regarding product malfunction, which is of great importance in the case of pursuing claims, along with proving the cause-and-effect relationship. I hope the document will be adopted.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Willmott and Mr Liese for the great work they have done and for the success achieved in negotiating these two reports. It has not been easy. It's almost five years since the original proposal put forward by the European Commission, and it has rained heavily since then. Five years of work and almost two years of tough negotiations between the Council, the Commission and the Parliament that lead us to be able to approve new rules on medical products that reflect the technological and scientific advances that the sector has had in the last twenty years . An agreement in favor of which we will vote tomorrow because it reflects what we want: more security for our citizens; more security both in controls after the approval of products and in the passports that all implants must carry in order to be properly monitored and traced; more security, greater transparency and faster response times, forcing Member States to take the necessary measures to empower healthcare professionals, users and patients to report suspected serious incidents at national level using forms harmonized. We want safer products that allow us to build a control and protection system that reinforces pre- and post-marketing controls, which is more transparent and prevents the recurrence of cases as serious as those of PIP breast implants, which affected thousands of women in Europe.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - Mr President, there have been several notorious scandals in recent years which have shown us that poorly applied legislation, when combined with negligence or even the crimes of some producers, can endanger the health and lives of patients. The defects of some HIV tests or of some hip prostheses, the PIP scandal with the implants that contained industrial type silicone, all these cases prove the urgent need to change the system that made them possible. Under these new rules, all medical devices, including those with an aesthetic role, will have to comply with the same standards in order to receive marketing authorization. High-risk devices will be subject to additional clinical trials. Unannounced mandatory inspections will deter irregularities, and stricter traceability measures will allow producers to improve their response in crisis situations. I would like to congratulate my colleagues on completing this legislation and on their work. I believe that it will play a very important role in increasing patient safety and reducing the risk of new scandals of this kind. Thank you.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - Thanks to the rapporteurs. Medical aids are indispensable in our daily life, especially when something goes wrong and the patient is about to become a patient again. Many of us owe our lives to medical devices: breast or hearing implants, artificial hips and viral tests make the lives of men and women in the Union healthier and we should be happy about that. And don't forget: they ensure a more pleasant and dignified life. Since the turn of the century we have been confronted with scandals, such as the PIP scandal. Breast implants have been found to leak dangerous silicone. I am therefore satisfied with the legislation reached by us as Parliament in negotiations with the Member States and the European Commission and under the Dutch Presidency. This legislation ensures better traceability, greater liability and accountability of producers. It also includes stricter rules for high-risk medical devices and, finally, a stricter assessment before and after the marketing of these products. The health of the citizen and user is again central. I am less satisfied with the much too slow legislative procedure with the Member States. However, the European Union must start to deliver faster results when it comes to public health. This legislation will not enter into force for three or five years, respectively. This legislation takes far too long. Not until ten to fifteen years after the big scandals. As Europe, we must start delivering fast results.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Mr. President, I can only thank and acknowledge the great work of Mrs. Willmott and Mr. Peter Liese in what I consider not only to solve the issue of sanitary and cosmetic products, but also to mark - or I suspect thatbrand — the future of overall patient safety.They have introduced such important concepts as the responsibility of the manufacturer, with sufficient financial coverage;they tend to eliminate and limit the use of toxins and carcinogens in these types of products, a clear improvement in traceability, post-commercial monitoring and, of course, patient information.In short, an excellent job for these products, but - as I say - I am very sure that it will also be the future of improving patient safety as a whole.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, medical devices cover a wide array of products, from sticking plasters to heart valves, to analytical laboratory equipment; all in all, about 500 000 devices in the EU market. The proposals here mainly focus on scrutiny of devices before they are placed on the market and their surveillance after becoming available as well as their traceability and the supply chains, and this is highly commendable. Proposals include stricter criteria for designating and monitoring notified bodies, adaptation of classification rules and streamlining of different assessment procedures. We must ensure a high level of health and safety protection for EU citizens using these products and must adapt the EU legislation to the significant technological and scientific progress in this sector over the last 20 years. I believe that with this text these goals will be achieved and I commend the rapporteurs Willmott and my colleague, Liese on their significant work in this regard. With this work, we will see stricter requirements for notified bodies who check the conformity of these products. This is important for consumers who rely on them for ensuring the highest standards for these products in the EU. Strengthened rules for high-risk devices are also welcome, as is the guidance and expertise to be provided by expert panels and laboratories on this issue. This is also important to ensure the utmost safety of products on the market. I am pleased with the inclusion of the enhanced system of traceability of devices along with post-market surveillance. I welcome the setting up of a central database. A good job well done by the rapporteurs.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank everyone who has helped us to take another very important step towards maximum patient safety. The legislation is complex, extensive and highly technical in nature. In the three-year transition period following the publication of the Medical Devices Ordinance, the regulatory authorities must deliver 80 implementing and delegated acts, 18 of which are mandatory. You need to develop and test the Eudamed online database. They need to set up new specialist advisory structures and new EU preference laboratories. You have to rename the notified bodies that are approved for the assessment of medical device dossiers. There are currently around 15 employees in the DG GROW and in the Joint Research Center available for this and a number of other tasks. As far as I understand, this group is planned to be about 40; 45 people, and it turns out that recruiting is apparently taking place quite slowly here. If we want to guarantee the highest level of patient safety, which we have set out to do today, then we must also guarantee that the necessary staff is available. I believe that even the targeted 45 people will not be able to fulfill this great task in terms of maximum patient safety.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, of course, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this important dossier: Mrs Willmott, the colleague from Great Britain, Peter Liese, but of course also Mairead McGuinness in our group. The PIP scandal shocked us all exceptionally a few years ago. With this legislation today, we are giving a large part of the answers that are necessary to ensure safety for patients on the one hand, but on the other hand not to unnecessarily complicate the incredible innovative potential of medical technology. A lot of difficult discussions were necessary and there was a lot of need for change, including the Commission's proposal. But we have succeeded in making the current end result of these discussions unbureaucratic - as unbureaucratic as it is possible with such complicated questions - while at the same time achieving more safety for the patients and not making the innovation aspect of the medical technology industry too difficult. An important element, which has also been mentioned occasionally, is now that implementation must be the same everywhere in Europe. That will improve the security of all Europeans. There will be no different implementation variants; we must attach importance to ensuring that it is implemented uniformly. Everywhere in Europe, the medical technology industry will ultimately have to be measured by a law. We need pragmatic solutions here, and we need flexible solutions that make it possible to ultimately bring this high innovation potential to the patients. In this respect, many thanks to everyone who contributed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the medical device scandals of recent years have highlighted the urgent need to remedy the obvious lack of legislation. Congratulations to the rapporteurs: the Union is finally equipping itself with a solid and transparent regulatory framework aimed at increasing the level of health protection of European citizens without hindering innovation. Among the most significant innovations are a special procedure for certain high-risk devices with an independent assessment by a group of experts, a clarification of the roles and obligations of all market players, a total ban on certain carcinogenic substances, mutagenic and toxic present in some devices subject to a series of exemptions and a comprehensive system of device traceability, vigilance and post-market surveillance to ensure constant monitoring and rapid reaction in case of problems. We have reached a good compromise. The new regulatory framework will make it possible to overcome the differences in implementation and ensure the safety of medical devices and their free movement in the internal market.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs as well, because they bring to the surface an issue that concerns the lives and health of the people. I also argue that before medical devices can be marketed, they must be proven to be safe. However, quality controls must be carried out on medical devices, as well as on medicines. Implants are not a parameter, but an essential element of the issue, given the well-known case with implants that was discovered some years ago in France. Disposable instruments need further thorough research. Legislation must also impose a surprise check. I close by repeating what I said at the beginning, that here we are talking about human life and health and we must be strict.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the need for every person to protect or restore their health has enabled profiteering in those involved in the production and exploitation of medical equipment and other related products. The cases of this corruption are many and unfortunately they are increasing, either because the states cannot control the situation or because they often tolerate it. The ultimate victims and recipients of this unacceptable situation, however, are the patients and those who use these materials, not only because they spend large sums on often defective materials, but also because their health is endangered. For this reason, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteurs of the new regulation because, among other things, they have provided for many, varied and strict controls on the industries and products produced and thus protect public health.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, when we talk about medical devices, we need to think about people and their security. In many cases, patients have suffered from the quality of these medical devices, and I am pleased that the rapporteurs have supplemented the Commission's proposal with the responsibility of producers, which was missing from the proposal. Post-market monitoring and surveillance are extremely important and the value of the report also lies in the fact that it provides for unannounced inspections. The new regulation sets out detailed provisions for the whole process, with clear rules. I appreciate that there is a provision for genetic counseling in cases where genetic testing is used. I would like to emphasize that this report introduces an improved overall system for device traceability and subsequent surveillance and constant monitoring for rapid reactions, because here we are talking about people's lives. I heard a colleague say that the certifications of the devices are too numerous. I believe that nothing is too numerous for the life and safety of patients and I want to congratulate Glenis and all the rapporteurs who worked for the extraordinary work on an extremely technical report, but extremely important in terms of the quality of the medical act and of patients' health. Thanks.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I truly believe that this is an important day for EU patients, medical society and industry – especially its innovative sectors – and for all EU citizens. Thank you all for making this happen.  We have set the conditions for Europeans to receive the safest and most reliable healthcare, and for the EU to remain at the forefront of innovation in the field. However, let me also add that the adoption of these two comprehensive texts represents only the beginning of a long and challenging process. We now need to make sure that the new system is effectively put on the ground and delivers the expected added value to all stakeholders. The Commission will continue to consider this dossier as an utmost priority. I am confident that with the support of the European Parliament, national authorities, patients and all the relevant operators, the challenge of the implementation of this new legal framework will be met successfully and, very importantly, in good time. I wish you all the best and thank you very much indeed.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you all for your support and comments. The medical devices industry is hugely important in the EU, with over 25 000 companies employing almost 600 000 people. That is a lot of people. Throughout our work on this legislation, we had in mind that we needed stronger rules to improve device safety and protect patients without stifling the innovation that is a key feature of the industry in Europe. I believe the agreement that we have reached strikes the right balance. This will strengthen requirements for medical devices, and require high-risk devices to undergo additional pre-market assessment. Stricter rules on post-market surveillance will also ensure a faster response if there is a problem with a device and a new ID system will improve traceability. It is clear that Member States will have to cooperate and share information, and the new EU-wide database EUDAMED will help them do that. And importantly, patients will have more information on the devices they use or are treated with. Unfortunately, we cannot go back in time and prevent past scandals from happening, but with this legislation, we can make them much less likely in the future. Patients rightly expect that if a device has been placed on the market, then it must be safe. But unfortunately this has not always been the case. We have a responsibility to make sure that patients can have confidence in the medical devices industry and I firmly believe that this is what the agreement we will be voting for this week will do. Once again, thank you to everyone who has helped us to get to this stage, and again in particular to all of our staff and the Group staff, who have worked their socks off on this. I hope we have strong support in the vote tomorrow, because at the end of the day, this is about the safety of patients across the EU, and nothing can be more important than that.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Rapporteur. - I would also like to thank you very much for the support that came from almost all of the speakers. I'm very glad about that. I would like to briefly address the critical voice from UKIP. Ms. Reid is unfortunately no longer there, that's why she can no longer hear it; but perhaps it can be brought to her. She said that it would be good if the Member States looked into the matter. I think we have to see clearly that if these products are traded in the internal market, then we will also have common standards of control. It is not that we have an open free market and that consumer health is not protected by common standards, and I believe UKIP and its allies will see the huge problems the people of Britain face if they do the internal market is no longer there at some point. Products are becoming more expensive, innovations from the rest of Europe may not come to the island so quickly, and you will still see what kind of crazy policy it is that the UKIP has again represented in the European Parliament today. We need these rules and we need the single market with high rules to protect human health. And then I would like to respond to one thing that many colleagues have said: Why did it take so long? 2012 was the PIP scandal, no, the European Commission made this proposal in 2012, the scandal was a little earlier. And it took us four and a half years. It's a difficult technical dossier. That's why you can't just negotiate between lunch and dinner. But we as Parliament passed a comprehensive opinion on all subjects in twelve months, and it then took the Council another two and a half years - unfortunately that is also the case with many other subjects. Europe doesn't have to worry about everything but if we have such problems, then the Council will have to speed up a bit in the future, and we should make a joint appeal to the Member States.Good legislation comes, but it comes too late.And in other areas, too, the Council will soon have to work a little faster so that we can solve the problems.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much.It has been a great pleasure to chair a debate like the one that is now ending.Let me note that there was not a single blue card appearance, which means that we all followed the same concern.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday 5 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The medical devices sector, representing more than 25 000 companies of which 95% are SMEs, has not only become an influencer on expenditure, but also increasingly important for the healthcare of EU citizens, covering a wide range of products, from simple bandages to heart valves, and the most sophisticated X-ray equipment. It helps improving the quality of life of citizens by providing innovative health care solutions regarding diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, treatment and alleviation. Since the existing regulatory framework dated back to the 1990s, only considering the advances of technology in the medical sector there was a stringent need for revision. The new regulations on medical and in-vitro diagnostic medical devices will help to ensure that all medical devices are safe and perform well, and will make sure that all medical and in vitro diagnostic devices are designed to reflect the latest scientific and technological state-of-the art, but also comply with EU patient safety and ethical requirements. The rules will also improve market surveillance and traceability, and provide more transparency and legal certainty for producers, manufacturers and importers and help to strengthen international competitiveness and innovation in this strategic sector. I strongly support the outcome reached.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: in writing. - Work on the modernization of regulations on medical devices, including those for in vitro diagnostics, started in 2012, and the current solutions in this regard were developed in the 1990s. Given the speed of technological progress and innovations in this field, the regulations required reality, which is confirmed by the developed regulations. During the works, the main goals of the regulations were: to ensure the safety of products sold in the EU and to increase access to innovative solutions so that they could effectively protect patients. We must remember that these products in many cases help diagnose and heal diseases, conditions and, very importantly, that thanks to their use we can prevent them. The catalog of medical devices and in vitro diagnostic devices is over 500,000. products that are available on the EU market. In order to avoid the scandals that we have dealt with in the past, when defective silicone breast implants, not meeting the standards, were implanted 300 thousand. women around the world, it is imperative to ensure the safety of this type of product. The most effective way is to control, identify and supervise medical devices during the entire life cycle of products. This will allow for decisive action and reaction in the event of problems that may have a negative impact on human life and health, which should be the greatest value.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Elena Valenciano and Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Development, on solutions for the movement of refugees and migrants: the role of EU external action (2015/2342 (INI)) (A8-0045)/ 2017).

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: speaker. -Mr. president. This is a very important debate because we talk about our external response to the phenomenon of migration and refugees, but in reality it is a debate that speaks a lot about us, about what we want the European Union to be, about what we believe the European Union should be. European Union. The truth is that I believe that this is no longer the time for rhetoric. A lot has happened. Today President Steinmeier spoke of courage. You probably have to give up rhetoric and instead deal with courage. The European Union is at a critical moment, without a doubt, and runs the risk of becoming even more self-contained. With the phenomenon of migration and refugees it has been completely overwhelmed. Overwhelmed by something we call a crisis. But it is not a crisis, because it will not end anytime soon. We must stop calling the movement of people fleeing the most absolute horror and who have only one thing, which is their right to be protected, a refugee crisis. We must stop calling the arrival of thousands of people a migratory crisis who do not choose on a whim to leave their home, country and family, but flee because they have no other choice. On the other hand, we can talk about another crisis. The crisis of European solidarity. That is a crisis. A lack of solidarity with those who come from outside and a lack of solidarity within with the partners themselves, between partners. We can also speak of an institutional crisis, because the European Council has been unable to fulfill its own commitments, which were already minimal commitments in hosting refugees. And we can also speak of a moral crisis, because we are more busy blocking the access of these people to our borders, even with spurious agreements, such as the agreement adopted with Turkey, or more interested in promoting returns than in alleviating the dramatic situation that all these people live inside and outside our borders. What reaches Europe is a small proportion of the harsh reality of displacement in the world, from countries much poorer than ours that host, multiplied by five and ten, this crisis that we call refugee. Our reaction has been irresponsible to say the least. Especially that of national governments. It has been short-term, myopic, they do not want to see that this phenomenon has come to stay. The report that we present is an own-initiative report and therefore does not require action by the Council and the Commission. But it is a voice, the voice of the European Parliament, the voice of the representatives of the citizens in the European Union. And this voice affirms that migratory phenomena cannot be understood as a threat, that we need a change of paradigm, of narrative, to make them something beneficial, as it has been throughout history. This is a battle that Democrats cannot lose and that we must fight without complexes in the face of a rising extreme right and a populism of the left and right that is clearly expanding. To do this we must overcome, says the report, an approach focused only on security to deal with human rights, to deal with integration, to ensure that these people have legal avenues of access to our countries. And so as not to always transfer responsibility to third parties. We are demanding that many countries that have much greater difficulties than us to take charge of something that we are not prepared to take charge of, and this Parliament cannot be ignored in this whole new strategy of agreements with third countries. We face a very serious credibility problem with our citizens and we have to respond to them to the extent that our values ​​require us to respond. I believe that it is a great step that the external action of the European Union will also deal with the phenomenon of migration and refugees. That is good news that we have to follow very closely.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: speaker. - Mr. President, first of all, I want to thank Mrs. Valenciano for her cooperative and rigorous work and her spirit of consensus. I want to start by approaching the report question correctly: we refer to the challenges posed by the flows of migrants and refugees and the external role of the Union. It is not, therefore, a report that focuses primarily on the inner dimension. An external dimension, Mr President, is of the utmost importance in tackling irregular migration and tackling its root causes, as was underlined at the Valletta Summit and at the last European Councils. Migration is a powerful development tool and, therefore, can contribute to socio-economic progress, as has historically been the case. Furthermore, it must be approached as a unique opportunity to transform migration into a key factor for sustainable and inclusive development. Therefore, I consider it essential that a positive narrative is used that promotes an authentic and objective understanding of the issue and the associated common benefits. That is why I very sincerely support the "Together" campaign launched by the United Nations to reduce negative perception and attitudes towards refugees and migrants. I call on the Union institutions to cooperate fully with the United Nations in support of this campaign. I would like to underline that the Union must respect its values ​​and principles in all common policies and promote them in its external relations, as established in Article 21 of the Treaty on the Union, which I am expressly going to cite, since I consider it of utmost importance for our purpose: «The Union's action on the international scene will be based on the principles that have inspired its creation, development and enlargement and which it intends to promote in the rest of the world: democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of the human rights and freedoms fundamental principles, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity and respect for the principles of the Charter of the United Nations and international law ”. Well yes, what is in crisis is management and what is in crisis is solidarity, nothing more. I specifically wanted to mention the solidarity of the Union and all its policies to emphasize that the Union's aid and cooperation must be unconditional and designed to achieve development and growth in third countries, thereby also promoting growth in the within the European Union itself, and all the more so since the Union is the world's largest donor. It is true that the humanitarian aid system is absolutely overwhelmed and therefore we need a comprehensive and more enduring approach to migration that includes promoting closer links between humanitarian and development fields to address this challenge, not forgetting that the primary objective of humanitarian aid is the eradication of poverty. I also want to emphasize the empowerment of the role of women and their greater participation in decision-making processes at all migration stages. In addition, I ask for greater protection for the most vulnerable, such as the aforementioned women, minors, people with disabilities, the elderly and LGBTI people, and, in particular, that they all be granted unique help and greater protection humanitarian aid and that they are facilitated access to resident status and basic services, including health care and education. Following the doctrine of the United Nations at the high-level Summit in September, I consider it essential to achieve safe, orderly and regular migration. For this, we must intensify our cooperation with the United Nations, giving a fundamental role to UNHCR, the new resettlement program of the European Union. We also need to fight against smugglers who profit from the vulnerability of migrants, and greater protection of the Union's external borders is important.I would like to condemn and denounce the terrible numbers of deaths at sea, and I want to express my concern for the missing children and demand that the Union and the States assume their responsibility to achieve a global and multilateral response based on international cooperation and synergiesto respond to these present and future challenges.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, allow me to stand in for the High Representative, Vice-President of the Commission, Ms Mogherini, in this very important debate. First of all let me thank you for this report, as well as for your strong support for our work and in particular for the partnership framework approach. The partnership framework approach and your report are based on the same idea: isolation cannot solve the challenges of our time. We need to engage with our partners, build new channels for cooperation with them. And this is particularly true on the issue of migration. I cannot but subscribe to all relevant recommendations in your report. Never forget that this is about human beings, so respect for human beings and human rights must come first. Work on both short-term fixes and long-term solutions is important. Tackle the root causes of irregular migration and forced displacement and work for political and diplomatic solutions to conflicts. Engage not only bilaterally but also at the global, regional and local level. This is the cornerstone of our work with third countries on migration. Following our debate in February, let me first of all debrief you on our work on the central Mediterranean. All services involved, namely the EEAS, Commission services and Council, are working hand in hand together with the Presidency and Member States on the implementation of the Malta Summit declaration.  It goes without saying that our overall primary objective remains the stabilisation of Libya. The terrible situation of migrants trapped in the hands of militias is only one, albeit important, part of the broader difficulties the country is facing. An effective and sustainable long-term response to the migration challenge in the central Mediterranean cannot be found without a lasting solution to Libya’s governance and security challenges. At the same time we cannot wait for the crisis in Libya to be over: too many people risk their lives every day to cross the Mediterranean, too many live in terrible conditions inside the country. Work is being intensified on all levels as regards more immediate and medium-term migration-related actions. Firstly we are stepping up our support for implementing partners, in particular the International Organisation for Migration and the UNHCR. We aim at improving the situation at disembarkation points and inside detention centres. But our cooperation can achieve much also on assisted voluntary returns; according to IOM’s analysis, 80% of migrants present in Libya are willing to return back to their countries of origin if they are given a safe and dignified opportunity to do so. Secondly we have started to facilitate a common approach between Libya, Chad and Niger to better manage Libya’s southern borders. The objective is to disrupt the smugglers’ business and provide assistance to migrants who are stranded, vulnerable or willing to return back home, before they embark on hazardous journeys through the desert. Thirdly we continue our support to the Libyan coastguard through Operation Sophia and through our Seahorse programme in terms of training, to put Libya in a condition to manage its territorial waters. Last but not least community stabilisation, providing support to Libyans as well as migrants, is also an important element under the EU support package for Libya. Let me in this context highlight the interconnection between our work on various fronts and in particular between our work in Libya, the partnership framework approach and the Valletta process. As clearly shown in our third progress report on the partnership framework adopted on 2 March, the approach is the right one and needs to be further consolidated. As part of this partnership we are engaging strongly with countries of transit like Niger. In parallel we are working with the countries of origin of irregular migration, aiming also at developing cooperation on return and readmission. This is, however, indispensable to address the root causes of the irregular migration flows reaching the European Union, and to discourage further migrants from embarking on dangerous journeys through the desert or at sea at the mercy of smugglers and traffickers. In this context it is paramount to ensure the political engagement of our partners to support our work with their own political strategic choices, and with reforms for the prosperity of their countries. In that regard the European External Investment Plan will be fundamental not only for the major impact that private investments might have for economic development, job creation and growth; the plan also offers the necessary technical assistance to identify and implement reforms for good governance, security and transparency. I do count on this House to continue working speedily towards the final adoption of the investment plan. Let me now come back to the partnership framework and share with you the progress achieved with the five priority countries. Niger represents a prominent example of successful cooperation on migration. The authorities are engaging proactively in the fight against human smuggling, in particular in the Agadez hub. This is crucial as Niger is a transit country of migratory flows towards Libya. Results are there, with a considerable decline of flows through Agadez. We need now to stabilise this positive result by enhancing our support to the local communities which are accepting to abandon the smuggling business and expand Niger’s model of the fight against migrant smuggling to other countries of transit in the Sahel region. This is key also to addressing the possible deviation of the smuggling routes, an issue that we are closely monitoring, including by putting in place a better system of information sharing. Our dialogue with Mali is on track. We will soon meet with Malian authorities to discuss possible areas of cooperation to stem the business of traffickers and smugglers of migrants. These include enhancing Mali’s cooperation with neighbouring countries such as Niger, which the Malian Minister for Malians Abroad visited recently. Furthermore the projects we have approved under the EU trust fund for Africa will allow IOM to deploy activities in several parts of Mali to facilitate the voluntary return of migrants transiting Mali to their countries and the cooperation with border posts. Senegal remains a trusted partner and we see positive developments. The Senegalese side has recently taken further steps in the right direction and we expect some concrete results very soon. Ethiopia has also adopted a constructive approach in regional and continental dialogues with the European Union on migration as current Chair of the Khartoum process. Its contribution, together with Mali, was important to the successful outcome of the Valletta senior official meeting last February. Finally, dialogue and political cooperation with Nigeria has been stepped up significantly, although work is still needed with this country which represents the main origin of the irregular migration flows reaching the Mediterranean. This challenge we can only manage together and I am glad that our approach, based on migration compacts, has also become the international approach at the last United Nations General Assembly. The cooperation and experience acquired with the partnership frameworks is something we intend to bring as an EU input in the follow-up to the General Assembly during the six informal consultations that are to be held in New York, Geneva and Vienna.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. - Madam President, this new report on migration follows on from previous ones, in particular the one for which I was rapporteur, namely the report on human rights and migration in third countries, adopted in October latest. Thank you to the rapporteurs. As rapporteur for the opinion, I welcome the fact that many of the concerns of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) have been taken into account. However, we could have gone further in the holistic approach, in an approach based on internal policies by which the Member States would set an example in terms of respect for the rights of migrants, whatever their status. The absolute urgency is legal channels, including economic and labor immigration, regardless of the country of origin. In 2015, 500,000 new visas were issued in the European Union to Ukrainians. Good for them. Of these 500,000 visas, 90% were issued in Poland, 75% were work visas and 53% were visas for employment in the European Union. So why, at the same time, are we closing the door to those who come from the South, Syria, the Horn of Africa? Why do we obsess over sending them home, preventing them from leaving? Two weights, two measures. Only objective criteria will allow the European Union to have a coherent policy based on facts and not on fantasies which fuel fear and rejection of the other. Member States are moving further away from it.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the two co-rapporteurs Ms. Elena Valenciano and Mr. Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra for this comprehensive report which places the European Union and its partners in front of their responsibilities . Faced with this migratory phenomenon, unprecedented in its scale and complexity, Europe must provide adequate responses and act with clarity, efficiency and consistency. This report emphasizes several points of the Union's external action which I consider essential. First of all, the European Union and the Member States must confirm their political commitment to tackle the root causes of migration and forced displacement. We must strengthen the commitments made with our partners, for example on the Emergency Trust Fund, and focus our action, inter alia, on economic resilience, poverty reduction and security in third countries. Then, with regard to the Union's international partnerships, we must on the one hand step up our support to the countries of first reception which play a key role in responding to migratory pressures, like the Western Balkans or the Lebanon and Jordan. Socio-economic and judicial cooperation with countries of origin and transit must also be encouraged, within the framework of a balanced dialogue. In this spirit, monitoring the operational implementation of the Rabat and Khartoum processes is essential. On the other hand, we must continue our work of collaboration with multilateral bodies and NGOs which provide their expertise and support European action on a global scale. It is essential to continue to mobilize all stakeholders in the management of this phenomenon. Finally, I welcome the fact that this report gives an important place to the fight against human tragedies. faced by refugees and migrants.Human trafficking, violence and abuse are too many when we talk about all these victims forced to move.It is necessary to oppose a reaction on our part.(The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Ms. President!Special thanks to Mrs Representative for her intention to respond.I would ask two questions, both very simple.One is how much do you believe in the credibility of the European Union in negotiating with partner countries, when the position on the refugee issue is extremely diverse within the European Union?For example, in my country, Hungary, the Fidesz government, the Orbán government, which is sitting in your ranks, is specifically imprisoning refugees.How do you experience this in the People's Party?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: answer "blue card".- First of all, in the interpretation, there was only one question: is the European Union credible when dealing with migrants?I would like to say one thing: Credibility means making commitments in Brussels and then implementing them at national level, taking united and common actions for all Member States, and speaking with one voice on the international stage.If we have more concrete and adequate instruments to be able to meet this challenge, then we will gain credibility.Yes, the European Union has everything to gain if this credibility is accompanied by the elements I have just outlined.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, first of all I want to thank the two rapporteurs, Mrs Valenciano and Mr Díaz de Mera, not only for the report, but for their intervention here this afternoon. To assess the report I think it is good to put some data in context. Last week we learned that there have been around five million Syrian refugees, a very important part of the population of this country. But in the world there are sixty million refugees as a cause of conflict. If the war in Syria is resolved - and hopefully soon - we will continue to have tens of millions of refugees in the world. 1,200,000 people came to the European Union and had to be taken over by 28 countries and 500 million inhabitants. Lebanon, whose area is equivalent to the Alsace region in which we meet today, has 1.5 million refugees. Therefore, the crisis is not the number of refugees that have arrived. The crisis is the management of hatred, of the indifference with which we have treated those migrants or refugees fleeing war or hunger. The report has medium and short-term responses. And the first is to change the narrative: migration or the refugee is not a risk. It is a risk to mismanage it. And managing it badly is responding exclusively with walls, with barbed wire, with repression, with neglect of human rights. Managing it well is contributing to the development of those countries that force them to emigrate due to lack of opportunities and not as an option to improve their lives. Managing it well is offering legal avenues and humanitarian visas. And managing it well means respecting all their human rights when they arrive on Union lands.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, in 2015 over one million people arrived on Europe’s shores by irregular means. These people have fled war, famine, repressive dictatorships, economic hardship or a mixture of all of those combined. Their arrival has clearly sparked a huge debate in our societies as to where it is right to draw the line between compassion to those seeking a better life versus our actual political and financial capabilities to provide such relief. I am convinced personally that, in many respects, the Geneva Convention is ill—suited to the modern globalised world, and that reform is vital if we are to maintain support for its key tenets of providing temporary safe haven to those most in need. Rather than seeking to offer opportunities to the few that reach Europe, the majority is better served by support for economic and political developments in the countries that they are leaving.  The Valletta Action Plan recognises this and I welcome the EEAS’s efforts to support state—building and development goals. Furthermore, its efforts to secure readmission agreements with third countries like Turkey, and support for the CSDP naval Operation Sophia Mediterranean against people smugglers, are also very welcome, to stop illegal migration to Europe. Europe’s neighbours are seeing a rapid population increase, a lack of job creation and, in Africa in particular, are increasingly troubled by future effects of climate change. Clearly more needs to be done to defend Europe’s external borders, but we cannot ignore, nor insulate ourselves from, the reasons that are pushing people to leave their homes in the first place.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Commissioner, I am very pleased with this report which calls for a truly European approach to asylum and migration issues. That is what European citizens rightly ask of us. That is also what we should do. In 2017 we can no longer tolerate that people have and give their whole lives to people smugglers to go to sea in rickety boats, and that children, women and men drown daily, weekly. This is unworthy of Europe. That is why we in the ALDE Group are very happy with this report. It contains crucial things: strengthen external borders. Work on a genuine European asylum and migration application. Rethink the Dublin system. Make a real division, in solidarity with Europe. Tackle the people smugglers, but also: work on economic migration. Work on that blue card so that we can admit the people we need. Tackle the people smugglers hard and inexorably. We also discussed it here in plenary yesterday. That is one point that I will definitely keep stressing on behalf of the ALDE Group. We must also focus on ending the conflicts, on the fight against extreme poverty. Make sure that people do not have to flee their home front. To be honest, Commissioner, if I had been born in Syria today, I would also be on one of those rickety dinghies on the way to a better life. And I think you are with me in that rickety dinghy. So we have to work on that. You said it, end those conflicts, that's what we have to do. Finally, very important: focus on the protection of unaccompanied children. You know, sometimes I wonder how much longer we have to see those images. I think when my children grow up, they will ask: Mommy were you really so blind and deaf in Europe that you didn't do anything? Let's do it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, with this report they intend to wash the image of an unsupportive and cruel European Union. It is a joint report signed by Mrs. Valenciano and Mr. Díaz de Mera - Grupo S & amp; D and Grupo PPE. In this report, which is not legislative and does not mark European policy, they ask for legal and safe routes and humanitarian visas; but later, in the same report, they support deportations, the militarization of the Mediterranean, the intervention of NATO and the externalization of borders. And, what is worse: in the reports that are legislative, in the European Commission and in the Council, which is where it is really decided, their parties do not support the opening of legal channels and do not support humanitarian visas, but everything contrary. On the first anniversary of the "deal of shame" with Turkey, they are celebrating it by negotiating similar deals with Egypt, Tunisia, Libya and Nigeria, and blackmailing them with development aid. What the Government of Spain is directly negotiating is an agreement with Morocco to deport minors. Mrs. Valenciano, Mr. Díaz de Mera, in the report they appeal to human rights, but in their government action in Ceuta and Melilla, some put concertinas and others shoot in El Tarajal. Paper holds everything, but we see the consequences of its policies at the borders, the consequences of the policies of the grand coalition that today, here, you two represent perfectly. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: "blue card" question.- Fortunately, in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, not all the members of the GUE / NGL Group responded like Mrs Albiol.I am going to ask you a question, to see if you have an answer to this: how is it possible that her vote coincides with the vote that the extreme right of this House has expressed?That is to say, his vote coincides with that of the National Front, with Golden Dawn and with the Polish friend that we have cast out.Can you explain it to me?

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr. Díaz de Mera, I am going to give the floor to Mrs. Albiol Guzmán to respond and then I will answer you.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: "blue card" response.- Mrs Valenciano, we are going to vote against this report because what we want is to open borders.We want solidarity.We want to welcome refugees.The extreme right votes against just the opposite.The worrying thing is that you, who are from the S&D Group, and the PPE Group vote the same because they defend the same policies.We defend just the opposite of the extreme right.There is no group in this House that fights the extreme right and fascism more than the GUE / NGL Group.None!(Comment without microphone by Díaz de Mera García Consuegra)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Señor Díaz de Mera, I know.You also want to ask Mrs. Albiol Guzmán a "blue card" question.I have said before, like my colleague Sassoli at the beginning, that there would only be one 'blue card' per intervention.Won't she?Excuse me, what was she saying?

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - I'm not asking for a 'blue card'.I am asking for an answer by allusions.I am asking, based on the provisions of the House Rules, an answer for allusions.I am not asking for a "blue card."

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr. Díaz de Mera, the answer by allusions can only be given at the end of the debate or you can present it in writing.That is the norm we have here;so I can give you the floor at the end of this debate or you put it in writing.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Madam President, this is a point of order.It is a point of order and you must listen to what I have to say to you.I am addressing the presidency of the House.Look, ma'am, the interpretation of the Rules of Procedure ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: No, I'm sorry, Mr. Díaz de Mera, you don't have the microphone open now.I have told you that if you want to respond by allusions, you can do so at the end of this debate or in writing.Those are the two rules there are;there is no other way, sorry.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
