text: –Don't feel anything, listen to me.This is a Chamber for dialogue and debate.It is not a Chamber for the imposition of the presidency.Listen to me.Do you want to listen to me or not?

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr. Díaz de Mera, I have listened to you.This is nothing that I impose on you: these are the rules we have here.If you want to respond by allusions - for the third time I am telling you - you can do so, in accordance with Article 164 of the Rules of Procedure, at the end of this debate or you can also do so in writing.Those are the rules.I'll give you the floor later.Sorry, that's right.We will continue with the debate.We are not going to have a discussion you and I here.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, our group supports this excellent report by Mr Valenciano and Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra. It emphasizes the need now, above all, for a strong common EU immigration policy based on human rights. This common immigration policy must be based on solidarity between Member States and must also have legal channels for safe immigration. It is excellent that the report also highlights the need for a long-term development policy so that people do not have to leave their homes. Unfortunately, we are seeing an increasing emphasis in the Member States of the European Union, based on the promotion of border control, the return of refugees and also readmission agreements. This is a very short-sighted and inhumane policy. The following happened in Finland last night: From there, a plane left Helsinki-Vantaa Airport for Kabul, where there were ten asylum seekers who had been forcibly returned and had received a negative decision. People took a really strong position that the police had illegally picked up an 11-year-old girl from school, and this one, along with her father and pregnant mother, could also have gotten on this flight if civic activists had not intervened. This is unacceptable.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Mr. Díaz de Mera García Consuegra!I would like to explain the rule to you again.According to Rule 164, if you have been addressed personally, you can make a personal statement at the end of each debate.Either I will do it myself or whoever follows me.Or, in accordance with Rule 162 (11), you can also make a written declaration of no more than 200 words on this debate - once per session, that is, once this week.That in order to explain in detail my answer to your request to take part in the debate earlier.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if the length of a report indicates the importance of the issue, we must say that, of course, the problem of the migration crisis we are facing is certainly at the heart of the European debate. We appreciate, in this report, the attention paid to the root causes of migration, which are those on which, in our opinion, the EU should focus: the call for European solidarity, the request for the strengthening of legal access routes, as well as the criticism of the migration compact, the criticisms of the self-styled EU-Turkey agreement and the joint EU-Afghanistan action. As paragraph 59 points out, EU assistance and cooperation should be unconditional and targeted in order to achieve the development and growth of third countries. In reality, however, we often see that these agreements, which are often not even under parliamentary scrutiny, far from providing unconditional support, are instead very conditional, and these conditions have a lot to do with the ability of third countries to stop migratory flows, with greater border control. In this way, if it is true that the trade-off seems apparently advantageous, in reality the earthenware pot becomes the individual, who is reduced to a mere statistical data and benchmark for the administration of help. From this point of view, therefore, unfortunately, we must criticize the action taken so far.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few days after the decision of the 27 to indicate immigration and security as the first point, Austria already declares that it wants to withdraw from the relocation and, immediately afterwards, Budapest clarifies that, should the commitment with Turkey be canceled , Hungary will stop migrants thanks to the wall and the new laws passed. At the same time, the Visegrád quartet denounces the blackmail of the European Union, what it calls the blackmail of the European Union on migrants, and this is not mentioned here. As if everyone agrees with your immigration policy. Meanwhile - Frontex source - what emerges about the situation of trafficking from Libya? The High Commissioner or whoever replaces him tells us nothing. It emerges - Frontex source - that the activity of NGO ships has increased from 5 to 40%, and at the end of 2016 the direct interventions of NGOs exceeded those of calls to the operations room of the military naval forces. And the report assumes the existence - I repeat: the Frontex report - of collusion with the ferrymen. This is investigated by the judiciary and police, the Italian SCO. And you don't tell us, you don't talk about it, as if this didn't exist. It is a very serious fact. And so I ask for less hypocrisy and more truth about these trades. Enough with the trafficking of immigrants, enough with those who speculate on the plight of immigrants! You should talk to us about this, and be ashamed of your guilty silence.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, over time, the flow of migration, legal and illegal, to the countries of the European Union is constantly increasing instead of decreasing. The European Union's misguided policy towards a Europe without borders has given the peoples of Asia, the Middle East and Africa the right to see the European Union as a land of promise which they must reach by all means and by all means. But this trend must stop. The European Union and especially the countries of entry, Italy and especially Greece, do not have the capacity to absorb other illegal immigrants. Lives must not be lost in the Mediterranean, immigrants must not live in poverty in reception centers in Greece. The people of Europe must live in freedom and dignity and in accordance with their principles in their own countries. It does not mean trying to integrate into our countries people who do not want to join them, but instead want to dominate. We must not endanger the security of Europe for the sake of a general and abstract concept of solidarity. We must control the borders, we must strengthen the countries of the external neighborhood to keep the migrants there, we must stop the causes that lead to migration and, finally, we must force Erdoğan not to threaten to flood Europe with three million illegal immigrants.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! The number of refugees has increased by more than 50% in the last five years and the migrant crisis is a situation of unprecedented magnitude that has called into question our ability to act at European, national and local levels. The internal and external policies of the Union must be more coherent in this respect and cover foreign affairs, security, trade, development, humanitarian aid and, of course, the issue of migration. In this context, it is important to distinguish between refugee and migrant status. In international cooperation, we must focus primarily on the root causes of migration, i.e. armed conflicts, violations of human rights, poverty or discrimination and marginalization of certain social groups, and effectively counteract them. It should also be remembered that a prudent and coherent development policy is based on the assumption that partner countries are responsible for efforts to improve the internal situation. The link between the positive conditionality of development aid and the issues of good governance, respect for human rights and democratic values ​​should be strengthened. It is also a major challenge to combat trafficking in human beings, including children, and organized crime related to the migration and refugee crisis more effectively, and this requires better coordination between the European Union and other international actors.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The people who flee to us have experienced terrible things, have traveled thousands of kilometers, and first of all they deserve our respect and our help - nothing else. If we shared this burden that comes with it, it would be easier for everyone. It is no coincidence that not even a janitor from the council building is here today at this debate. But if we also have to admit that we cannot do this without limits, so to speak, because a society has to endure it, then we have to seriously consider how to reduce these refugee flows. No wall, no fence, not even if we symbolically build them up somewhere in Africa instead of here, will prevent the refugees from coming to us. If we do not help to eliminate the causes of flight, more and more will come to us and no one will be able to blame them. Development cooperation is not only important because we want to create more justice in the world, it is in our best interests. If we don't want more people to come because hunger doesn't allow them to do anything else - poverty, fear of dictatorship and war - then we have to act. That costs money and that is why the Member States must also meet their obligations. Let me say one last sentence. We, as a parliament, can also ensure that the situation gets better by ending our poverty-promoting policies. We no longer have to subsidize our exports and ……… do something against poverty and displacement. (The speaker speaks briefly without a microphone.)

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Madam President! When you read the proposal for a common refugee and asylum policy for Europe, which is on the table here today, the most positive thing I can say is that I am glad that Denmark has an exception in this area. The consequence of the proposals contained in this report is that an already uncontrollable flow of immigration and immigration to Europe will only become even greater, even more unmanageable. It is almost incomprehensible to understand how one can believe that embassy asylum, the right to seek asylum, come to Europe and seek asylum in the immediate area will in any way alleviate the situation we already have today, where more than one million people has come here in both 2015 and 2016. Add to that the burden of now allowing people to seek asylum in the immediate area, considering that we in Europe can not even deal with the people who come illegally and illegally today . It is simply so far removed from the reality experienced in the European nation-states that it can only be devised by the European Parliament. This is precisely the reason why the common asylum policy for Europe will never work. We are too unrealistic, too unrealistic in this house.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, when immigration into the European Union began to escalate two years ago, we should have immediately sought to control it by addressing its root causes. For too long, immigration has been dealt with mainly as an internal issue in the Council of Ministers for the Interior and Justice, on the one hand, and in Parliament's LIBE Committee, on the other. The report before us also focuses too much on home affairs and justice, but it certainly also draws attention to how the foreign service can influence the causes of immigration. The Foreign Service can and must seek peaceful solutions to violent conflicts that give rise to migration. The reform of the Instrument for Stability and Peace, which is currently being discussed in Parliament's committees, will contribute to this. Migration can and must be curbed by eradicating poverty and promoting economically, socially and environmentally sustainable development. In this, the Foreign Service has a key role to play both in implementing long-term development policy and in channeling humanitarian aid. Refugee camps set up outside Europe must be supported and new ones set up in cooperation with partner countries and relevant UN organizations. At the same time, efforts must be made to enable the residents of the refugee camps to return to their homeland as soon as possible. The integration of those who have been granted asylum must, of course, be continued, and the granting of asylum to those who are entitled to it must also be continued. Finally, I would like to thank Commissioner Mimica for his good speech, in which he said and showed how the Commission has taken quite effective action to manage this migration.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: - Madam President, the Agreement between the European Union and Turkey has been a disaster for the thousands of people who have been stranded in dangerous, desperate and seemingly endless limbo on the Greek islands. I'm not saying it, Amnesty International says it. We are not concerned about the European Union-Turkey Agreement, as the report mentions. We reject it, without ambiguity and without fissures. Let's not be hypocrites: you are what you vote and what you do and not just what you say. Now it also seems that the Migration Cooperation Agreement with Libya must be justified, where there are systematic human rights violations, police brutality and degrading conditions for migrants. A model of externalization of borders that is imposed in Europe, but that the Governments of the Socialist Party and the Popular Party inaugurated precisely with Morocco, selling to our Sahrawi brothers. Likewise, it justifies and is committed to NATO interventions in migration matters, justifying a strong Europe, which, by the way, is the political fuel for the rise of the extreme right in Europe. While thousands of people continue to die in the Mediterranean, the humanitarian aid of many NGOs dedicated to search and rescue in the Mediterranean is now criminalized, reaching where the European institutions do not and do not want to. I take this opportunity precisely to request the amendment of Directive 2002/90 / EC, which criminalizes humanitarian aid. We are not going to be and do not want to be accomplices by action or omission of this fortress Europe.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: - Madam President! We Greens largely support this report. It calls for safe and legal access routes for refugees and the protection of migrants' rights. We support the criticism of an EU policy that focuses excessively on border protection and returns, as well as the criticism of the EU-Turkey deal and the latest developments in US migration policy. We Greens also demand that development policy should not be instrumentalized for direct migration control. In December, the United Nations also asked the EU to fulfill its obligations towards refugees and migrants, for example by creating legal access routes and urgently improving the European asylum law and asylum system. The instruments for combating the causes of flight, such as conflict prevention and mediation, are listed in the report, but unfortunately only play a subordinate role. The countries from which most of the refugees come to us are Afghanistan, Iraq, Eritrea and now Syria. These have remained more or less the same countries for the past 20 years. People are fleeing from there because war, violence and oppression threaten their lives. Therefore, in this report, too, a stronger focus on conflict prevention and conflict resolution would have made sense in our opinion. Thank you very much again to the rapporteurs for this report, and yes, other EU reports have different EU policies.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, when regulated correctly, migration assists a nation’s economic standing. When there is no proper control, many question the sustainability of a system that effectively hinders the low-paid through the suppression of wages in the unskilled labour market. The 2004 enlargement of the European Union was that catalyst. Honesty must now prevail. Free movement has proved to be a failure for many, with the blame falling firmly at the feet of those still trying to enforce this ideal.  Moving onto this report, it condemns the restrictions and prohibitions on persons leaving or returning that are imposed in certain states – even if that person is a jihadist returning from Syria. Seriously? In addition, it calls on national governments and parliaments to abolish punitive legal frameworks that treat migration as an offence. Madam President, it must be for national governments to have the right to put their own migration policies in place, not the European Union.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!Italy once had an agreement with Libya.This was true until a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights in 2012, which made the principle of non-refoulement a fundamental problem in today's migration crisis.Italy is now picking up the refugees off the coast of Libya, and the cause of this migration and refugee crisis, namely the monetary incentives granted by the EU states for these refugees, does not have other countries, such as Australia.The solution to this should now be to ultimately legalize illegal entry - legal channels for illegal entry.Ladies and gentlemen, please be consistent!If you do not expect the refugees to travel illegally, do not expect them to travel legally either, help them on the spot.It's cheaper, it's more effective.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, the Union's external action to tackle migration flows must strike a balance between two strategies: prohibition and deterrence. Just as every independent state has a strong armed force with a deterrent and defense role, so the Union must align itself accordingly. In this sense, its policy must be based on three pillars: banning the entry of illegal immigrants from the external borders, readmission of all those who have entered illegally and preventing immigration, with financial and logistical assistance to third countries and at the same time imposing a clause on objectives and commitments to address the root causes of migration, ie political, economic, developmental, social and humanitarian. Any short-term approach to the situation will only exacerbate the problem and lead to a further waste of Union resources.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs and say that this is a global problem that also requires a global approach. I believe that with some exceptions from Member States, saying that the European Union is a Union that is unsupportive does not correspond to reality. In the years 2015, 2016 and 2017, the European Union has mobilized 17 billion euros, has created the European Fund for Sustainable Development or the Trust Fund for Africa. The European Commission's Green Paper on demographic change says that Europe is the only continent that is going to lose population in net terms between now and 2035, approximately 30 million people. This figure must be put in line with the 244 million immigrants and 65 million refugees. For this reason, Madam President, what must be done is to try to manage migratory flows adequately, as proposed in this report, and, in accordance with the European Agenda on Migration, preserve the dignity and rights of migrants, taking into account the suppressing that dramatic event that Mr. Díaz de Mera has told us about, of the terrible deaths that occur in the Mediterranean, and properly managing the almost 100 billion that are foreseen in the Financial Perspectives of the European Union for foreign policy and of aid and development cooperation, going to the relocation of causes and looking for associations that seek development, dignity and progress, especially of the youngest - I finish, Madam President - which will be more than 1 billion in the year 2030 in Africa.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us start with a principle which should be fundamental: if someone claims to be a refugee, they must be listened to. But there are countries, by contrast, from the United States to Australia, which are delivering potentially devastating messages. Europe is also not immune to these messages. There are 65 million refugees in the world, very few are in Europe, most are in third countries or in neighboring countries. Yet in this continent of ours, which should be the cradle of freedom and rights, a conflict is open around migrants and refugees, a wrong and dangerous conflict, but which has two fundamental reasons. The first: there are political forces that have exploited the different, and this political use of refugees has been lethal for reception. Let's take family reunification, which is a fundamental ethical principle, yet in Europe it is now very difficult to have legislation in this sense. The second reason: it is precisely the disorganization, the lack of cooperation and solidarity between the various countries of the Member States that have made migration a non-governed phenomenon and therefore preparatory to the spread of fears that run through public opinion. There are serious political and moral responsibilities. Hence the urgency of a change of approach. The motion for a resolution - and I thank Elena Valenciano and Agustín Díaz for what they have done - aims to write a new page, which recognizes the central role of human rights and the dignity of people. This is the right direction, and I hope the Commission and the Council will be able to listen.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: - Madam President, migrants and refugees need our full support, but the European Union, unfortunately, is proving to be insufficient. The deficits of the Common Foreign and Security Policy that make the Schengen borders perforated, do not protect non-Schengen countries and, above all, do not protect the unfortunate migrants and refugees are clear. A common immigration and asylum policy is needed to share the burden fairly between Member States. We need solidarity between us and the support of countries that bear the burden of refugees. A review of development policy and control over the allocation of resources to developing countries is needed. Joint economic, diplomatic and military targeting is needed to resolve conflicts in the European neighborhood. And, above all, more care is needed for the particularly vulnerable, such as young and unaccompanied children, the sick, the elderly, the mentally ill, the disabled, all those among the refugees. There will be an escalation of the problem after the expected transformation of Turkey into an authoritarian state on April 16th. In Turkey, the European Union's policy is proving to be completely wrong.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, migration and asylum flows are at record highs and there is no end in sight. It is crucial to consider all EU instruments available to prevent conflict, help development and protect people’s rights. We cannot only look at emergency measures but must invest in mid- to long-term goals. Yet there is a dangerous trend to instrumentalise the EU’s foreign policy altogether for ‘managing migration’.  The agreement with Turkey as well as the clones of this arrangement are not addressing the needs of asylum seekers and migrants or our own commitments under international law and the EU treaties. While neighbourhood funding to Libya is halted because the country is too unstable to deal with, there are efforts to outsource migration management to this very same country. That does not add up, and such shortcuts will come back as a boomerang. If the EU does not uphold international law and universal human rights, who will? Countering terrorism and managing migration must not be an excuse to forget about principles.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Madam President! I welcome the fact that my colleagues Valenciano and Díaz de Mera have taken a positive starting point in this report. But I am very concerned about how the Council and the Commission in a rather one-eyed way choose to mobilize foreign policy instruments, aid instruments, trade policy and even military means, all to keep people from fleeing. It is not sustainable - it is not morally sustainable, and it is not politically sustainable. Using military operations and shameful deals with third countries such as Turkey as border guards is a dead end. We will not make such shameful agreements, and, as has been said before, we will not make agreements with Libya, the Libyan militia, either. I want to see a Europe that develops its capacity to receive refugees. We will increase development assistance, as has been said here before, where the focus will be on poverty reduction, gender equality, education and health. We must be an actor that cooperates with the UN for development and faith in the future, as has been said by the rapporteurs. And we must, last but not least, create legal routes, something that I work with within the framework of resettlement. It's time to make a U-turn.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Madam President, the European Union must gain credibility in the debate on refugees. A credibility today touched by an excessive focus on security, by an agreement between the Member States and Turkey at the limit of international law, by the rejection of some States of resettlement quotas and by the shame that the Mediterranean is the biggest grave maritime world. People will continue to flee from crimes against humanity, from crushing inequalities, from the effects of climate change. In the best of cases, we can only mitigate mass displacement by tackling the roots of injustice and conflict. This is where the Union's external action must be directed, without forgetting that, out of solidarity, but also out of self-interest, we must keep the doors and minds of Europe open. I come from a European country, Catalonia, where, last February, 160,000 people took to the streets to claim to be able to host refugees under the motto "Casa nostra is casa vostra." This is the Europe of solidarity and responsibility that must defeat the Europe of the walls.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Madam President! Today, we are discussing a report with two rapporteurs from Spain, a country that has been saved by the EU several times and a country that has upgraded its infrastructure with the help of redistributed tax money from Sweden and other net contributors in the EU. If we were to discuss the problem of migration in a report, it would be good if it did not contain untruths such as "Europe would die if there were no migration to Europe". A pragmatic and democratic debate cannot be based on false claims. Among other things, we in Sweden pay for the migrants, and the costs can not only be measured in direct costs. It is now absolutely necessary for the whole of Europe to take a long break in migration reception. For Sweden, this is absolutely necessary, and the EU cannot force Sweden to receive more. We have invested tens of billions of euros in this and paid with increased uncertainty for those staying in Sweden and social unrest. We will see what humanism you have in other countries when the wallets are to be opened and your citizens are allowed to live in insecurity. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: "blue card" question.- Mrs Winberg, are you saying that this report presents false information?Are you saying that this Parliament and this joint work of two rapporteurs, such as Mr Díaz de Mera and Mrs Valenciano, are arguing false data?Does UKIP say that the data is as false as the data they used in their Brexit campaign to say what the UK was contributing or not contributing, or what healthcare cost and what could be saved?

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: answer (“blue card”).-  Thanks for asking.The report says that we are in need of migration and that we cannot survive, that we are facing a demographic challenge.But that is not the case.One must also look at the problems of this mass migration to Europe.We have received so much that Sweden suffers from extreme problems.This with the fact that it should be a necessity with migration, that is not true.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! Of course, this is about people and it is about fates, and that is why it would be so important to deal seriously with the problem. But with this report, dear colleagues, something must have gone wrong here, at least in the choice of the title “Overcoming the refugee crisis” - great strategy! We just open the door for everyone. How did they come up with this strategy, I wonder. And the rapporteur said: we have a crisis of solidarity in Europe. Dear colleagues, on the one hand, solidarity is not a one-way street and, on the other hand, if I look at this report, I think we have a crisis of common sense in this House. And to completely ignore the problems that are taking place in Europe with this indignant migration, that is a special work of art. But what I find particularly remarkable is that this is still happening with the help of the Conservatives and the EPP in this House, with President Tajani having a completely different opinion on this issue and they are also communicating it completely differently outside.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ms. President!The report states that migration triggered by economic reasons or started in the hope of a better life is as legitimate as an escape from persecution.This is unacceptable!Anyone whose life is in danger and fleeing comes to Europe with the same right as someone who chooses to live better than the Swedish or German social network?Unacceptable.The rapporteur is calling for a paradigm shift, the essence of which is not to talk about a crisis, not to say that it is a migrant crisis, but to treat the whole thing as an opportunity.This is nothing more than the conscious eradication of Europe's remaining immune system.We constantly hear the word solidarity, solidarity, we only hear one thing about solidarity with the indigenous peoples of Europe.

name: David McALLISTER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The migration and refugee crisis presents our continent with a huge challenge. It is a challenge that we can ultimately only master together in Europe. I would like to mention two points on which the success of this European migration policy will largely depend: Firstly, we will only be successful in the long term if we succeed in resolutely addressing the root causes of migration. As the European Union, we should make our contribution to peace in our southern neighborhood and promote economic development, especially in Africa, by investing in jobs, vocational training and entrepreneurship, especially in the agricultural sector. Second: the external borders of our Member States are the external borders of the European Union in the 21st century. That is why the Schengen system must be preserved, deepened and expanded. The Schengen area must be able to maintain and protect its external borders. Separate European monitoring instruments are just as necessary as a common asylum and migration policy in order to strike a balance between the fulfillment of humanitarian obligations on the one hand and the absorption capacity of the member states on the other. That should be the central message of today's debate. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Mr McAllister, my fellow countryman – or at least half of you is – may I just say that the problem is that, when Ms Merkel invites any number of people to come to Europe without let or hindrance, it is all very well for Germany, but this affects Germany’s neighbours, especially Great Britain, and this is something that is a problem. So if you have your Schengen, and you have open door immigration from goodness knows where, we could end up with lots of jihadis and a lot of people we cannot house or have schools or hospitals for.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - I am happy to take a question from my Scottish compatriot - at least fifty percent. Two pointers: First: Angela Merkel did not invite hundreds of thousands, millions of people to come to Germany, but they set out, and Germany and other member states of the European Union have accepted their humanitarian responsibility. I would have liked to have seen that from other countries too. Second: I like to live in a borderless Europe. My daughter once asked me when we were crossing the autobahn from Germany to the Netherlands: What exactly is a border control? We are very fortunate in Germany to live in a country that is surrounded by countries that are in the Schengen area. And that's why we have to strengthen the Schengen area, and that's why I am in favor of a European border guard so that we can continue to have a borderless Europe in the future. You in the UK, especially your party, do not want that. Have lots of fun with it!

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to thank the rapporteurs for their work. 86% of displaced people around the world are hosted by developing countries. Achieving a fair sharing of responsibilities on reception is not only a European but a global issue. But how will the European Union do its part if every effort by the Council, and ultimately also by the Commission, seems to be aimed at externalizing our borders? We see this in the proposed reform of the common asylum system, with the inadmissibility checks based on the discretionary concept of safe third countries; we see this in the agreements with Turkey, whose success is measured in the inhumane conditions of 15 000 migrants stranded on the Greek islands, and now with Libya, which has not even signed up to the Geneva Convention; we see it in the new partnership frameworks, which would like to condition cooperation on development, on the control of migratory flows and on repatriation. This not only violates the very essence of development cooperation, which according to article 208 must eliminate poverty, but also risks directing aid only to countries on migratory routes, forgetting the least developed ones and jeopardizing the relations of the Union with third countries. This goes against the long-term goals of addressing the root causes of migration: conflict, climate change, inequality, and goes against the goals of sustainable development. Many new financial instruments are being created, but never with new resources, always diverted from other funds and priorities, and without proper democratic scrutiny by this Parliament. Let's put solidarity and fundamental rights at the center.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr. Carver!I saw you want a blue card.But you have had the floor once before in this debate.Now that we're running out of time, I'm not going to give you a blue card.I thank you for your understanding.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, we need to change the European Union's refugee policy, because we see that it has not gone well and we see that the confidence of European citizens in us has also fallen and that of refugees. It's a mess we have to put in order. We went through this experience, it helps us, let's put things in order. First of all, the External Action Service needs to negotiate with the states in the vicinity of the conflict zones so that they can take in refugees and give them the assistance they need. Secondly, I support the application of reallocation. This means that Member States, depending on their capabilities, go and take refugees from the camps where they are, after undergoing medical, criminal and security checks. This means that everyone will feel safe: both the refugees and the European citizens to whom these refugees are brought. The most vulnerable families and people must be the ones who are brought to the Member States in particular on these criteria, I repeat, on the three methods of verification: medical, criminal and security.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: - We have not been effective in preventing the tragic fate of refugees, exiles or migrants, for one reason or another.However, in the truly comprehensive report we are discussing, we can find many reflections and values that justify Europe's reputation as a continent of humanism, culture and compassion.As an expression of acceptance of our responsibility, I support an ambitious and investment plan for the countries from which most refugees and migrants come.I also support the Commission's approach to ensure the participation of all countries in the wider region of the Middle East, Africa and Asia, which, given their economic potential, can contribute significant resources to the realization of this program.We must continue to work with Turkey, regardless of our criticism of the state of democracy and human rights in that country.However, we must also support all countries along the path of refugee flows, thus enabling refugees to receive humane treatment along the way.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: - Madam President! A fisherman from West Africa was interviewed on German television who can no longer earn anything at home because European ships are fishing the coast empty. He was not given asylum, he was sent back home as a so-called economic refugee. Of course there are many causes of flight in Africa too, including many self-inflicted, but it is the EU that with its trade agreements is literally sucking these countries out. I would like to remind you that the agriculture of these countries is being forced to supply us with cheap coffee, tea, cocoa and tropical fruits, that the establishment of our own machine economy is prevented by the customs agreements. That means that this same economy cannot come up. The EU is even using funds originally earmarked for development aid to rearm countries in order to use violence to prevent refugees from coming to Europe. It's a scandal, it has to change.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, this reports seeks to paint any criticism of the failed and discredited policy of mass migration as xenophobic or racist or any of the smorgasbord of buzzwords the elitist European political class uses to shut down reasoned debate. Further, it attempts to herd nation states into a European bouillabaisse. Nations will lose all control over migration, borders and economic policies. Listen to the individual peoples of Europe who want to retain the fascination of their individual cultures, that which makes Europe interesting. Herr Mayer, my colleague from Austria, wears Lederhosen and I wear a kilt. It is a charming thing about Europe: difference. The people demand an end to open borders. They demand an end to the use of migration to keep big business happy and workers insecure, and they demand an end to the EU wasting their taxes on foreign aid, which only perpetuates inequalities in world trade and props up dictatorships and unstable regimes.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Kłosowski, I saw your card when I had already given the floor to Mr Coburn, so I am sorry but I cannot take your blue card now because it was given to the previous speaker.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while the flow of migrants to Europe will once again explode with the arrival of spring and summer, while the European Court of Auditors denounces the ineffectiveness of EU policies. Union in terms of external border control, while even the French Senate denounces the flaws in the functioning of the Schengen area and the failure of the so-called hotspot policy, the parliamentary report that you are submitting to us this evening, obviously supported by right-wing MEPs dare to demand from member states that they extend asylum to all economic and climatic migrants, which is sheer madness. This enlargement will amplify the migratory air call and incite hundreds and hundreds of illegal immigrants to cross the Mediterranean to come to us. Worse, you are asking national parliaments to abolish legal frameworks that you deem repressive, which amounts to thinking that a migrant who crosses the border without having been authorized to do so would no longer be considered illegal. In what language should we tell you that we no longer want this immigration? The peoples of Europe no longer want immigration. The peoples of Europe want to control their borders and, above all, to preserve their identity.

name: Sławomir KŁOSOWSKI
text: - Madam President!My name is Sławomir Kłosowski.I wanted to ask Madam President at what point, according to the Rules, I acted inappropriately by lifting the card to ask a question.Madam President did not give me that vote.If I can ask, please answer me.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Kłosowski - please excuse me if I pronounce your name incorrectly - I first explained that I and my colleagues here only saw the blue card with which you wanted to ask a colleague a question on this pagewhen I had already given the floor to Mr Coburn.In other words, you could no longer ask this question about the blue card procedure at that time.I hope you understand that, and the next time we speak, if we see it in time, you will speak with the blue card.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Madam President! Yes, the report does not differentiate, it does not differentiate enough. There are immigrants. There are immigrants who are needed, there are immigrants who are not needed. There are immigrants who want to be integrated, who do not allow themselves to be integrated, and luckily the sovereign state - England will soon be able to do so - can choose for itself which immigration to the country you want and which you don't. Then there are the refugees. Of course there is the Geneva Refugee Convention, which is not mentioned at all in the report and which is being debated far too little here in this Parliament. Of course someone on the run and in danger has to feel the protection of the community. But the Geneva Refugee Convention also says: When the danger is gone, when the war is over, the refugee in question has to return to his home country. So I don't know what these integration courses for refugees want, and I think opening borders means solidarity, it is said here, but monitoring borders means security.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, we all know the background to this resolution – 65 million refugees around the world, the Dublin Convention existing only on paper, one—sided decisions to close borders or to implement limits for immigration, a temporary resettlement agreement for refugees which never took place. The fact that the EU today clings on to countries like Turkey and Libya is not the result of an ambition to find a sustainable solution in this situation. It is the result of a political failure. It is the result of a lack of responsibility in dealing with one of the major challenges of our time. However, as we all know, there is an alternative – secure external borders, legal roads into the Union and a permanent and shared resettlement mechanism. This resolution offers such an alternative, which is why it is so important to support it: we need more, not less cooperation; we need more, not less, solidarity with vulnerable people. We need a political leadership that does not give into populism but stands for values and stands for human dignity.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - Madam President, the arrivals of migrants and refugees will not stop, it is a reality. It is therefore necessary to anticipate them and provide lasting and concrete solutions. You should know that every day, 34,000 people are forcibly displaced around the world. In this context, the European Union has a double responsibility. Its primary responsibility is to show solidarity with the developing States, which host the vast majority of refugees and which, despite their difficulties, come to the aid of those in need of protection. This is the case of Lebanon and Jordan, where the situation is deteriorating rapidly. The Union’s second responsibility is to fight, through its external action, against the root causes of migration, which are poverty, violence, the lack of democracy and unemployment. I want to be absolutely clear: I am not opposed in principle to cooperation agreements with third countries. But we only hear about one side, that of security, border protection and aid conditionality. At a time when migration issues have become a real lever for negotiation in discussions on development aid, the latter must be firmly anchored to the values ​​of the European Union, in particular respect for human rights.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - Unfortunately, my delegation cannot support this comprehensive report. First, because the report does not want to make a distinction between people fleeing war and torture and people who emigrate for economic reasons, even though this distinction is essential. But what bothers me even more is the following: not a word is mentioned in this comprehensive report about the role that certain NGOs play and with which, according to Frontex, they facilitate human trafficking. Of course people need to be rescued, but why should everyone be transferred to the ports in Italy? What prevents us from having them disembark in the country of departure if they were safe there? After all, the only right measure to combat the migration crisis is to close our external borders and so we must carry out pushback operations against those who were previously safe in a third country. Subsequently, a limited number of real refugees can be admitted. For this we have to set a strict maximum limit.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Mr. President, Mrs. Valenciano, Mr. Díaz de Mera, I admire your work and support your joint, constructive approach, because there are already Mrs. Albiol or Mr. Urbán to destroy - who has left - to systematically undermine and not contribute no viable solution. But the rest of us are here to work and to listen to each other and to reach solutions. What I want to talk about today is a failure. The failure of the European Council, the failure of the Member States to fulfill their commitments to host refugees. Pacta sunt servanda. Of the 15,000 refugees that our Government, the Government of Spain, the Government of the Popular Party, promised to host, we will only hopefully reach 10%. A bleak 10% a far cry from the already sad 25% on average that Mr. Avramopoulos acknowledged the other day. Is it not surprising that thousands of refugee children pass through Europe, risking all kinds of dangers? Every missing child, every minor in trafficking networks, every child caught in terrorist networks is our responsibility. A single missing minor is too many, and I want Spain, my country, to fully assume its responsibility and to keep its word.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: - Mr President, I find that we always attend the same circus in this hemicycle: an extreme right and a less extreme right, but nevertheless visible, try to tell us that all the problems could be solved with the construction of walls and closing borders. For me, with a billion Africans deprived of hope today, two billion Africans in misery tomorrow and perhaps three billion Africans in utter destitution the day after tomorrow, borders and walls will not be able to solve anything. The only solution will be through a multilateral development policy that will benefit all the places, which have unfortunately become far too numerous, where people are fleeing. They are fleeing misery, war, hunger, bad governance and corruption, all phenomena that unfortunately surround us, which become more and more oppressive over time and which we will not be able to fight without incisive actions, carried out with our partners in the regions around us, particularly in Africa. European policy, through the Foreign Investment Fund and the Africa Fund, is good policy. Nevertheless, I doubt that the means currently deployed will prove to be sufficient. They will have to be amplified by calling on other partners, I am thinking in particular of China. Finally, I believe that state building in Africa is a necessity, but state building in Africa must not only manifest at the borders but above all in the essence of the African state, which must become a Rule of law. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Sławomir KŁOSOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Allow me to ask the Honorable Member and, by the way, a delayed lady representing the Spanish view on emigration.Well, the honorable Member said that, indeed, the fundamental problem and the reason for regretting the fact that Spain had accepted not only 15,000 emigrants were economic reasons.And therefore the question: isn't it better to eliminate such situations from the emigration home countries?And a question for the honorable Member: the honorable Member himself said that in the queue of these refugees - because this category of refugees and emigrants is very, very fluid here - I would very much ask that we clarify who is a refugee, who is an immigrant.Eventually, this billion people in the queue will bring a huge threat to Europe.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I would ask you to respect the rules. I gave you the floor to ask a question to Mr Engel and you, misleading the President, used the time you had to ask a question to ask the Spanish colleague who spoke earlier, while you made this request very late. Please respect the rules. Sit down, I'm not giving you the floor. Mr Engel, if you think the previous colleague asked you something, please answer. And you have no say, please follow the rules next time. Mr Engel, do you want to answer?

name: Frank ENGEL
text: answer "blue card".- Both I understand and I do not understand the question.Again, it's always the same problem.To me, a migrant is not someone more loathsome than a refugee.A person who moves out of necessity and out of desperation has no less good reasons than another to abandon his country.At the end of the day, we are faced with all kinds of phenomena.Above all, we are - and we will be much more so in the future - faced with a migration of poverty from the South.To respond to this misery, we must design policies that cannot be based on building walls.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr. President, in November 2015, 66 countries of the Maghreb, sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East and the European Union met at the Valletta summit and made the following observation: the problem of migration goes to the —Beyond the refugee crisis; it is a lasting, political and human phenomenon that we must tackle without fear of nationalists. We have to admit that we remained with the weapon at the foot. I'm asking two questions. What about the 3.6 billion from the trust fund for Africa decided in Valletta? What about the 44 billion euros of the foreign investment plan proposed to us here by President Juncker on September 14th and which was to be supplemented to the tune of 44 billion by the Member States? It is, I believe, our living together, which is threatened. So it is high time to make decisions and stick to them financially. Our partners in the southern Mediterranean - the Maghreb, sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East - are impatient. It is about our credibility, it is also about our identity, the one we have, the European identity.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Please state!I come from a country which in the nineties - as few know - accepted almost one hundred thousand immigrants, refugees and Muslims from Chechnya, then attacked by Russia, which has been occupying it to this day.In fact, there are only a few of them left, but I think I have a right to talk about it.We have also admitted a great many immigrants - I do not want to say refugees because these definitions are different and Mr Kłosowski is right to ask for a very strict definition of the terms 'refugee' and 'immigrant'.Therefore, we accepted approximately one and a half million people from Ukraine.They are mainly immigrants, but it is also worth appreciating.I think that the decisions of the European Union in this matter should be taken by consensus, and not by a minority vote by a majority.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Mr President, let me be very clear. The EU should, of course, work closely together with partners in our neighbourhood in order to manage in the best way possible the challenges posed by migration. This can, however, not be an excuse to try to externalise our borders or to refuse to take our fair share of receiving applicants for international protection. What we now need to make sure is that we establish a well-functioning common European asylum system where each and every country of this Union takes its fair share of the responsibility for the people that are seeking international protection in the EU. This should be binding and mandatory for all Member States. Let us also keep in mind that there is a big difference between building capacity and stimulating development and cooperation with third countries and outsourcing our own responsibilities to these countries. Keep in mind that it is in the absence of a functioning system on asylum that we see new border controls imposed by Member States, emergency measures of all sorts, and statements such as the one with Turkey. If we ensured that we did our job, this would not have been necessary.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: -  Mr. president; thanks to Mrs. Valenciano and Mr. Díaz de Mera for their report. The crisis experienced in the last two years at the European borders has shown us some of the shortcomings of the Union's migration policy. Important efforts are being made - for example, the creation of the European Coast and Border Guard or the asylum and visa initiatives - but we all know that the Union's migration policy requires a comprehensive approach that reinforces its external dimension. Arrivals have fallen substantially on the eastern Mediterranean route, but in the central Mediterranean they are increasing year by year. The stabilization of Libya, the main country of departure, is of vital importance. So is the realization of long-term cooperation with other of our African neighbors, where a significant 'youth bubble' is developing. A solid association and comprehensive collaboration with the countries of origin and transit are essential to channel migration flows, tackling, as far as possible, the problems at their origin — poverty, insecurity, lack of horizons, etc.—. That is why I welcome the Valletta Action Plan and the launch of the partnership frameworks - Senegal, Mali, Ethiopia, Niger, Nigeria - as well as the proposal for the foreign investment plan, formulated by the Commission. Massive flows of people are a challenge that affects us all: there is no individual solution. I hope that the work started at the high-level meeting on large movements of refugees and migrants in New York last September will be given serious follow-up and that the European Union will take center stage. Our neighborhood with Africa, of course, demands it.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Mister President! The number of refugees who have come to us is not a problem. But despite early warning, Member States failed to prepare and then claimed they were surprised. And now some want to distract from ineptitude, discouragement or simply a lack of foresight. Instead of facing their responsibility at least now, they defame refugees and stir up fears and hatred. That is pathetic, because the vast majority of people only want one thing after fleeing, namely to build a new, safe life for themselves. I hear that we would like to help real refugees. But there is little movement in relocation and resettlement. Yes, it would be good if people didn't have to flee or if their number at least decreased, and politically and economically stable states are generally in our interest. But nothing comes by itself. The admission of those in need of protection and better prospects in the countries of origin belong together, including a common, coherent and sustainable foreign policy with all its various facets. This is important for the refugees and for us, so that the Member States of Europe can remain free, open, secure and democratic.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, I will not support this report because it proposes wrong solutions. This report again shows that nothing new has been learned and nothing old has been forgotten. The solutions proposed in it are unfeasible and time has shown it. It has shown that these measures do not work, it has shown that those who carried out the attacks in European countries have gone through these so-called 'integration measures'. The result is visible. Illegal immigration should not be encouraged with these proposals in the report! On the contrary, Europe's security must be strengthened, its external borders must be strengthened, a hostile and aggressive Turkey, ruled by a man who does not respect any democratic rules and procedures, must be made clear that this will not work for him! The report is wrong and suggests wrong solutions. And this is another such report in this Chamber, in which, while we are talking these stories, everything that is happening on the streets of Europe is happening, but it is not visible from this Chamber. Once again - I will not support it!

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Mr. President, Honorable Commissioner Mimica, I congratulate my fellow rapporteurs on a well-balanced report calling for a common agreement and response to the unprecedented wave of migration facing the European Union. I believe that the three key messages we need to send through this Report, both to our citizens and to our global partners: the only lasting solution to the migration crisis is at its source, the European Union's foreign policy must play a more assertive role in reconciliation processes. the union must be at the forefront of coordinating migration management funding instruments with other international institutions and communicate more visibly its efforts to help eradicate misery and intolerance, the main causes of injustices that force people to leave their homes. We must not forget countries, sensitive interfaith population structures like Lebanon that are coping in these difficult times with the enormous pressure of refugees who make up half of their population. They urgently need help so that the dam does not overflow and Europe faces even bigger problems.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the challenge of migration and refugees does not correspond only to the Council of Ministers of the Interior, does it? No, of course not: it has an external dimension. And therefore we welcome the report of our colleagues, but many socialists demand that the dignity and human rights be respected in refugees regardless of their legal status and, furthermore, we say that it is not acceptable that conditionality is mechanical to determine that Only countries that commit to readmission or control policies can be helped, and that the criminalization of humanitarian aid, now allowed by the so-called "Facilitation Directive", disappears. We demand safe roads, humanitarian visas, humanitarian corridors as a legal route to enter the European Union, and that the European Parliament be involved in the definition and implementation of the policy, as well as in its budget calculation. But, above all, we want to change the negative and prejudiced view of immigration policy. We reject the agreement with Turkey. We demand a change from that prejudiced gaze and a total demand for compliance with the commitments made by the Council regarding resettlement and rehousing, finally changing that security approach to a humanitarian approach.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, I consider the protection of the external borders to be the most important thing. This is an essential tool in the fight against illegal economic migration. We do not have and will not have an effective pan-European institution here, nor a European External Action Service, nor a European border guard. We will have to get used to the fact that the main burden of protecting borders against illegal economic migration will be on the national services of individual member states, that the border countries of the European Union simply have increased responsibility and the rest of us have an increased responsibility to help them financially, organizationally, logistically. I would very much like the Commission to come forward with allocating far more resources in the new multiannual financial framework after 2020 to the protection of the external borders, that this money will go to Greece, to Italy, to Spain, that we will contribute to them instead, to come up with new institutions, so that we support those institutions that are already functioning, that is, their national border services. I would consider this to be an effective and sensible approach.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - President! The European Union has voluntarily or unintentionally wasted many years in dealing with the almost unexpected migrant crisis. Although it was clear from the outset that a common European security and defense policy was needed in the face of the influx of millions of migrants, its development has been delayed ever since. With this in mind, we can only welcome the renewed efforts of the External Action Service, the Commission and the EP to answer the refugee issue and bring it back to normal. It replaces the extraordinary challenge of migration in place of the Rome Declaration, and the recent Maltese resolution of the European People's Party on illegal migration is also looking for a solution. For these, the Valenciano-de Mera report unfortunately represents a serious setback. In agreement with Hungary and the Visegrad countries, our primary task must be to protect Europe from the invasion of illegal immigrants at all costs. It is true that we must give all refugees all the help and respect the human rights of migrants. However, our most important thing is to protect the citizens and nations of Europe, our security, our democratic order, our identity and our common values. The Holiness of the Pope should also primarily protect our European Christianity, faith and values.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: -  Mister President! Europe is in a very difficult position: the refugee crisis does not want to disappear from the agenda. Much is self-inflicted. The solutions are mostly dominated by national interests, they are short-sighted and symbolic. If we want to overcome the crisis, then we need European solutions, long-term and solution-oriented. It doesn't have to be about sensitivities, but about cause-effect relationships. Without looking outside, we cannot solve our problems. Mr Valenciano and Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra have presented a very good and balanced report. It makes it clear that we cannot be guided solely by security interests. Stability can only be achieved in the long term if there is pressure to adhere to human rights and the rule of law and if economic conditions prevail that open up opportunities for people. We need a development policy that is based on this. We need an effective European immigration instrument, and that includes humanitarian entry corridors.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!We are to talk about a solution to the immigration crisis, as the title of this report declares.Meanwhile, for example, its points 16 and 39 again contain indirect but explicit calls for the legalization of illegal immigration, and as such, of course, constitute an attack on sovereignty and the rule of law.And it is necessary, Members of the House, to remember that it is precisely such calls, such statements about the legalization of illegal immigration, that in fact built the prosperity for the illegal immigration industry.And this illegal immigration industry is increasingly - according to the information we have - infiltrated by the caliphate of the Islamic State.Moreover - and I think this is the most important thing - it is actually suggesting that illegal immigration will be legalized sooner or later is at the root of the tragedy of thousands of people who have been exploited by smugglers.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - We face three types of problems: problems in countries of origin, in countries of transit and in countries of destination.The report shows more attention to the causes of the refugee problem, and I am glad that this approach is much more ambitious towards the problems in the countries of origin, which will still be the source of migration, even if we manage to contribute to ending the unfortunate conflicts there.I come from Slovenia, which has experienced several hundred thousand refugees from the south-east, on its way from Greece to Germany, to put it simply, and for this reason I particularly support the intention of the European Union to pay more attention to transit countries.interests of the European Union.With regard to the target countries, I would like to draw attention to an aspect that is, in my view, underestimated, and that is the cultural aspect of migration and the refugee problem.The issue of integration is not a matter of statistics or technique, but is a distinctly cultural issue.I would like more attention on this topic.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, in 2015 the record for forcibly displaced people was broken: 65 million worldwide. And in the face of this global phenomenon, the European Union and the Member States have been unable to provide a coordinated, supportive and effective response to this entire movement of forcibly displaced people, which has also affected us. For all these reasons, the report that we are going to adopt here today is so necessary and timely. And that is why we must also congratulate the co-rapporteurs - and I especially wanted to congratulate Elena Valenciano - because today we send - Parliament sends - a very clear message on this matter. First: we need legal and safe routes of entry to end the deaths in the Mediterranean. Second: we need a relocation system that works, because the current one is not working; only 25% of what was committed has been fulfilled. Third: we need to reject the policy of outsourcing our asylum and reception obligations; And, especially, it must be said that the agreement with Turkey is that outsourcing that we want to reject. And fourth: we must go to the root of the problem, be a stronger and more influential actor, capable of stabilizing and pacifying a burning Middle East and North Africa.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, it is a fact that the most of those who arrive in Europe from Africa and the Middle East are very unlikely to find employment and become self-sufficient in Europe. This kind of immigration is an economic and social burden, not a resource. It is also a fact that most of those who arrive illegally or using the asylum procedure are not genuine refugees but rather people looking for better opportunities. For these reasons it is both necessary and justified to limit as much as possible immigration from the Third World to Europe.  The report rightly addresses the root causes of migration, such as poverty and bad governance and calls for more cooperation with the neighbourhood countries. Our focus should shift from managing the crisis within Europe to supporting the countries of origin and transit countries and helping refugees where most of them are, in the camps.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: – Mr President, a serious question has to be straight. My highest respect to the rapporteurs that they are trying to find the right way concerning the question of refugees. I have regularly visited the countries in the Middle East for many years. I have had numerous meetings with local religious political leaders, dealing with migration issues. Each of them urged Europe to help migrants on the spot in their own region. I hope you are aware that if you approve this report you will send, in indirect form, an invitation to thousands and thousands of potential refugees. You encourage them to leave their homes with the fake illusion of a better life. But can you guarantee this better life for all of them? Can you promise them that they and their children can get safely to Europe? Can you take responsibility for their future? It is time to change the paradigm and turn the focus on helping them in their own homeland after the tragedies of previous years. I am afraid that, for all its good will, the message of this report is that Europe wants to use the people as second-rank citizens to solve its own demographic and labour problems.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, for too long the external dimension has been missing in the definition of the EU response to migration movements, although it is fundamental to address the root causes of these phenomena. I support the call for full respect for migrants’ and refugees’ rights and dignity, no matter their status. I reject any conditionality of EU aid on the collaboration of third countries on migration issues. We definitely need a common EU policy on asylum and migration to be forged in the near future. I urge the establishment of safe and legal channels for reaching the EU for asylum seekers and potential migrants, which would be the best way to break the business of human traffickers and organised crime, and I believe that Parliament has to be fully involved in all current initiatives and their budgetary consequences. Last, but not least, allow me to warmly congratulate the rapporteurs.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: - Mister President! When we talk about asylum and refugee policy, we are talking about an overall problem that has really been analyzed to a large extent. We know the problem areas and, if we are completely honest, we also know what to do to solve these problems. It is not a one-dimensional problem, it is multilayered, which means that we have to act on different levels. One level is definitely on-site help. We have been calling for this for a long time, and right now we are currently seeing it again in numerical examples that are mentioned in other draft reports by the Commission - it is now assumed that if you do not want to accept an asylum seeker or refugee you do not want to one would have an admission quota in the EU for which non admission should pay 250,000 euros. These sums alone show that something is going completely wrong. With this money we could help an incredible number of people locally, and here we are talking about a single migrant who comes to Europe. We finally need an honest definition of what the EU can and wants to achieve. And, in my opinion, this joint asylum work must be based on voluntary action, because otherwise the integration of the people will not succeed, and that must be our goal. That means a system in which the Member States commit themselves to certain measures, but then they have to be implemented, otherwise we have only printed on paper and nothing will happen.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Externalizing responsibilities and borders is a recipe for disaster, for the European Union's discredit and for further insecurity inside and outside it. The Commission and the Council refer to security. But what security when Member States refuse to open legal and safe routes for immigrant refugees through humanitarian visas or family reunification and thus feed the business of drug traffickers delivering desperate people to death in the Mediterranean and organized crime behind those networks, including terrorist crime? The Commission and the Council refer to readmission agreements as an example of cooperation with strategic partners. But what is the strategy in the face of a Libya that the European Union has let up in its current inability to govern? What is the strategy of becoming hostages to Erdogan in the immoral and illegal business? Or to finance governments that manufacture refugees for the oppression and misery they impose on their people, like the Ethiopian government? As colleagues Valenciano and Díaz de Mera point out, there is an urgent need for external action with a strategic vision consistent with European values ​​and principles that lead by example and that respects human rights and that tells our citizens that refugees and immigrants help to fight demographic decline in our societies. Only then will we truly defend the security of Europeans.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Mr. President, congratulations to the reporters on their hard work. I welcome the initiative to help the Union's Southern Neighborhood and the Western Balkans, which will lead to job creation, economic resilience and poverty reduction, and in particular the need for a decentralized approach in conducting European migrant refugee policy. However, key questions remain unanswered. Who caused the migrant crisis? What is the responsibility of the European Union in this? And how should the EU act preventively? The European Union must strictly control the influx of migrants and carry out systematic surveillance of external borders. Of course, the European Union should show solidarity and help vulnerable categories, primarily women and children, but it must not ignore the security issue and the fact that a large number of refugees are able-bodied men. Solidarity and humanity must not be a front for Europe's cultural change, and the European Union must not turn into a refugee camp or remain their final destination.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, millions of men, women and children emigrate to escape wars, persecutions and hunger. We are experiencing the most serious migratory crisis, with a very high price in terms of human lives lost. In this terrible tragedy, once again, minors are paying a very high toll, and on the tragedy of unaccompanied minors, Italy has just launched a civilization standard that equates the rights of these children to all others living in Europe: a good example for all of Europe. The business model of traffickers must be stopped. The recent agreement on migrants reached in Tripoli between the Italian government and the new Libyan national unity government can also be a platform to work on. The real challenge that Europe faces is to build a strategy based on international cooperation. Synergies are needed, coordinated and concrete actions, which are not only a reaction, but capable of anticipating possible future crises.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, during the debate we heard talk about the value of having a legal migration route, as this way we can avoid a lot of problems. The Balkan Road, the road of the Western Balkans, which was arbitrarily and illegally closed by Skopje, was also a legal road. That is what Mr Ban Ki-moon said. But yesterday we saw Mr Tusk in Skopje applauding the Skopje government for illegally closing this otherwise legal immigration route. Second, relocations: relocations must finally proceed. The European Union must implement what it said and carry out the 66,400 relocations of refugees from Greece. About 20% has been executed and the program ends next September. The relocations must therefore be implemented immediately.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, I have heard very good views here, according to which we must support people to stay in their countries. I argue that it is a very good idea, but I suspect that the real message behind this idea is: "let them not come to our door". So I suggest: "And whoever this is, let not the wicked be left behind." In addition, I want to say something about Turkey. Mr Erdoğan is threatening to break the agreement, and the European Union seems to be afraid of that possibility. In my judgment, the threat is meaningless and I will explain briefly why. To some extent, the war has stopped, so the power has been cut. Secondly, the Syrians who are in Turkey have been there for about three or four years and to some extent they are used to it. Thirdly, the corridors from Greece to the rest of Europe are closed, so if they come to Greece, they will stay, at best, in some settlements. I therefore think it is right to know that Mr Erdoğan's threats are meaningless and should be taken seriously.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are once again discussing immigration and possible solutions. We have done so many times, many times we have voted, we have decided, we have found solutions which, however, have not been followed up afterwards by the Commission, but above all by the Member States. So I ask myself, on this work done by colleagues, which is a work that follows the positions taken and that it is a job well done, what do we really think we will achieve? This is an own-initiative report that has been considered by the Conference of Presidents, therefore on the observation of the Conference of Committee Chairs, as a non-strategic report on which, moreover, we cannot even submit amendments if there are no 76 signatures. So, if a Conference of Committee Chairs that is made up of people who do not even respect the D'Hondt method - for example we are not represented - decides what is strategic and what is not, who can table amendments and who cannot, then say what are we discussing, what do we think we're getting?

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Mr President, my congratulations to both rapporteurs. The data tells us that, in the last five years, the number of refugees has increased by 50%, and most of them live without any prospects and in a situation of prolonged displacement. Repatriations are very rare and local integration non-existent. I have just come from Lebanon, where in one of the many refugee settlements I have met Rami, a boy whose hair turned white when his father was killed in a bombing. This is just one of the tragic stories that one can hear from that million and a half refugees living in Lebanon, a country that gives us an important lesson in solidarity. Everyone wants to go back to Syria, but where and when? Their houses are destroyed and the war continues. I ask the High Representative to direct all her efforts to the search for peace and security for that region, because in the end those who suffer are always the same: those who have lost everything and those who, as many of them told me, only they have their god and their dignity.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like first of all to thank the honors. Valenciano and Díaz de Mera for their commitment to a complete and balanced own-initiative report that goes in the right direction. Indeed, today's debate has also highlighted how the European Union and its member countries have tackled the problem of migration exclusively from an emergency perspective, without a real long-term strategy, and how coordinated action is now necessary, aimed at support the economic development of the countries of departure to guarantee the fundamental rights of the citizens of those countries and to ensure them decent living conditions, so as to reduce the flow of migration.
