And as I have stressed several times in this House, ensuring that the most vulnerable - and specifically children - are welcomed, cared for, supported and protected inside but also outside our borders must be a priority of the European Union's external action. within the policies and actions of international organizations.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, the migrant crisis, which is not over yet, is the biggest migration challenge that Europe has faced since World War II.We cannot remain indifferent to the suffering of people coming from regions affected by a raging war, but we must also not continue with the naive and disastrous policy of accepting anyone who appears on our borders.Protecting the endangered is one thing, and not having any criteria is quite another.The Brussels solutions proved to be bad, both for the migrants and for the hosts.According to quotas, migrants were sent to countries they do not want to go to and which for various reasons do not want to accept them.This makes no sense because it violates the will of both the Member State and the migrants.No one should have the right to decide for a Member State what its society will look like, who it will accept and how it will integrate these people, as long as the country respects the fundamental values and the acquis communautaire.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, the report rightly criticizes the Union for focusing too much on curbing migratory flows rather than addressing the causes of asylum and migration. It is rightly said that immigrants and refugees not only do not harm our societies, but on the contrary, they strengthen and enrich them. The causes of refugee and migration flows may be properly identified, but the reasons leading to conflict and war, as well as the role played by European states and the United States, are not named. Instead, the Union continues in the same dead-end, inhumane policy with new border walls, segregation of legal and illegal immigrants, strengthening of FRONTEX and unacceptable agreements with neighboring countries to act as border guards. As I have emphasized many times, tackling flows can only be done by tackling their causes and by genuine solidarity, solidarity and offering support to suffering countries, solidarity within the European Union and, finally, by creating legal avenues. and implementation of a permanent refugee resettlement system.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, citizens are asking us what the European Union has done to tackle the migration crisis.We have the answer in this report.Here is a balance of what has been done, but what will also be done, clear goals: to protect lives, to ensure the protection of those who need it, to effectively protect the European Union's external borders and to stop human trafficking.The European Parliament is proposing to address the root causes of migration, that is, to promote stability and the economy in the countries of origin.It's not just words.The European Union has already spent EUR 17 billion over the past period on tackling the migration crisis, including the mobilization of human resources and legislation.Finally, I would like to ask the Commissioner, who mentioned aid to Libya here in protecting the southern borders, and I would like to know: what specific means are the European Union preparing for this aid?

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I am descended from French Huguenots who fled persecution in 1685 to seek refuge in a welcoming Britain, introducing the very word ‘refugee’ into our vocabulary. Today, whether fleeing conflict, famine or climate chaos, no one wants to risk their lives at sea or on land in search of safety and stability. Therefore, I would like to congratulate everyone who has worked on this report. It offers a truly comprehensive and holistic strategy for dealing with the needs of refugees coming to Europe. We need to work simultaneously at all levels. We need international cooperation to tackle root causes and combat the horrific human rights abuses perpetrated by smugglers en—route. We need to establish safe routes of travel and humane living conditions for refugees, taking into account women and girls, children and other groups.  We need to work at home against the nationalist, xenophobic and racists discourse we have seen on the rise. We need to celebrate the cultural richness that refugees and migrants bring with them and provoke a truly compassionate, empathetic debate. That is the standard we must hold our governments to.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, this has been a very interesting and warming debate. Indeed, ensuring a joined—up approach among all the EU actors concerned, as well as with Member States, is something I personally consider vital for the success of the partnership framework approach. I take note that that majority of the honourable Members support our approach on solidarity with migrants and on cooperation with partner countries on migration, and I am very grateful for this support. While thanking you again both for the report and for this fruitful exchange of views, let me reassure you that your concerns raised in the report, as well as during our debate, are duly noted and will be taken into consideration when working together on our external actions addressing refugee and migrant movements.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: speaker. - Mr President, I would like to excuse Mr Díaz de Mera, who surely will not be able to be in the part of his intervention because he has had to go to his Group. I think the debate has been quite clarifying. Thank you very much, Commissioner, for being here. I am sorry that the Council is not here, frankly, because I believe that a large part of the problem that we are addressing has to do with repeated non-compliance by the governments of the Member States. I want you to convey to Mrs Mogherini that we clearly support the strategy they are implementing, but we want to closely monitor how things are going to happen, and I believe that this Parliament has not only the right, but the duty to do so. You have already seen, Commissioner, that, among xenophobia - which is evident in some of our colleagues despite the fact that they belong to countries that have often had to go to refuge and asylum -, among xenophobia - he said - of some who want to close all borders and the rampant populism that considers that the action of the European Union and the Member States in the Mediterranean is to militarize the sea, we are facing two positions with which we will not do anything good for refugees and migrants. Fortunately, I want to thank the rest of my colleagues, the rest of the groups that have participated constructively in the preparation of this report, which aims to shed some light on a phenomenon that will accompany us for a long time, and I reiterate my thanks also to Mr. Díaz de Mera, who has worked loyally and constructively on this report. I believe that we have tackled tonight one of the most serious problems facing the European Union because it affects its credibility, it affects its values ​​and, above all, it is leaving out thousands of human beings who are suffering. I believe that, in the same way that we monitor Member States when they fail to meet their budgetary commitments and prosecutors, we must monitor Member States when they fail to fulfill their solidarity commitments.And I believe that we have instruments to exert pressure on those Member States that are not fulfilling their commitments, because we cannot try to teach the world lessons if we are unable to set an example.I am pleased that the Council is now here, now that the debate is over.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 5 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - In order for European asylum policy to be successful, it is crucial to distinguish between economic migrants who come to Europe only in search of better economic prospects and those who seek protection by fleeing conflict. If we can provide asylum to the latter, then we have no obligations to the former. However, the European Union cannot tackle the migration crisis alone because it is a global problem that requires close cooperation with other countries. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to negotiate and sign more readmission agreements to return irregular migrants quickly. Cooperation with countries of origin and transit also needs to be stepped up so that human trafficking networks, with which thousands of people reach Europe, are broken. However, the most successful way to work with countries of origin is to strengthen economic ties and provide more aid so as to create a long-term perspective for economic growth and jobs in poorer countries. This is precisely the role of European foreign policy and financial instruments, with the help of which we can turn the migration crisis into an opportunity for the rapid development of the countries of Africa and the Middle East.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - In 2015, 66 million people had to move because of conflict and violence. Faced with this distress, the international community, including the Union, has the duty of a comprehensive and effective response. Too often it is NGOs, despite the dangers to which they are exposed, that provide emergency humanitarian aid. I think of the most vulnerable: women, children and LGBTI people, who face an increased risk of violence and abuse on their way to exile. Women experience sexual and gender-based violence, even in places deemed to be safe. Reception procedures must meet their specific needs. But before we got there, how many died on the road? Tragedies follow one another due to the lack of legal and secure pathways for asylum seekers. However, solutions exist: resettlement, legal economic migrations or humanitarian visas. Humanitarian visas are only a possibility today. This must become an obligation clearly written in the visa code. The EU must base its action on human rights and international law, which is not negotiable. We will thus be more credible in our agreements with third countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - People migrate and leave their homes voluntarily and involuntarily every day for various reasons. Today, there are about 244 million international migrants, and this figure indicates the unprecedented scale that migration has reached. It is a worrying fact that in the last five years the number of refugees has increased by as much as 50%. The most endangered are minors in the migration flow in the Mediterranean who, in the hope of a better future, cross borders and thus risk their lives, because despite rescue operations, the number of dead is constantly increasing. They are exposed to a number of psychological and physical dangers, including various forms of violence, and it is alarming that a particularly vulnerable group consists of women and children who are the least resistant to these dangers. I believe that, aware of the fact that international migration can contribute to socio-economic development, the international community must representatively highlight the benefits of migration and urgently take measures to strengthen the common response to protect the rights and dignity of those forced to leave their homes. Only by fighting together can xenophobic, populist and nationalist discourses be stopped.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. – EU external action plays a key role in forging a successful common migration policy. Some argue that agreements with third countries are crucial, the most recent examples being the EU-Turkey deal and EU-Afghanistan Joint Way Forward. Our experience, however, has shown that such initiatives can embolden autocratic regimes in their ambition to consolidate power in internal and external context. The lessons from the deal with Turkey are clear. We cannot trade cooperation on migration for closing our eyes to obvious violations of the European values, unacceptable statements targeting the European project or direct political interference in Member States. Such partnerships cannot serve as an excuse for Europe not to reform its policies in a swift, bold and comprehensive way. This direction could cost us our credibility among the European citizens, who want to see effective management on a European level where the burden is shared fairly among everyone. Instead of outsourcing the problem to our immediate neighbourhood or conditioning aid, we should pursue sustainable cooperation in areas of common interest and support countries of origin and transit in achieving peace and prosperity by creating economic opportunities for their citizens, making migration a choice and not a necessity.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda was the joint debate on the recommendation by Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1605/2002. . 1311/2013 on the definition of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (14942/2016 - C8-0103 / 2017 - 2016/0283 (APP)) (A8-0110 / 2017), - the report by Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1605/2002. 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (2017/2051 (INI)) (A8-0117 / 2017), and - the report by Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, on behalf of the of the Committee on Budgets on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision (EU) 2015/435 on the mobilization of the margin for unforeseen needs (COM (2016) 0607 - C8-0387 / 2016 - 2016 / 2233 (BUD)) (A8-0104 / 2017).

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Both today's debate and tomorrow's vote are symbolic, because for the first time in the history of debates on the European Union's budget, multi-annual perspectives, we will be deciding to revise the financial perspective. I would therefore like to emphasize that the European Parliament first came up with this proposal before the Financial Perspective Regulation was adopted, and last year it was Parliament that started the debate on the revision, assuming that what is in the regulation, i.e. the need to review was the first and necessary step. The European Parliament has therefore carried out a review of the state of implementation of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial perspective and, following this review, concluded that changes were necessary. He proposed a range of these changes, which were then discussed in the Council and, of course, very carefully analyzed by the Commission. After the first doubts that arose, we were very pleased to hear that the Commission supported the revision proposal and the Council, after long debates and doubts of some Member States, also agreed that the multiannual financial perspectives must be changed. It should also be remembered that such changes have a major impact on the debate on the future financial perspective post-2020. If we have decided to revise and change the perspective, it means that we will also be ready for more flexibility and revision in the next financial perspective. I would like to point out that what we have discussed does not only concern purely budgetary issues. An element of the revision is also a proposal for greater simplification. Please note that parallel to the budget debate, work is underway to amend the financial regulation, the so-called by omnibus. These matters should not be separated because revision means a change of approach, change of treatment. What we are going to vote on tomorrow, as is well known, concerns various issues. Firstly, it concerns the greater elements of flexibility that will allow us to implement also in the coming years new tasks that were not envisaged at the very beginning of the preparation of the financial perspective. Greater flexibility will also allow amounts that have not been used appropriately in recent years, in other words, to use them before the end of the financial perspective, which is not the case at present. At the moment, this money is being returned to the Member States. We hope to make greater use of this in recent years. Therefore, increasing flexibility is the first result of the work that has taken place between the European institutions. Besides - the proposals that appeared in the declarations: both in the joint declaration of the Council and Parliament, but also in the position of Parliament, which was voted on tomorrow, which is a declaration. In other words, earmarking greater amounts for tasks related in particular to the new challenges related to the immigration crisis and also to employment of young people. The European Parliament raised its doubts about the re-use of amounts within the budget, but we will probably discuss this matter in the upcoming work on annual budgets. Therefore, I would like to emphasize that the so-called the package of changes, which includes both the revision of the regulation and the additional elements that we will vote on, creates a completely new situation in the debate on the financial perspective, and I think it will be a good starting point for discussions on the next financial perspective after 2020 .

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we meet again on the eve of the vote on the revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. We encountered headwinds, avoided a few shoals, suffered flat calm for months of standing still, suffered a few squalls, and we resisted the sirens singing to us that we would never get there. However, we stayed on course and are touching the wharf. The trip could have been more peaceful and we could have brought more fish back to our holds, but we achieved the goal: the revision of the financial framework. Indeed, if the budgetary programming extended over seven years allows everyone, region, State, research laboratory, etc., to access European programs with serenity, and also with visibility and efficiency, this exercise becomes more and more difficult. . First, because in 2013, we implemented an undersized financial framework for the years 2014-2020, then because the duration implies that the last invoices arrive in 2023, but above all because in the unstable period when we are, it has become impossible to project seven years in advance and respond to unforeseen events and profound changes. MEPs had this lucidity, since in 2013 they had obtained the possibility of a mid-term review. It was not a whim, as we can see, but simply a realistic vision and analysis on the undersizing of the budget and on the evolution of a world that is increasingly quickly. In 2013, the migration phenomenon, Brexit, the terrorist attacks, the imperialist aims of Vladimir Putin and the election of Donald Trump were not on the agenda. The truth is, our framework is obsolete today. To begin to respond to these challenges, a review of the financial framework was needed. Obviously, what is offered to us will not answer all problems and questions. This is only a small step, but in the right direction, and I would like to thank the Commission for it. This step forward is the one which makes it possible to release up to six billion euros for Europeans, up to three billion for flexibility, with 516 million additional euros for the flexibility instrument, 80 million for the emergency aid reserve and up to EUR 2.4 billion of re-use of unallocated funds which will be added to the flexibility instrument. Budget increases are planned - you know them - for the fight against youth unemployment, the reception of refugees, and 2.5 billion euros are planned for the security of Europeans. But contrary to our expectations, this revision does not provide for either raising the expenditure ceilings or sufficient solutions to avoid a new payments crisis and, finally, it does not unfortunately mention the subject of own resources, which are nevertheless essential if we want to. stop the infernal circle of budget shortage. However, we are satisfied. This text inscribes in stone the principle of a mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, thus demonstrating its usefulness and setting a precedent, a necessary step for the future. We wanted with my colleague, Mr Olbrycht, co-rapporteur, to add a statement so that there is no ambiguity on our interpretation of the statements proposed by the Council. Clearly, Parliament will never give up the slightest bit of its power, nor of its budgetary authority defined by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Of course, the Commission will remain the guarantor of full respect for everyone's budgetary prerogatives. Thus, we approach the next budgets taking into account the issues and priorities. Parliament has always been and will remain clear on its interpretation of the financial framework: “por límite el cielo ”, I am not very good at Spanish but, as Cervantes wrote,“ the sky is limit ”, that is to say the ceilings and only the ceilings of the financial framework as a whole, it goes without saying.self.This review is an important step, but let's not kid ourselves.While this is indeed a breath of fresh air, a moment of respite, it is not the hoped-for solution to all the budgetary difficulties that beset us.We pointed out, during the review examination, the gap between the new priorities and the actual state of the Union's means.This is not an end to budgetary questions until 2020. No, this revision is a reinforcement on a young construction, but one that these last years have tested hard.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for the invitation to address Parliament. I have noticed also that some Members would have liked the Presidency to be here during the preceding debate but we had no invitation. I would have liked to join your Members in that particular debate. With regard to this file, this file has kept the Council and Parliament busy since the start of September and this hard work is now coming to fruition. Before going into the substance I want to make a point on the process. The result we have on the table today could not have been achieved without the help of the European Parliament, particularly Mr Arthuis as Chair of the Committee on Budgets, but also Ms Thomas and Mr Olbrycht as co-rapporteurs have worked very constructively with the Council. They conveyed the messages coming from the European Parliament at all stages to feed into the discussion of the Council as well. We saw that many of the concerns expressed by this Chamber were shared also by the delegations. I can also say, in another way, that you helped us to be more ambitious with this review and making it also a proper revision of the EU budget that goes beyond words and also turns into action. Now a point on the substance of the deal that you all have in front of you. This is the result of the dialogue and cooperation between the European Parliament and the Council, and it is a package of new rules and new amounts which found unanimous support within the Council on 7 March. I highlighted the word ‘package’ because of course you know what it means having unanimity in the Council, and we had to make every element count. The balance of the deal is delicate and also cannot be picked apart. Now we have created room for manoeuvre allowing additional funding to respond to the new priorities we all share: migration and security but also growth and youth. They will benefit from more than EUR 5 billion in extra funding over the next four years. Second, our budget will be more agile and also more flexible to respond to future crises. This will also allow us to meet unforeseen needs and move swiftly in their regards. We will increase the capacities of the flexibility instrument and the emergency aid reserve by a total of almost EUR 700 million over the next four years, and in addition the flexibility instrument will be increased further by unused amounts from the Solidarity Fund and Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The global margin for commitments will be extended in both time and scope whilst the caps of the global margin for payments will also be increased.  We all want to move ahead with this deal because we are convinced that it will also allow us to strengthen our tools and better respond to the priorities that have emerged in the last two years. Let me use this occasion, Mr President, to underline the work achieved also by our Slovak friends in the autumn. We started last September with heavy groundwork, we planted seeds we hoped would grow. They needed a little time but they are now about to bloom. I use this metaphor also to convey a simple message that the time is ripe to secure the agreement on the revision of the MFF regulation and its accompanying package. But this flower is also fragile and the season is short. I hope that we will have a green light from this Chamber and conclude this file without any further delays. I look forward to Commissioner Oettinger’s delivery and those of your Members in the debate.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, honorable colleague Borg, ladies and gentlemen! Tonight we are debating an important package to improve our common European budgetary policy. Even more than at the national level, two goals have to be brought together at the European level: the goal of planning security on the one hand and the principle of flexible, efficient ability to act on the other. Planning security: Regardless of whether it is rural areas or our farmers, no matter whether structural programs, regional programs, social programs, whether connecting Europe and thus the construction of expensive infrastructure or our research policy - if we could only commit ourselves for one year, they would Medium-term, important and large programs and projects would hardly be feasible, and the planning security that our partners - the people, the economy, the farmers, the regions, the Member States - need would not exist. This is why a budget framework lasting several years - in this case seven years - makes sense. And vice versa: who could, when the Commission made its MFF proposal in June 2011, and who could foresee the political, economic and social development in 2016 in Parliament and Council when it was deliberated and decided on in the second half of 2013 / 2017/2018 brings new tasks, focal points and problems for us? And therefore: planning security on the one hand and flexibility to act quickly on the other. If the present package, which was indeed moderated very aggressively by your predecessors - the Slovak Presidency - and by you, which was then approved by our Italian government, which was discussed constructively in the Committee on Budgets, is adopted in Parliament and the Council at the end of April, this would be a great success for the ability of European politics to act and a particular success for the European Houses of Parliament. It was you, the honorable Members, who then proposed the mid-term review and mid-term update of the MFF package. I openly admit - at that time not yet jointly responsible for the budget -: I would not have believed that Parliament's request - your request - could now become a reality. It is true that the proposal that is on the table, which the Council made you unanimously, is not one hundred percent identical to the proposal of the Commission, but it is a considerable step in the right direction. And if that is decided, it will be your - the honorable Member - success. On the one hand, it is a question of being able to effectively support important priorities of our people and Parliament with more money for the second half - because the seven-year budget framework will have its mid-term on 30 June this year: the fight against youth unemployment, the issue of security within Europe , the financing of migration efforts, which includes border protection and border control, or increased development aid in neighboring countries, where this can reduce the reasons for fleeing, and the revitalization of Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus, Connecting Europe, or the extension and continuation of our European Fund for Strategic Investments - all requests by a large majority here in Parliament, supported by the Commission and ultimately in agreement with the Member States, which are also affected and benefit from it. But there is more to it. With this package, the Commission's proposal for the 2018 budget can be much closer to the needs of the present, the 2019 budget much closer to the needs of the next two years and the 2020 budget too. We will thus create a considerably better ability to act for the next three budget years. The Commission is currently preparing the next multiannual budgetary framework. We are in first Considerations for the period after 2020 and in due course - this year or next year - we will present you with our five- or seven-year budget proposal for the next decade. I can tell you: if this package is adopted, we will create for the next Parliament, for the next Commission, for the Council in the next decade better ability to act, more accuracy, more flexibility. That's why we're happy about this progress. Many thanks to the president. Many thanks also to the colleagues in the Committee on Budgets. We are campaigning for the acceptance of this package out of conviction, and we want to announce that we and our Maltese friends want to advance the omnibus regulation in the remaining weeks. Your offensive moderation here impresses me very much. That would be the counterpart, that would be the supplement to a then largely existing flexible budget policy based on the tasks that change, that change and that could thus be better solved at European level than with the old law.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would also like to salute the Presidency of the Council, the Commissioner and all and all colleagues. The multiannual financial framework must respond to new challenges, needs, urgencies and contingencies. So, in good time - and here I pay tribute to all those who were in that negotiation - we, Parliament, have fought in the last negotiations on the financial framework and we have achieved more flexibility in the European Union budget and the possibility of having a review of the framework multiannual financial framework. It was worth it, as it is recognized today, albeit belatedly, by the Council. This year, for the first time in history, we have the possibility, therefore, of approving the revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. We have an obligation to increase employment and, in particular, youth employment, tackle terrorism, support those who need it most. For this purpose, we have increased the initial amounts with approximately € 5,000 million - new money that was not foreseen. The “Youth Employment” Initiative takes the largest share with 1,200 million euros. The research and innovation program “Horizon 2020”, the Cosme for SMEs program, the “Connecting Europe” mechanism, Erasmus +, are other reinforced programs, even if they are reallocated. Thus, we will have more means to face the current challenges and we will also reinforce, to face the issues of migration, the amounts allocated to it. This review introduces flexibility, allows financing additional needs, enhances employment, promotes solidarity. Conclusion: it is a good review and everyone who agrees with these objectives should support it and the amounts are not for the European Parliament, the amounts are for the European Union, the institutions, the Member States to face the challenges I mentioned . It was also important to eliminate constraints, limitations, the global authorization margin, increase global margin of payments, increasing the reserve for emergencies and an instrument of flexibility. I am talking about special instruments and here I turn to the Council and tell them that they should also have good interpretation - and the good interpretation is that these special instruments, as the name implies, are special - and that means they are above the limits, outside the limits of the multiannual financial framework. A word to regret that the Council has once again tried to provoke and condition Parliament. As it is more than evident, a political declaration does not remove any prerogative from us, much less prerogatives that are enshrined in the Treaties and are, yes, mandatory in terms of respect and our competences, the competences in the annual budgetary process, these we will maintain them. I would like to end, Mr President, by thanking the Commission for the bold proposal it has made and, in particular, Commissioner Georgieva and the two presidencies for the success we have achieved, even though we know the difficulty, the delay and the need for unanimity for this objective.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Presidency of the Council, from the S & amp; D Group we have on numerous occasions expressed our concern regarding the structural insufficiencies and the scarcity of available resources in the context of the current financial framework. During the negotiation of this financial framework, we already warned of the terrible consequences of the reduction of resources compared to the previous framework, and we opposed it. And thanks to this opposition, we were at least able to achieve some achievements: greater flexibility, a mandatory mid-term review, a roadmap for reform of the Union's revenue system, and even some new priorities such as, for example, the European Youth Guarantee. And thank goodness we achieved those improvements, because to the multiple crises that the Union is facing today, we should have also added the budgetary crisis. In these first years we have squeezed one hundred percent all the margins of action that we had to finance new needs such as, for example, launching the European investment plan, care for refugees, humanitarian aid or the fight against youth unemployment. But make no mistake: this has had significant budgetary consequences, especially in areas such as competitiveness, research or transport. That is why this review is so important, because we have no room for action; We cannot continue cutting programs to finance new needs, because these needs are still there. And that is why we also value this review positively: it represents a potential increase of EUR 6 billion between now and 2020, and this will allow us to reinforce key programs for the future of the Union in research, transport or education. It will also allow us to give greater support to SMEs, duplicate the European investment plan and re-finance in a once the Youth Employment Initiative. And furthermore, this will also give us the possibility of launching new investment and development plans for neighboring countries, providing resources to the European Asylum Support Office or developing a true European policy for managing our borders. . But regrettably, once again, the Council - I believe - has not been ambitious or courageous enough to dare to make a real review based on a rigorous analysis of needs and priorities, and putting all the necessary means. But we in this Parliament do not lose hope. As soon as we approve this review, we are going to get to work - the Commission is going to do that too - without wasting a single minute on a new proposal for the future. We know very well that changing the dynamics - as the Council reminded us - and decisions in the Council is a task that requires a great deal of patience. We know that we have to continue to insist and that we have to show, day by day, that things can and should be done differently and better. But that's why, as Einstein said, we succeeded because we didn't know it was impossible.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! There is a great deal in this draft report that is absolutely correct and guaranteed undisputed. However, one important ingredient is missing, and that is the courage, namely the courage to leave these well-trodden paths that we have now seen in the EU for a long time. We saw the vote on a Brexit. Why did it all happen? Why are the citizens of this EU a little bit tired? Because it is too complex, the EU is not understood. You want a lean, transparent EU. We should deliver it, but it starts with a good budget. And here we would have the unique opportunity to say when we revise the MFF: Where do we want to focus? We always talk about the fact that we want to fight unemployment, that we want to increase competitiveness - absolutely undisputed. But the question is: are we going to increase competitiveness in such a way that we redistribute as much money as possible through subsidies? Nobody seriously believes that. We can certainly increase competitiveness. But then we have to ensure that the excessive bureaucracy is ended, that we leave the forces of the market free within the framework of social ties, but otherwise free, but not through an ever-growing budget with more and more money that we pay out. That won't be the solution. We need money to be able to help in solidarity. We need money to be able to tackle the big tasks, for example migration policy. We have to invest money for this, but you also need an overall concept.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, finally! This is the word I want to use as our Assembly gives its consent to the proposed revision of the multiannual financial framework. The road has been long and strewn with pitfalls. First there was - I want to emphasize this - the ambitious report by our colleagues Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, whom I would like to congratulate once again. Then there was the Commission proposal which, even if it fell short of our expectations, represented a good basis for discussion. There was also the good performance of the Slovak Presidency, which surprised many and which I had unfairly criticized. Finally, there was the hesitation of the Italian government, which added a little suspense, making this file a mini political thriller. So relief, because there will be - Mr Olbrycht reminded us - a first. Satisfaction is certainly not total, but partial and with measured enthusiasm. Of course, there is indisputable progress: the overall margin for payments increased by some five billion, the increase in the means of the flexibility instrument and the reserve for emergency aid, the partial removal of the limitations which affect the scope of the global margin for commitments, 1,200,000,000 euros intended for the youth employment initiative, 875 million reserved for programs that are close to our hearts (Erasmus +, Horizon 2020, Cosme, etc.). Even if it does not have the necessary scale, this progress deserves to be welcomed and supported. Having said that - and I regret to have to say it - meanness is not entirely absent from the Council's proposal. He has indeed seen fit to add to these few improvements some joint statements which he asks our assembly to approve. The aim of one of his statements is to get the consent of the European Parliament to the limitation increases in funds allocated to programs that we consider strategic.This somewhat pitiful maneuver prompted a unilateral declaration on our part which reminds us of the inalienable nature of our prerogatives in budgetary matters.Clearly, a declaration cannot change treaties.In conclusion, Distinguished Presidents, dear colleagues, I am sure that this revision will not be sufficient to face the challenges that we will have to face by 2020, but it is a small step forward, even if it remains measured.And a little progress is always better than a big failure.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, cé go bhfuil céimeanna beaga tógtha – agus cuirim fáilte roimh an tsolúbthacht sin, i ndáiríre cad is féidir linn a rá faoin Creat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil seachas: Plus ça change? An tseanreitric chéanna, na torthaí céanna agus na botúin chéanna; agus ní athróidh sé seo mórán. I measc na n-athruithe agus na neamhchinnteachta go léir atá os ár gcomhair, cuireann sé ionadh orm gur tháinig an Chomhairle ar ais chugainn leis na moltaí céanna a chuireadar os ár gcomhair i mí na Samhna. Bhí deis againn machnamh a dhéanamh ar na géarchéimeanna atá ag teacht aníos orainn agus dul i ngleic leo; dul i dtreo níos fearr dár bpobal, agus infheistiú ceart a dhéanamh i samhail eacnamaíochta éagsúil, a chuireann béim ar dhlúthpháirtíocht idir ár dtíortha agus laistigh dár sochaí.  In Éirinn, agus ar fud na hEorpa aithníonn na daoine go bhfuil an tAontas Eorpach ag athrú. Cén fáth nach nglacann an Coimisiún leis na fíricí seo agus iad ag cur moltaí ar an MFF os comhar na Parlaiminte? Cén fáth nach n-aithnítear go bhfuil gá dul i ngleic leis an drochthionchar a bheidh ag Brexit orainne in Éirinn agus maoiniú agus tacaíocht a chur ar fáil dúinn – dár bhfeirmeoirí, dár SMEs, dár n-aos óg ó thaobh fostaíochta de agus dár bpobail?  Muna n-aithníonn an Coimisiún agus an Chomhairle go bhfuil an tAontas Eorpach ag tráth na cinniúna táimid i dtrioblóid, agus i dtrioblóid mhór. Caithimid aghaidh a thabhairt ar an eagla a chuir leis an toradh Brexit sa Bhreatain. Caithimid dul i ngleic leis na buarthaí sin atá ag daoine maidir leis an todhchaí agus treo chun cinn a aimsiú. Is crosbhóthar atá os ár gcomhair anois, agus tá sé thar am dúinn an treo ceart a thógaint; is é sin infheistíocht a dhéanamh in Aontas atá bunaithe ar dhaonlathas, dlúthpháirtíocht agus dul chun cinn sóisialta.  É sin ráite, ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a ghabháil le Isabelle Thomas agus Jan Olbrycht as an obair fhónta atá déanta acu.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Whether the glass is half empty or half full depends, of course, on perspective. An optimist or a pessimist, a People's Party or a Social Democrat, a Portuguese, a Greek or a Finn - the perspective is different. I would like to say that this glass is half-empty, because 9 months ago we called for - and adopted in this House - decisions that would have given us the opportunity not only to strengthen the European Union's policies verbally, but also financially. I liked Commissioner Oettinger's speech because he repeatedly emphasized the word 'flexibility', but the paradox is that flexibility is confused between seven-year planning and annual planning. And now we are lean on the compromise that seems bad to the Group of the Greens. The glass is half-empty because our suggestions have not been sufficiently taken into account. And that is why we think we should stop supporting this initiative. But I would like to conclude by saying that the Council - the European governments - did not want to give us that glass either, and that is why we must commend the governments for getting to that side. And the next time we do the MFF for the new financial perspective, I would recommend that the Commission and the council give us a glass of just as much - half, but a better drink.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, these reports are a massive obfuscation, confusion and sleight-of-hand manoeuvring which would not be out of place in a logic puzzle book. Of course we want to pay off debts as quickly as possible, but this is just an accounting ruse to spend more taxpayers’ money in the coming years. And then, incredibly, in the other report we are finding more ways to move money outside of EU budgetary ceilings so that we can spend even more taxpayers’ money next year. And then for the first time ever they do not even schedule a debate on the report on Parliament’s proposed expenditure for 2018, which includes British taxpayers paying for things that we will never see the benefit of, but of course the EU will never mention that in their divorce bill. This whole knotted mess is not unravelable, so let us take a sword to this Gordian knot.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Thank you, Mr President. I thank the Council, I thank the Commission for being here tonight and I thank the Commission and first of all Commissioner Georgieva for succeeding in imposing this exercise on the Commission, rectification, for the first time and including in that proposal, at that time, many of Parliament's proposals. A much greater flexibility has been reached, which has allowed the use of sums for policies that are currently extremely necessary. I'm talking about young people, migration. I hope that the vote in Parliament tomorrow will approve this proposal because it would be a big step backwards if there were a negative vote. We got a lot of things, we didn't get everything, we didn't get what might have been much better, but it's still a big step forward. I hope that the responsibility will prevail and the vote will be in favor of this proposal. Commissioner, you mentioned the proposal you have to make this year for the new financial year. I think that there you could take into account the part of this rectification in which it was not possible to approve the use of money, of the amounts disengaged, because this solution could solve many of the possible emergencies that occurred along the way. In 2014-2015 over 280 billion were paid and much of this money was paid for projects started before 2014. It is under the treaty, but this situation will probably again cause problems at the end of the financial year with payments for cohesion. If the money were transferred in full next year, I don't think there would be this problem.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, Minister, ladies and gentlemen! I am pleased that we have succeeded in getting the revision of the multiannual financial framework through and that the European Parliament has succeeded in achieving this mid-term review for the first time. Because even then the European Parliament was right in making this request. It was already apparent in 2013 that the tasks for the EU would increase, and it is not the case that more and more political tasks could be done with less and less money. Nor is that true because some finance ministers occasionally claim so. If we want to stimulate growth and employment, then we need more investment in research and innovation - that has been achieved. If we want to give the unemployed and young people a perspective, especially in the south of the European Union, then we must continue the European Youth Initiative. We pushed through additional money - if not enough in my opinion. If we want to get the problems of migration under control, then we have to eliminate the causes of flight. Now peace in Syria is not in our hands, but we can make a contribution to providing aid in the neighboring states of Syria. Help is not only needed there. I am thinking of UNRWA, the UN relief agency for the Palestinians. I am thinking of West Africa, where security and economic prospects need to be developed. And here, too, more should be done, and the additional funds that have been decided are at least a start. Finally, the dimension of the refugee movement to Europe has made it necessary to increase the domestic policy efforts considerably. Joint border protection and additional means for integration were such overwhelming challenges that even the narrowest of finance ministers could not ignore these needs. These are just some of the challenges we face today. The European The Bratislava Council decided on a new agenda in the common security and defense policy.Does anyone in this room, who understands anything about this matter, believe that this agenda can be realized in the corset of today's, current financial framework?No, it is clear: the current medium-term financial framework is the cause of the chronic underfunding, so the new medium-term financial framework must change this from 2021 at the latest.It is about new tasks that must mean additional resources - either this or the Member States must find the strength to agree on what the EU should no longer do in the future.And this can be more successful if the Member States start a constructive discussion on the Monti Group's own resources report and finally give Parliament and the European Union what we need.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Taking the floor in the debate on the review of the financial framework, I would like to emphasize that the Polish delegation in the ECR group is in favor of adopting the solutions proposed in both reports by Mr Olbrycht and Mrs Thomas. In view of the unprecedented scale of challenges arising from instability in the Union's southern and eastern neighboring countries, causing massive migratory flows and related security threats, the Union must have both additional financial resources and new instruments that will allow us to face these challenges. Therefore, allocating an additional amount of EUR 2.5 billion for activities related to migration and EUR 1.4 billion for combating the causes of migration, creating a new instrument in the form of a crisis reserve, financed from decommitted funds, or other solutions to make the EU budget more flexible, are decisions that will allow to respond adequately to the scale of threats resulting from mass migration.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Mr President, could we for a moment go back to the discussion we had about two years ago in these solemn surroundings and remember what the Council then said or what the Commissioner then said? You should actually have shown the courage to say you were totally wrong. When you look at the figures then you see that you were wrong. You are not on the page of reality, and this is disturbing because this reality is going to be there for the next few years, and if you do not learn to read the reality then you are coming back to this Parliament again with an approach which is totally unacceptable, because it is unintellectual. I congratulate you on being stupid.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: - Mr President, we should be there this evening to be satisfied with an increase of 0.28% for the next three years, and we should also come and cry victory in a concert of self-satisfaction?Be serious!Not only is this increase small, it is also backed by state strangulation.Where is the big overhaul we were promised, that big overhaul for the combat budget that we need to face the challenges?The reality is that we are not getting out of the bind and the austerity logics that underlie everything, prevent everything and continue to offer the only prospect for the people to suffer again, again and again.Sad prospect for the people and for Europe.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger! So today we are talking about adjusting the EU budget. Above all, the EU spent a lot of money in the migration crisis and thus exceeded the prescribed framework, and now funds from other budget items are to be reallocated. I can say two things. First: the EU budget obviously has billions that can be reallocated. That means the EU has too much money. We should change that. Second: The crisis has become very expensive because some EU states have not protected their external borders. If all the illegal migrants hadn't come, it would have been a lot cheaper. So above all we need law-abiding border guards, and we should then help the EU foreign states with border security, help with money, and gladly help with EU money. But first and foremost, we note that there are billions that can be repurposed. So there are too many billions in this budget. They have to be deleted.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Mr President, I am sorry that, many times, we are generous and level in our criticism, reaching zero and, in fact, not recognizing any success, while we are very sparing in giving praise, congratulations and positive greetings. actions and actions. I have to pay tribute to the dear rapporteurs, Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, and to the Commissioner, Mr Oettinger, for really fighting hard and taking a small step, as some have called it, for us, a major success. a small feat under the current circumstances, namely the revision of the multiannual financial framework, which was an obstacle for us to be able to implement our policies and strategies. We criticize and say that there are no jobs. And we are looking for jobs. This is the way to create jobs. And we have succeeded, through this revision of the multiannual financial framework, in sending the message that Europe can, that Europe is moving forward, that Europe, through hard work, as was done by our dear colleagues and the Commissioner, is able to show the good, her positive face, positive actions. This is the Europe we want, the Europe that can, in this difficult time, channel six billion for youth unemployment, for the European Strategic Investment Plan, for innovation, for Horizon 2020, for COSME, for the "Connecting Europe Facility", for all these programs we are all looking for. It is not right, therefore, now that we are given the opportunity through this important success, to try in any way to reduce these achievements. I think the message is clear. Europe shows that it cares about its citizens. It is Europe that has its social face, which in practice, through this review, proves once again that, when it wants, it can become the Europe of citizens, the Europe of young people, the Europe of small and medium-sized enterprises, the Europe of the social person, social policy and action and not of reaction, nihilism, negativity and flattening.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, the frequently unspoken truth about the EU budget is that it is put to very good use. It is used to support the lives of citizens across Europe. My part in this review has been to focus on the Horizon 2020 programme which funds cutting-edge scientific research and facilitates the largest research area in the world, and to focus on CEF, the Connecting Europe Facility, which develops better digital, transport and energy connections for EU citizens, the arteries of our modern world. As our world gets smaller, our challenges get larger. It is essential that we work together to find ways to protect and enhance citizens’ lives. The budget funds research into rare diseases, into cancers, into new energy sources – our future world will be shaped by this funding. It is developing space technologies, graphene and quantum computing. The great minds of our continent value this collaboration. Beyond this, the revision focuses on the responsibility we have regarding the refugee crisis. Recognising it benefits all of us to support the Member States who are doing most to fulfil our international and moral obligations and responsibilities to protect refugees and to police Europe’s borders.  This revision recognises these issues. It is long overdue for us to restate the fundamental principle that we are better, stronger and more effective when we work together. That does not just apply to individual citizens; it applies to regions and it applies to countries, and the EU is the embodiment of this.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: -Mr President,I am glad thatParliament and the Councilwith the support ofthe Commissionreached anagreement on therevision ofthe multiannual budgetas the Councilorcalled a "package".It is important that the agreement is now adhered to and that the spending ceilings are not slipped.The budget should not be increased during the rest of the season.This also means that payment appropriations for specific financial instruments should not be exceeded above the ceiling of the financial framework.The EU cannot demand more money for its own, while at the same time the Member States have to cut services and live on austerity, or at least within very strict limits.Finally, we have not yet reached the target of a 5% reduction in staff.It is good that this is now being clarified, so that in this case, too, we are acting in such a way that, once a 5% reduction has been agreed, it will be done.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework has been overtaken by events. Brexit, the investment crisis, the banking crisis, the poverty generated in the periphery and the border crisis show that the corsets to which this framework obliges us have failed. It is not enough to do budget engineering to move small figures or to resort to private investment plans and guarantee funds that escape democratic control to patch the problems we face. We need a policy that enhances the Union's own resources, a policy based on direct and progressive taxation, together with national contributions based on the economic capacity and weighted by the per capita income of each country; a multiannual financial framework that, in terms of spending, is capable of fueling a new and ambitious public investment plan for Europe, of a socio-ecological nature and generating employment, in initiatives committed to changing the model and to the energy transition.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, needless to say I was one of the MEPs that was sceptical about this MFF revision. Not because it is not a classical European document, but simply because it is not responding to what Europeans are requesting today. I mean by that: investment in job creation; proactive youth policies; instruments designed to reduce the development gap between regions; digital skills programmes; and the list may continue.  I am not referring here only to numbers, I am referring here to the political message that the Council and the Commission are sending to European citizens by this revision. The message is that the EU does not have any new solutions. We seem blocked in the austerity mentality. We take money from one pocket to put in another pocket, hoping we will not need them any more, like the EUR 2 billion ‘possible’ unused funds from the Solidarity Fund and the Globalisation Fund we hope to reshuffle. I am a former entrepreneur but also a Social Democrat and I can tell you for a fact that if you want fresh money you need to invest more in the things that can help your business grow. In this sense we, the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, want to help, therefore we support the plan to reinforce with almost EUR 1 billion the growth and jobs programmes, like Horizon 2020, Connecting Europe Facility, Erasmus+, COSME, Wifi4EU and even EFSI, but we need fresh money. We need to think ahead especially for the next MFF. If we want to plan for the future I do not understand why we are only allocating EUR 700 million to the Youth Employment Initiative for the next few years. This represents a lot less than what we are spending as European institutions on IT and digital services. Two million young people, true pro-Europeans, have benefited from the Youth Employment Initiative since its creation. People do not have maybe the time to focus so much on numbers but they are surely focusing on the political message, and the political message that I want to send today as a true pro-European is that the European Parliament is thinking about them. I hope in the future that the Council and the Commission will understand the need to go beyond numbers and start speaking to people directly about what we plan to invest and to do with taxpayers’ money at European level.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, first of all I would like to express my support for the proposed change to the multiannual financial framework, as I believe that the draft regulation amending the multiannual framework is an important step towards optimizing the implementation of the European Union budget and the preparation of the future multiannual financial framework after 2020. The project enshrines the principle of achieving maximum flexibility of the budget to address unforeseen problems and circumstances. Increasing the maximum amounts for the adjustment of the payment ceilings for the years 2018-2020 within the overall payment margin, as well as the abolition of the ceilings for growth and employment policy objectives, in particular youth employment, and migration and security , is a step in the direction we need. The proposal also addresses the possible accumulation of unpaid bills and a new payment crisis resulting from the delay in the implementation of operational programs.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - We are today discussing the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. A short financial framework, less and less oriented towards cohesion and which reinforces the foreign policy areas and which, at the time, deserved our vote against. The budgetary execution of the first half of the term ended up demonstrating the correctness of our position. The divergences between countries and regions increase - with peripheral countries trapped in the austerity trap with low levels of investment and growing indebtedness - the European Union's own indebtedness also increases, returning to the spectrum of cyclically defaulting payments. This review, instead of considering this reality by reinforcing the cohesion funds, ends up accentuating the problems that we denounce, mobilizing, above all, the flexibility instruments for the security and citizenship and foreign policy headings, to the detriment of measures that foster the creation of job. In this way, we continue with a budget that does not answer the real problems of the European Union, privileging the militaristic and security aspects.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, this revision of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 is a victory. It's a victory to be tempered, but a victory nonetheless. This is a victory for the European Parliament and in this regard I would like to thank the work of my colleague from the Socialists and Democrats Group, Isabelle Thomas, as well as that of the co-rapporteur, Jan Olbrycht. They remained pugnacious and patient throughout these negotiations and knew how to ensure respect for the prerogatives of the European Parliament, which is also the guarantor of democracy. This victory should not, however, obscure the urgent need to think bigger, to aim higher, to think more daringly. After nearly three years in office in the European Parliament, I unfortunately never ceased to point out that the budget of the European Union is insufficient and that it must be supplied by own resources, themselves drawn from funds. resources necessary for ecological and societal challenges. "To not have the courage of your opinion is to have no opinion" wrote the Frenchman Émile de Girardin in his Pensées et Maximes in 1867. It is now time to stop bracing yourself to existing and sustainably lead the world of tomorrow. For this, a more ambitious budget is necessary, especially since new policies must be implemented each year and their financing cannot come from the stripping of structural policies, such as the CAP and cohesion policies.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, at the beginning I would like to congratulate Mr Olbrycht and Ms Thomas for their dedication and work. I think we have a reason to be positive tonight. I am proud that I am part of Parliament, managing to achieve a historical breakthrough, managing to achieve a top-up agreement above the MFF in the remaining three years of that MFF. This is how we are going to provide additional funding for programmes such as the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), Erasmus, COSME, EFSI, Youth Employment Initiative, and so on and so forth. In my view, this is not expenditure, this is not spending, this is an investment in the future of this Union. This is what it is, and this is a success, nothing but success.  I do believe that EFSI is a working initiative. It is providing results as it was designed to do, but I am convinced that structural and investment funds should remain a key source of financing of large infrastructure projects in the developing regions in the countries where this is needed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I think that the debate on the revision of the multiannual financial framework has raised a number of issues. First of all, it is important that there is flexibility. Flexibility, however, should not be limited to foreign policy issues. We must also have the necessary flexibility in dealing with unemployment. That is where, Commissioner, we need to put more emphasis so that we can tackle the scourge of unemployment. The second issue is the strengthening of actions to combat immigration, because Europe is full of refugees and too many, I would say, illegal immigrants. The agricultural sector must also be strengthened, as well as actions that can reduce the gap between north and south, the European south, which is currently suffering from austerity and violent fiscal adjustment.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr President, I congratulate and thank the rapporteurs, my colleague Olbrycht and my colleague Thomas.The revision messages of the multiannual framework are very clear and encouraging.First, we know and can respond to new challenges.Secondly, we are building Europe as a global leader and that is why we are increasing spending on innovation, research, connecting science and economy, education, entrepreneurs, transport connections.Thirdly, investments in education and youth employment are particularly important to us, and this is an important message to Member States to develop national programs as well.And fourth, we want a strong cohesion and agricultural policy.Therefore, national envelopes remain as they are and it is important to speed up implementation.This audit is a good combination of the security and flexibility that the budget must have, and Commissioner Oettinger has also emphasized it several times.It is up to us, of course, to use the funds efficiently through smart projects.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Let me start by thanking the rapporteurs for their determination to act in preparing such an important and courageous report. It is a new approach, maybe not new, maybe just new, but effective. New solutions for the implementation of the multiannual financial framework are taking shape. This is important as additional opportunities are created to respond to new challenges. Mention was made of unemployment, refugees, youth, Horizon 2020, innovation and the Erasmus + program. The introduction of flexibility will give us a chance to use funds that has not been available before. The long period of the multiannual financial framework underlined here today makes it necessary to make changes to the budget during this great implementation. The proposed solutions are well received in the circles of future beneficiaries. Omnibus raises a lot of hopes, among others, a number of simplifications, especially in the complex and difficult common agricultural policy. This direction of changes requires further determination in action. Please state! It is also a good start for work on the new financial perspective.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, can I join with others in congratulating the joint rapporteurs on this topic, Ms Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, for their work. Like others, I consider it is important that we have a flexible mechanism to ensure, over a seven-year period, when new priorities arise, that we can respond to that in a clever way, and that is exactly what we are discussing here today, and hopefully in the vote tomorrow that will be successful. Just two points. My first point is this, that the overall budget is of course a tiny percentage of gross overall expenditure within the European Union, and the most effective way to ensure that we have more money to spend, and that we spend it wisely in a reformed way, is to ensure that we have growth across the 28 Member States of the European. That is happening this year. We see significant growth in the euro zone, we see three million additional jobs within the euro zone. Despite all the negativity that exists about the euro zone and Europe, Europe is coming back faster with a higher growth rate, and that is the most important way that we can ensure that we have additional funds to put into key investment for the European Union via the budget.

name: Brian HAYES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to express my thanks to the two rapporteurs, Mrs Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, as well as my thanks to my predecessor, Mrs Georgieva. We listened very carefully to your requests to speak and I can see that a large majority of the speakers supported the package. In some cases, greater expectations have been mentioned, but it is progress and it helps to make future budgetary policy more efficient and therefore better. With this mid-term review - and I mention the omnibus in the addition, on which I also ask for your constructive cooperation - we can make better use of the budget, up to 100%. This has not been the case in the past. The exhaustion of the budget, efficiency and flexibility are the main implications of this package to be discussed this evening. It's a package - I want to remind you of that too. The revision, the mid-term review, the change in law on the one hand and the declarations on the other. I would like to ask you to adapt accordingly to the overall vote. Thanks again to everyone involved.

name: Brian HAYES
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill. - Grazzi Chairman. Grazzi wkoll lil kull Membru li kkontribwixxa mhux biss fis-seduta tal-lum imma f’dan il-proċess: proċess li kien wienħed sensitiv u li fih ried jintlaħaq il-bilanċ u l-kompromess li kulħada irħferh għalih. Hemm u uud illi kieni jixtiequ riżultati aktar ambizzjużi, però naħseb illi pprevala l-ottimiżmu anki tal-Membri li tkellmu llejla u naħseb illi, kif qal anki l-Kummissarju, dan għandu issa jinkuraġġina liie qġudiem g'd quddiemna: l-isfidi tal-immigrazzjoni irregolari, l-isfidi dwar is-sigurtà tal-kontinent tagana u ċ-ċittadini li qegħdin jitolbu li dan il-kontinent ikun aktar sigur. Però mbagfad għandna sfidi oħrajn; sfidi bħal dik tat-tkabbir ekonomiku u anki ż-żgħażagħ illi għaddejjin minn nuqqas ta 'impjegabilità u anki opportunitajiet, u li dak illi - jekk for the purposes of this Regulation. Jiena ningħaqad magħkom ilkoll u anki mal-Kummissarju Oettinger sabiex nirringrazzja lil dawk kollha li kkontribwixxew: -rapporteurs is-Sur Olbrycht u s-Sinjura Thomas, kif-ukoll anki l-President tal-Kumitat tal-Baġit, il-Kummissjoni Ewropea, il-Predeċessur tal-Kummissarju Oettinger, il-Kummisarju Georgieva, kif ukoll anki lilek, Sur Kummissarju , and the President of the Slovak Republic, of the former Yugoslav Republic of Malta, of the Maltese Republic, of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Mr. Minister! Commissioner! I think this debate has made it very clear that the situation is not clear for all of us in the European Parliament. For us, the most important thing - and it came with great difficulty - was to convince the Council (I think a big thank you to the Slovak Presidency, but also to the Maltese Presidency) with very much help from the European Commission that the financial perspective is not something that is rigid. It was crucial for us to show that if there are new challenges and tasks, there is a chance or even a need for change. I think this is crucial in the whole matter. On the one hand, of course, there are additional financial resources, but above all, it is important that the European Union budget is flexible, so that it can react to external actions. On the other hand, it seems to me that in the debate on the revision, we made it clear what can be done within the European budget. Unfortunately, it is impossible to do everything within the framework of the European budget, and it makes no sense to lie to the inhabitants of the European Union to the contrary. This revision clearly showed what we can and cannot do, how we can do it more efficiently, effectively, wisely, and to what extent we are ready for change. Our common achievement and victory lies in the fact that, with the help of the European Commission, we have convinced governments and ministers that we can react to certain changes with the budget, that the budget is an instrument for implementing a certain policy and not something that is given once and for all and stiff.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, dear colleagues, on the occasion of this last stage, I would obviously like to thank Commissioner Georgieva, who accompanied us at the start of the process, as well as Commissioner Oettinger, who facilitated its conclusion. I would also like to thank the Slovak Presidency as well as the Maltese Presidency and the representatives of the Member States, who have played a decisive role in this endeavor, even though - and I forgive them - they slipped us a little banana peel at our end of the process. I would also like to thank my colleagues in Parliament, those of today, but also those who, in 2013, gave birth to the revision project, and those who, with the steadfastness of the gardener, made it flourish. Too bad Mr Kölmel is gone, because I wanted to tell him that I too want Parliament to show courage. Courage, as Jean Jaurès said, "is to seek the truth and to speak it". The truth about the Union's budget is to say that it is not in line with the stated priorities. To tell the truth is to declare that in order to weigh on the world, we need a powerful Europe, it is to say that with a budget less than 1% of GDP, the budget is still only a drop of water which does not allow to weigh with all its power. Telling the truth also means saying that the Union risks dying from the inaction and reluctance of governments, and that if we do not find a budgetary structure made up mainly of own resources for a genuinely European budget, we cannot 'will not succeed. But this will be examined by our rapporteurs on own resources, to whom I wish the greatest courage.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday 5 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing.- With the approval of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, we as Parliament give a clear message of the importance of an increased EU budgetary capacity, which translates into an additional 6 billion for the 2017-2020 phase.While adding up the crisis and the emergencies on which governments and citizens are asking the EU to get busy, too often we have not found that Member States are open to considering the necessary appropriations or the appropriate flexibility to deal with thenecessary action on problems such as employment, growth and management of migratory flows.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - In the 2016 resolution that anticipated the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework - which is being updated due to the changed political, economic and social priorities of the EU -, Parliament highlighted horizontal critical issues (misalignment between the mandate of Parliament and the Commission and budgetary planning; MFF with respect to contingencies; need for own resources for the European budget), and thematic priorities: for the Culture Commission, the need to adequately finance Creative Europe, Europe for Citizens, review the management criteria of Erasmus +. The compromise reached is a positive step: it allows greater flexibility and increases funding for initiatives for young people, in particular to combat youth unemployment. Italy's "suspended veto" has allowed for better financing of initiatives for refugees and migrants. However, there remains a sense of the inadequacy of planning the multiannual budget, and the impression that some Member States are more likely to request returns from the European budget than to give the EU the means to act in its areas of competence. I am confident, however, that this review is a first step towards sound, fair, sustainable budget planning, and that Parliament's concerns are properly addressed in the new Financial Framework for post-2020.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Neena Gill, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on money market funds (COM (2013) 0615 - C7-0263 / 2013 - 2013/0306 (COD))(A8-0041 / 2015).

name: Neena GILL
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, 1 310 is the number of days between the publication of the proposal on the money market funds regulation and when we will actually have the final vote on this matter – tomorrow. This must be close to a record: money market funds (MMFs) have been held up for more than three years and four Council presidencies, because it is one of the most contentious and complex pieces of legislation we have ever dealt with. It has been a long journey, but I am delighted we have reached the right destination, an overall agreement between Parliament and the Council. I believe this is a win-win, both for the European money market fund sector and for the European taxpayer, who will be better protected. With assets under management of around EUR 1 trillion, MMFs are an important source of short-term financing for financial institutions, corporations and governments. In Europe, around 22% of short-term debt securities issued by governments or by the corporate sector are held by MMFs. Money market funds hold 38% of the short debt issued by the banking sector.  Because of the systemic inter-connectedness between MMFs, the banking sector and corporate and government finance, their operation has been at the core of international work on shadow banking. As a result, MMFs have been scrutinised by various regulators and supervisors. Indeed, the financial crisis of 2007-2008 showed that MMFs can be vulnerable to shocks and may even spread or amplify risks. This can fuel an investor run and liquidity crisis, foreign MMFs potentially triggering negative effects on other parts of the financial system. The agreement we have reached under the Slovak Presidency that we will vote on tomorrow addresses these systemic concerns, in particular through the following measures: liquidity and diversification requirements are strengthened, with strict daily and weekly liquidity requirements to fulfil potential redemption requests, and furthermore, the MMF portfolio will be more diversified, with stringent concentration requirements to reduce risks; assets in which MMFs can invest, including government debt, have been more strictly regulated; sponsored support to these funds is forbidden, to avoid any contagion risk; we have addressed provisions for transparency in more detail; a review clause for government CNAVs has been introduced; after five years, the Commission will report on the feasibility of establishing an 80% EU public debt quota; the report will look at the availability of short—term EU public debt instruments...
